choices.text: High HDV viral load
High HBV viral load
Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies
Absence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies

questions.text:
Serologic findings of a patient with hepatitis are given below: (INICET NOV 2022)

  • HBsAg positive
  • Anti-HBc IgM positive
  • Anti-HDV IgM positive
  • Anti-HBc IgG negative
  • Titer of HBV DNA: 7.4 x 10⁸
  • Titer of HDV DNA: 4.1 x 10⁴

Which of the following is most useful in diagnosing HDV co-infection over superinfection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Absence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies

 

Anti-HBc IgG antibodies are markers of chronic hepatitis B infection. Their presence along with anti-HDV antibodies would suggest a superinfection of hepatitis D virus (HDV) on top of chronic hepatitis B infection.

 

The absence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies indicates an acute episode of hepatitis B, which suggests HBV/HDV co-infection. Co-infection occurs when a person is simultaneously infected with both HBV and HDV, leading to acute hepatitis with signs and symptoms such as fatigue, jaundice, and dark urine. Co-infection typically resolves with recovery and viral eradication in most cases.

 

In contrast, HDV superinfection occurs when an individual who is already chronically infected with HBV acquires HDV. Superinfection tends to result in more severe disease progression, and the absence of anti-HBc IgG helps differentiate co-infection from superinfection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High HDV viral load: The viral load of HDV can be elevated in both co-infection and superinfection, making it not a reliable marker for distinguishing between the two conditions.

 

Option B. High HBV viral load: HBV viral load is not the most relevant marker in distinguishing between co-infection and superinfection, as it may vary depending on the phase of infection and other factors. HBV viral load can be high in both conditions.

 

Option C. Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies: The presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies indicates a recent or ongoing HDV infection, but it does not differentiate between co-infection and superinfection since both can result in the production of these antibodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of hepatitis B and D, the absence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies indicates an acute co-infection of HBV and HDV. This finding helps distinguish co-infection from superinfection, which typically occurs in patients with chronic HBV infection and is marked by the presence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies. Co-infection generally has a better prognosis compared to superinfection, which is more likely to lead to chronic disease and cirrhosis.

questions.text: The viruses of the filoviridae family like Ebola and Marburg resemble which of the following morphologies? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3

 

  • Viruses belonging to the filoviridae family, such as Ebola and Marburg, resemble the morphology shown in image 3.
  • Image 3 - Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Image 1- Influenza viruses have linear segmented, single-stranded RNA.

 

 

Image 2- Adenovirus is an icosahedroal symmetry with fibres extruding from vertices and contains double-stranded DNA.

 

 

Image 4 - Corona virus is non-segmented single-stranded RNA virus.

 

Coronavirus Structure

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Filoviruses, such as Ebola and Marburg, are filamentous and contain nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

questions.text: The clinical finding in the 10-year-old boy includes fever, joint pain, and a hand lesion as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis based on these findings? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gottron's papules - Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

  • Juvenile dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease affecting the skin and muscles. It typically presents in children with a characteristic skin rash and muscle weakness.
  • Gottron's papules are distinctive red or violet, raised, scaly lesions seen over knuckles (dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints), elbows, knees, and other extensor surfaces, highly suggestive of dermatomyositis.
  • The combination of fever, joint pain, and Gottron's papules strongly indicates juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Other features associated with Dermatomyositis are:

 

  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.

 

 

Gottron's sign: seen in the above image

 

  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as seen in the image below

 

 

  • Periungual telangiectasias: enlarged capillaries in the nail folds.

 

 

  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

 

 

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid nodules - Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis:

 

  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder causing chronic joint inflammation in children.
  • Rheumatoid nodules are firm, painless, subcutaneous nodules that usually occur in areas of pressure but are not typically seen in the hands in this form.
  • The lesion in the image doesn't match the typical appearance of rheumatoid nodules.

 

Option C Sclerodactyly - Systemic sclerosis:

 

  • Systemic sclerosis is a connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and hardening (scleroderma).
  • Sclerodactyly refers to thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers and hands, leading to a claw-like appearance.
  • The lesion shown doesn't indicate the skin thickening or tightness characteristic of sclerodactyly.

 

Option D Mechanic's hand - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease affecting multiple organ systems.
  • Mechanic's hand is a sign associated more with dermatomyositis than SLE, characterized by rough, cracked skin on the sides of the fingers, mimicking the hands of a manual labourer.
  • The presentation of mechanic's hand in SLE is less common and the symptoms described do not align well with SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case involving fever, joint pain, and hand lesions in a child, the presence of Gottron's papules is indicative of Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53 page no 53.1-53.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page 2820-2821

questions.text: What of the following stain can be used for staining Iron in tissues? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prussian blue  

 

Perl's iron stain is the classic method for demonstrating iron in tissues. The section is treated with dilute hydrochloric acid to release ferric ions from binding proteins. These ions then react with potassium ferrocyanide to produce an insoluble blue compound (the Prussian blue reaction).

 

 

Used in hereditary hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue, lead toxicity to visualize iron-laden mitochondria of ring sideroblasts and myelodysplastic syndrome.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Masson's trichrome: This stain is used to differentiate between collagen and other tissue components. It stains collagen fibers blue or green, muscle fibers red, and cytoplasm light red or pink. It is not used for detecting iron.

 

Option C. PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff): PAS stain is primarily used to detect glycogen and other polysaccharides in tissues. It stains these components magenta. PAS is not useful for detecting iron in tissues.

 

Option D. Fite-Faraco: This is a special stain used for detecting Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium responsible for leprosy. It is not used for staining iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prussian blue stain is specifically used for detecting iron deposits in tissues, particularly in cases of iron overload or iron-related disorders.

questions.text: In a diabetic patient, the following lesions are present in the armpit. What would be observed during a Wood's lamp examination? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coral red fluorescence.

 

  • The clinical scenario of a diabetic patient, along with the observed hyperpigmented lesion in axilla strongly suggests erythrasma.
  • Coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination is the characteristic finding in this disease.

 

 

Erythrasma

 

  • It is a skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with diabetes and weakened immune systems and is associated with factors such as obesity, excessive sweating, and poor hygiene.
  • The characteristic feature of erythrasma is the presence of hyperpigmented patches that are typically asymptomatic. These patches commonly appear in areas like the axilla, groin, intergluteal, and sub-mammary regions.
  • The coral pink fluorescence observed during Wood's lamp examination is a defining feature of erythrasma and is caused by coproporphyrin III, a pigment produced by the bacterium.

 

 

  • Wood's lamp uses ultraviolet wavelength light at 365nm (320-400nm) with a peak at 365nm. The filter of the Wood's lamp is composed of Barium silicate and 9% Nickel oxide.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Yellow fluorescence: Often seen with Pityriasis versicolor, which fluoresces yellow or apple green due to the presence of tryptophan metabolites produced by Malassezia species.

 

Option C. Blue fluorescence: Not commonly associated with bacterial or fungal infections of the skin but may appear in certain conditions unrelated to common skin infections.

 

Option D. Green fluorescence: Typically observed with Pseudomonas infections or some cases of Tinea capitis caused by fungi that produce substances that fluoresce green.

 

Additional Information

 

Table: Various diseases & their colour on woods lamp examination

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Wood's lamp uses UVA light with a wavelength of 365nm (320-400 nm) for the diagnosis of various skin conditions based on the fluorescence characteristics of the skin under this specific range of ultraviolet light.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.20

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 26 Page no 26.40

Image source: https://dermnetnz.org/assets/Uploads/bacterial/erythrasma13__WatermarkedWyJXYXRlcm1hcmtlZCJd.jpg

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) West Nile Virus

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can cause neurological disease and death in people. WNV is commonly found in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, North America and West Asia. In Mumbai in the year 1952, the antibodies against WNV were first detected in humans. Since then, the virus activity has been reported in southern, central, and western India. WNV is maintained in nature in a cycle involving transmission between birds and mosquitoes. Humans, horses and other mammals can be infected.

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) is a member of the flavivirus genus and belongs to the Japanese encephalitis antigenic complex of the family Flaviviridae.

 

West Nile virus can be diagnosed by a number of different tests:

 

  • IgG antibody sero-conversion (or significant increase in antibody titers) in two serial specimen collected at a one week interval by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • IgM antibody capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • neutralisation assays;
  • viral detection by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, and
  • virus isolation by cell culture.

 

IgM can be detected in nearly all cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum specimens received from WNV infected patients at the time of their clinical presentation. Serum IgM antibody may persist for more than a year.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Hendra virus is endemic to Australia

 

Option C: Ebola virus is endemic to Africa.

 

Option D: Yellow fever endemic to South and Central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Educational Objective

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can be identified by PCR and is endemic to India, with significant historical and ongoing presence, making it a critical pathogen for regional public health monitoring and response.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankyloblepharon

 

Ankyloblepharon is a condition where the upper and lower eyelids become attached to each other. This can happen as a congenital anomaly or due to adhesions that form during the healing process of traumatic wounds, ulcers, or chemical burns affecting the eyelid margins. Treatment involves removing the adhesions between the eyelid margins. In cases where adhesions extend to the angles, epithelial grafts should be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva in which the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball.

 

The image given below shows symblepharon.

 

 

Option C: Congenital blepharophimosis is a condition in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is decreased. It can be congenital or acquired and is due to a vertical skin fold at the lateral canthus. No treatment is required. In some cases, canthoplasty is done.

 

 

Option D: Congenital ptosis is a condition present since birth and is characterized by drooping of one or both upper eyelids due to developmental defects or weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. The affected individuals may also have lid lag on downward gaze. The most common treatment for congenital ptosis is surgical correction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankyloblepharon involves the fusion of the eyelid margins, which can be congenital or acquired, and requires surgical intervention to correct the adhesion and restore normal eyelid function and appearance.

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of human immunodeficiency virus. Which of the following drugs acts at step 5? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Raltegravir


The step 5 in the given image shows the step of integration of the viral genome into the host DNA with the help of Integrase enzyme. Among the above given drugs, Raltegravir can be used to block this step as it is an integrase inhibitor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enfuvirtide: It is fusion inhibitor, which acts by binding to gp41 protein on the surface of the virus. This inhibits the Step 1 of this diagram.

 

Option C. Tenofovir & Option D) Zidovudine: These are NRTIs which are used in combination therapy against HIV virus. NRTI works by inhibiting the activity of reverse transcriptase (Step 6 of the diagram), thereby, preventing the viral replication.

questions.text: In Which of the following pathways, cyclooxygenase is involved? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prostaglandin

 

Prostaglandins are derived from arachidonic acid, which is an essential fatty acid found in cell membranes. This process is mediated by Cyclooxygenases called, COX-1 and COX-2

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Kreb's cycle: Kreb's cycle is the terminal pathway for the oxidative catabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids, and fatty acids.

 

Option C. Leukotrienes: Leukotrienes are also produced from arachidonic acid with the help of lipoxygenases.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K is essential for the carboxylation of glutamate residues in certain proteins required for blood clotting. This process does not involve cyclooxygenase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclooxygenase is involved in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway, converting arachidonic acid into prostaglandins, which are key mediators of inflammation, pain, and other physiological responses.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tumor shown in the radiograph? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epiphyseal

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma):

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology:
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% malignant transformation. This is incorrect. Pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.

 

Option C. Ground glass opacity is diagnostic. This is incorrect. Ground glass opacity of the bone is seen in fibrous dysplasia.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy is the treatment. This is incorrect. The mainstay of treatment of GCT is curettage and stripping of the cavity. More aggressive tumors are treated by excision and bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.

questions.text: Which vaccine is not recommended to be given before splenectomy in a 5-year-old child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Typhoid vaccine

 

The typhoid vaccine is typically not recommended before splenectomy in a child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism. Typhoid vaccination may lead to a transient decrease in platelet count, which can exacerbate the existing hypersplenism and increase the risk of bleeding. Therefore, it is often deferred until after splenectomy when the risk of post-vaccination thrombocytopenia is reduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal vaccine: The pneumococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia (absence of the spleen) or hyposplenism (reduced spleen function) because they are at an increased risk of severe infections, including those caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the pneumococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenza B vaccine: The Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccine is recommended as part of routine childhood immunization and does not have specific contraindications related to hereditary spherocytosis or splenectomy.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: The meningococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia or hyposplenism, as they are at an increased risk of meningococcal infections. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the meningococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typhoid vaccine is often deferred in children with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism before splenectomy due to the risk of transiently reduced platelet count, which can be problematic in the presence of hypersplenism. Other vaccines, such as the pneumococcal, Haemophilus influenzae B, and meningococcal vaccines, may be administered based on routine immunization recommendations and the individual's spleen status.

questions.text: How is cerebral perfusion pressure calculated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mean arterial pressure - intracranial pressure


Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated as mean arterial pressure (MAP) - intracranial pressure (ICP).

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is the net pressure gradient that drives oxygen delivery to cerebral tissue. It is the difference between the mean arterial pressure (MAP) and the intracranial pressure (ICP), measured in millimeters of mercury (mm Hg). If ICP values are not readily available, central venous pressure (CVP) may be used.

 

Normal CPP lies between 60- and 80-mm Hg,

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated by subtracting the intracranial pressure (ICP) from the mean arterial pressure (MAP). This measurement is crucial for ensuring adequate blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain.

questions.text: Book test is for: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ulnar nerve

 

TESTS FOR ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  • Froment sign/book test: Hyperflexion of the thumb IP joint while attempting to pinch. This indicates a substitution of flexor pollicis longus (innervated by median nerve) for adductor pollicis (innervated by ulnar nerve).

 

 

  • Jeanne sign: Reciprocal hyperextension of the thumb MCP joint indicating substitution of flexor pollicis longus (FPL) for adductor pollicis.

 

 

  • Wartenburg sign: Abduction of the small finger at MCP joint indicating deficient palmar intrinsic muscle (innervated by ulnar nerve) with abduction from extensor digiti minimi (innervated by the radial nerve).

 

 

  • Duchenne sign: Clawing of the ring and small fingers, hyperextension of MCP joints, and flexion of PIP joints indicating deficient interosseous and lumbrical muscles of the ring and small fingers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve. Special tests for median nerve injury are:

 

  • Pen Test:
    • Test: Patient keeps his/her hand flat on the table and at the same time, examiner brings a pen above the thumb.
    • Interpretation: Patient tries to touch the pen by abduction the thumb and examiner feels the tendon of abductor pollicis brevis (APB) at the wrist. Patient fails to touch in APB paralysis and examiner will not be able to palpate the tendon.
    • Note: Median nerve invariably and exclusively supply APB.

 

 

  • Pointing Index Sign/Ochsner’s Clasping/Benediction Test:
    • Test: Patient clasps his both hand together.
    • Interpretation: The index finger fails to flex in median nerve injury and it points outward as pointing index.
    • Note: It occur in high median nerve palsy where flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus gets involved.

 

 

A. Pointing index; B. Benediction test

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. Depending on injury severity there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Option D. Radial nerve. Special tests for radial nerve palsy are:

 

  • Wrist drop test:
    • The patient is asked to extend wrist with the elbow flexed 90°.
    • In radial nerve palsy affecting the wrist extensors, the patient will be unable to extend the wrist. The hand will hang down in a deformity known as a “wrist drop“.

 

 

a. Normal; b. Wrist drop

 

  • In a second stage of the test, the patient is asked to abduct the thumb.
  • In radial nerve palsy, the patient will be unable to abduct the thumb because of the paralysis of the abductor pollicis longus muscle and, to a lesser extent, the extensor pollicis brevis muscle.

 

 

a. Thumb abduction; b. Paralysis

 

  • Thumb extension test:
    • The examiner grasps the patient’s wrist with one hand and presses the thumb into adduction with the other hand.
    • Then the patient is asked to extend or abduct both the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints of the thumb.
    • Where this nerve is damaged, thumb extension will be weakened or impossible as a result of paralysis of the extensor pollicis longus and brevis.

 

 

a. Starting position; b. Normal; c. Weak thumb extension

 

  • Supination test:
    • Supination Test evaluates compression neuropathy of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
    • The patient is seated, holding the elbow slightly flexed and the forearm pronated.
    • The elbow is held alongside the trunk to minimize motion in the shoulder.
    • The patient is then asked to supinate forearm, at first normally and then against the examiner’s resistance.
    • Weakness or loss of supination of the forearm is a sign of paresis of the supinator muscle, which is supplied by the deep branch of the radial nerve.

 

 

a. Starting position; b. Normal supination; c. Supination against resistance

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Book test is done for ulnar nerve palsy where there is hyperflexion of the thumb IP joint while attempting to pinch, indicating a substitution of flexor pollicis longus (innervated by median nerve) for adductor pollicis (innervated by ulnar nerve).

questions.text:
An HIV patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. Consider the following statements and identify the essential criteria for the diagnosis of neurocysticercosis. (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Brain biopsy showing the parasite.
  2. Muscle biopsy showing foci of calcification.
  3. MRI sequence as seen in A.
  4. MRI sequence as seen in B.

 

Image A

 

 

Image B
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4 only

 

The MRI brain labeled as B shows multiple cysticerci within the brain suggesting neurocysticercosis. Among the given statements, the essential criteria for the diagnosis of neurocysticercosis include 1 and 4 (option B), i.e.,

 

  • Brain biopsy showing the parasite.
  • Neuroradiologic demonstration of cystic lesions with scolex (MRI labeled B in this case).

 

Neurocysticercosis is a condition caused by the larvae of Taenia solium.

 

Criteria for diagnosis of neurocysticercosis:

 

1. Absolute criteria

  1. Demonstration of cysticerci by histologic or microscopic examination of a biopsy taken from the brain or spinal cord lesion.
  2. Visualization of the parasite in the eye by funduscopy.
  3. Neuroradiologic demonstration of cystic lesions containing a characteristic scolex.

 

2. Neuroimaging criteria

  • Major neuroimaging criteria: Cystic lesions without a discernible scolex, multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space, typical small enhancing lesions, typical parenchymal brain calcifications.
  • Confirmative neuroimaging criteria: Resolution of cystic lesions spontaneously or after cysticidal drug therapy and migration of ventricular cysts documented on sequential neuroimaging studies.
  • Minor neuroimaging criteria: Obstructive hydrocephalus or abnormal enhancement of basal leptomeninges.

 

3. Clinical/exposure criteria

  • Major clinical/exposure criteria: Demonstration of antibodies to cysticerci or cysticerci antigen in cerebrospinal fluid by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay; Household contact with an individual infected with T. solium; Evidence of cysticercosis outside the central nervous system (e.g., cigar-shaped soft-tissue calcifications).
  • Minor clinical/exposure criteria: Clinical manifestations suggestive of neurocysticercosis; Residence in a cysticercosis-endemic area; Frequent travel to a cysticercosis-endemic area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 and 2 only: While brain biopsy is crucial (1), muscle biopsy (2) is not an essential criterion for diagnosing neurocysticercosis. MRI or neuroimaging findings are more relevant.

 

Option C. 1, 3, and 4: MRI sequence A (3) is not relevant to the diagnosis of neurocysticercosis based on the images shown. MRI B (4) is the correct neuroimaging that supports the diagnosis.

 

Option D. 1, 2, and 4: Muscle biopsy (2) showing calcification is not part of the essential criteria, although it might provide supportive evidence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis diagnosis requires evidence from neuroimaging (e.g., cystic lesions with scolex) and/or histologic confirmation through biopsy.

questions.text: The significance of HMP shunt are all except? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Utilizes ribose

 

Explanation:

 

The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), has several significant roles:

 

Option A. Source of NADPH: The HMP shunt produces NADPH in its oxidative phase. NADPH is essential for various biosynthetic reactions, including fatty acid synthesis and maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in red blood cells.

 

Option B. Source of ribose 5 phosphate: At the end of the oxidative phase, ribulose 5-phosphate is produced, which can be further converted into ribose 5-phosphate. Ribose 5-phosphate is a crucial precursor for the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

Option C. Source of acetyl CoA: One of the end products of the HMP shunt is glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, which can enter glycolysis. Through glycolysis, it can eventually form pyruvate, which can be converted into acetyl CoA in the presence of oxygen.

 

Option D. Utilizes ribose: This statement is incorrect as the HMP shunt primarily produces ribose 5-phosphate rather than utilizing it. Ribose 5-phosphate is a significant product of this pathway and is used in the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

The overall reaction of the HMP shunt can be summarized as:

 

3G-6-P+6NADP+→2G-6-P+Glyceraldehyde-3-P+3CO2+6NADPH

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HMP shunt is significant for producing NADPH and ribose 5-phosphate and indirectly contributing to the formation of acetyl CoA, but it does not utilize ribose.

questions.text: What is the dose range of lithium in mEq/dL for acute attacks of mania and long-term maintenance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL

 

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window and its serum concentrations need careful monitoring.

 

0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL represents the general therapeutic range for lithium. According to 12th edition of Synopsis of Psychiatry,  for acute manic episodes, the target serum lithium level is between 1.0 to 1.2 mEq/dL, while for long-term maintenance, it is 0.4 to 0.8 mEq/dL. The option closes to this range is option C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.5 to 1 mEq/dL is close but not the typical therapeutic range. It is on the lower end and might not be effective for many patients, especially during acute mania.

 

Option B. 0.1 to 0.5 mEq/dL is subtherapeutic. Such low levels wouldn't be effective for the treatment of bipolar disorder and would not offer the necessary mood-stabilizing effects.

 

Option D. 2 to 3 mEq/dL is a toxic range. Lithium concentrations at this level can result in severe side effects and even life-threatening toxicity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 655

choices.text: MRI to rule out enlarged heart

questions.text: The parents notice that their child is tired and that he has shortness of breath on climbing stairs and while lying down. What is the first investigation that you would do? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest x-ray

 

The first investigation to be done for a child who feels shortness of breath on climbing stairs and in the supine position is a chest x-ray.

 

The child having shortness of breath on dyspnea on exertion worsened in the supine position is orthopnea could be suggestive of congestive heart failure.

 

Causes -

 

  1. Respiratory causes include asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD), pneumonia, and pulmonary embolism.
  2. Cardiovascular causes include congestive heart failure (CH), pulmonary edema, valvular heart defect, and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Evaluation

 

  • Oxygen saturation at rest and during physical activity
  • Chest x-ray is the first diagnostic test as pulmonary pathology or pulmonary edema and signs of CHF may be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: An echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac cause if the chest X-ray is abnormal

 

Option C: Spirometry to assess lung function when the chest x-ray is normal.

 

Option D: Cardiac MRI (Magnetic resonance imaging) is an emerging modality done to look for cardiomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with shortness of breath on exertion and orthopnea, the first investigation should be a chest x-ray to evaluate potential pulmonary pathology and signs of congestive heart failure.

choices.text: ACL and medial collateral ligament injury
Lateral collateral ligament injury
Medial meniscus injury

questions.text: The injury shown in the radiograph can result in: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ACL injury

 

SEGOND FRACTURE

 

  • Segond fracture is an avulsion fracture of the knee that involves the lateral aspect of the tibial plateau and is very frequently (»75% of cases) associated with disruption of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).
  • On the frontal knee radiograph, it may appear as a curvilinear or elliptic bone fragment projected parallel to the lateral aspect of the tibial plateau, referred to as the lateral capsular sign.

 

 

  • Contrary to the more common causes of an ACL tear, which typically involves valgus stress, a Segond fracture usually occurs as a result of internal rotation and varus stress.
  • Treatment:
  • Although the fracture itself is small, the extensive ligamentous injury associated with it usually requires surgical intervention.
  • Spontaneous healing of the Segond fracture may occur following ACL reconstruction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows Segond fracture, which is frequently seen with ACL injuries.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy. She came to the hospital after one week with acute pain in the abdomen with features suggestive of perforation. An X-ray showed the following picture. Identify the type of offense for which the surgeon can be held responsible? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Res ipsa loquitur

 

  • The X-ray indicates surgical scissors accidentally left behind during surgery.
  • The surgeon can be held guilty for Res ipsa loquitur.
  • "Res ipsa loquitur" means "the thing or fact speaks for itself."
  • The negligent act by the doctor is obvious from the Xray and the patient need not prove the negligence.
  • Conditions to be fulfilled to prove negligence:
  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • There was no contributory negligence from the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Novus actus interveniens: Refers to a new intervening act that breaks the chain of causation. It is not applicable here as the negligence was directly related to the surgery.

 

Option C. Res judicata: Refers to a matter that has been adjudicated by a competent court and therefore cannot be pursued further by the same parties. It is not relevant to the context of proving negligence.

 

Option D. Vicarious liability: Refers to the liability of one party for the actions of another, typically an employer for an employee. This does not directly apply to the surgeon's individual negligence in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of surgical instruments left inside a patient post-operation is a clear case of negligence, aptly described by the legal principle of "Res ipsa loquitur," meaning the fact speaks for itself.

questions.text: Match the following cells with their locations: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d  

 

The correct matches for the cells and their respective locations are as follows:

 

  1. Kupffer cells (b) Liver: Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages located in the liver, involved in the breakdown of red blood cells and the immune response within the liver.
  2. Parietal cells (a) Stomach: Parietal cells are found in the lining of the stomach and are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid (HCl), which aids in digestion.
  3. Dust cells (c) Alveoli: Dust cells, also known as alveolar macrophages, are found in the alveoli of the lungs. They play a crucial role in removing inhaled particles and pathogens from the alveolar spaces.
  4. Clara cells (d) Bronchioles: Clara cells, now more commonly referred to as club cells, are found in the bronchioles of the lungs. They secrete surfactant proteins and detoxify harmful substances inhaled into the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Carbon monoxide poisoning

questions.text: Identify the left curve, given the fact that the right curve is of adult hemoglobin.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

Explanation

 

  • The left curve is for myoglobin as it is a rectangular hyperbola curve which is characteristic of Michaelis Menton kinetics.
  • Fetal hemoglobin, CO poisoning and acidosis will shift the sigmoidal shape of hemoglobin saturation curve as shown in the image below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal hemoglobin: Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin, which shifts the curve to the left. However, the curve still maintains a sigmoidal shape.

 

Option C. Carbon monoxide poisoning: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin with a much higher affinity than oxygen, shifting the hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left and making it more difficult for oxygen to be released to tissues. This also retains the sigmoidal shape.

 

Option D. Acidosis: Acidosis generally causes a rightward shift of the hemoglobin oxygen dissociation curve, reducing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. This is the opposite of what is observed with myoglobin.

The left shift observed in the myoglobin curve reflects its high affinity for oxygen, distinguishing it from the sigmoidal curves seen in hemoglobin variations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myoglobin has a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve due to its single polypeptide chain and high oxygen affinity, contrasting with the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin due to its cooperative binding.

choices.text: Beta oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
Omega oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is caused by the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid

 

Refsum's disease is a peroxisomal disorder caused by the impaired alpha-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, which results in the buildup of phytanic acid in the body. This accumulation of phytanic acid is a characteristic feature of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid: Refsum's disease is not caused by the defect in beta oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. Beta oxidation is a different metabolic process.

 

Option C. Omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid: Refsum's disease is not caused by the defect in omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. Omega oxidation is a different metabolic pathway.

 

Option D. Alpha oxidation of dicarboxylic acids: Refsum's disease primarily involves the defect in the alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, not the alpha oxidation of dicarboxylic acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:

 

  • No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways
  • H2O2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase.
  • Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:

1. α-Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids (BCFA)

2. Oxidation of Very Long Chain Fatty Acid (VLCFA)

 

Refsum's disease: Occur due to defect in α-oxidation of BCFA in peroxisomes due to defect in phytanic acid hydroxylase. So, Phytanic acid not oxidised.

  • Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid
  • In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following increase the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Age < 1 year
  2. Temperature of 38-39°C
  3. Duration of fever < 24 h
  4. Duration of fever > 48 h
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children who are less than 1 year old, have a fever with a temperature between 38-39°C, and have a fever duration of less than 24 hours. Febrile seizures typically occur in children between the ages of 6 and 60 months and are generalized tonic-clonic seizures that occur in the setting of fever without any underlying intracranial infection or a previous history of unprovoked seizures.

 

Risk Factors:

 

1. Age < 1 year: Younger age increases the likelihood of recurrent febrile seizures.

 

2. Temperature of 38-39°C: Lower fever temperatures (38-39°C) are associated with a higher risk of recurrence.

 

3. Duration of fever < 24 h: A shorter duration of fever before the onset of seizures is associated with an increased risk of recurrence.

 

Other Information:

 

  • Minor risk factors for recurrence include male gender, attending daycare, having complex febrile seizures, a family history of febrile seizures, and lower serum sodium levels at presentation.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Duration of fever > 48 hours: A duration of fever greater than 48 hours is not considered a risk factor for febrile seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children under 1 year of age, with fever temperatures between 38-39°C, and fever lasting less than 24 hours.

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever and nuchal rigidity. The resident was instructed to perform a lumbar puncture on this patient. What is the correct order of managing this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h
  2. Start injection ceftriaxone
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis
  4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

 

When managing a patient with fever and nuchal rigidity (suggesting possible meningitis), the correct order of steps is:

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h: Establishing IV access is the first priority to ensure hydration and create a route for medication administration.
  2. 4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture: The lumbar puncture should be performed early to collect CSF samples before antimicrobial therapy alters the CSF findings.
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis: Once the CSF is collected, it must be promptly sent for laboratory analysis to identify potential pathogens and guide targeted therapy.
  4. Start injection ceftriaxone: After CSF collection, empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone should be initiated. This ensures that treatment doesn't interfere with CSF culture results while still providing timely antimicrobial coverage.

 

This sequence prioritizes obtaining diagnostic samples before starting antimicrobial therapy, which is critical for accurate diagnosis while not unduly delaying treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected meningitis, the ideal sequence is to secure samples for microbiological diagnosis before starting antibiotics, when clinically feasible. However, if there will be a significant delay in performing the lumbar puncture or if the patient is critically ill, antibiotics should not be delayed. The sequence emphasizes balancing the need for accurate diagnosis with timely intervention.

choices.text: It is a dematiaceous fungus
Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle or joints
Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia
These bodies are formed by engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages

questions.text: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm, which initially started as macules but then became nodules. Histology of the nodules shows the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a dematiaceous fungus

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis (CBM) is defined as a chronic cutaneous and subcutaneous fungal infection resulting from traumatic implantation of certain dematiaceous fungi through the skin.
  • The most frequent aetiological agents of CBM are the following species: Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa and Cladophialophora carrionii.
  • The aetiological agents gain entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds, usually by parts of plants.
  • In a typical manifestation the dermal lesions form cauliflower-like nodules. In the infected tissue, characteristic dark-colored, thick-walled, muriform cells i.e. sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) are observed, which is a histopathological criterion for the diagnosis.
  • The aetiological agent (i.e. fungal fragment) gains entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. Cases of buttock, trunk and face infection have also been reported. In more advanced stages of the disease dissemination may occur in the form of satellite lesions which arise from scratching autoinoculation and spread via the lymphatic system.
  • Treatment – Antifungal therapy with itraconazole or terbinafine. Surgical excision is the therapy of choice for small lesions.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle, or joints: This statement is more characteristic of eumycetoma, not chromoblastomycosis. Eumycetoma, caused by various fungal species, can invade deeper tissues including bone, leading to severe deformities.

 

Option C. Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia: Angioinvasion is typically seen in infections caused by Aspergillus species, which can lead to invasive aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. This is not a feature of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. These bodies are formed by the engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages: The bodies seen in the histological image (Medlar bodies) are not formed by macrophage engulfment. They are a morphological form of the fungi present in the infected tissue, indicative of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection characterized by the presence of dark-coloured, thick-walled sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) in histological sections, resulting from traumatic implantation of dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Needle thoracocentesis

 

Patient with stab to chest with reduced chest movement on right, mediastinal shift to left with distended neck veins is suffering from tension pneumothorax. Next step is placement of wide bore needle in triangle of safety to decompress the pneumothorax, followed by ICD insertion.

 

This is the correct answer. Needle thoracocentesis is the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. It is a procedure that involves inserting a needle into the pleural space to aspirate the air or fluid. It is performed initially to decompress the tension pneumothorax in the triangle of safety (between Pect. Major anteriorly, Latissimus dorsi posteriorly, 5th intercostal space inferiorly).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency room thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Resuscitative thoracotomy is an emergency surgical procedure that is performed in the presence of cardiac arrest due to penetrating chest trauma.

 

Option B. ICD placement: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. An ICD (intercostal drainage) is a tube inserted into the pleural space to drain the air or fluid. ICD placement is the definitive management of tension pneumothorax but is not the next step in the management.

 

Option D. Finger thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Finger thoracotomy is an alternative approach when needle decompression fails or is not possible. It involves making a small incision in the chest wall and using the finger to manually decompress the pneumothorax. However, needle decompression should be attempted first before considering finger thoracostomy.

questions.text: Which alternative method can be used for the procedure shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arm span

 

The image shows the measurement of a child's height using a stadiometer. The alternative method that can be used for measuring height is arm span. The arm span is a measurement from the tip of one middle finger to the tip of the other middle finger when the arms are outstretched horizontally. This measurement is typically close to the child's height and can be used as an alternative method, especially in cases where the child is unable to stand properly.

 

The proportion of arm span to height changes with age but is generally close to the height measurement. In clinical practice, when direct measurement of height is not feasible, arm span can be a reliable surrogate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head circumference: Head circumference is measured using a measuring tape and is an important metric in assessing brain growth and development, especially in infants and young children, but it is not an alternative for height measurement.

 

Option C. Crown-rump length: Crown-rump length is a measurement used during an ultrasound in early pregnancy to estimate the gestational age of the fetus, not a method for height measurement in children.

 

Option D. Knee height: Knee height is not typically used for measuring height in children and is more often used in adults, particularly the elderly, to estimate height when they are unable to stand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arm span can be used as an alternative method for measuring height, especially when direct height measurement is not feasible.

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Ehrlichia chaffeensis

questions.text: Image of Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is shown below. Identify the organism? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ehrlichia chaffeensis

 

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is an obligate intracellular, Gram-negative species of Rickettsiales bacteria. It is a zoonotic pathogen transmitted to humans by the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum) and is the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME).

 

Ehrlichiosis is evidenced by the presence of intracytoplasmic inclusions known as morulae in monocytes, which can be observed on a Giemsa-stained blood film.

 

Characteristics and Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Transmission: By the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum).
  • Symptoms: Patients typically exhibit symptoms within 1 to 2 weeks after tick infection. Early symptoms include fever, headache, malaise, low-back pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Some patients may also have myalgias, arthralgias, coughing, pharyngitis, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and changes in mental status.
  • Diagnosis: Besides observing morulae in monocytes, serological tests like indirect fluorescent antibody tests and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are also used for diagnosis.
  • Treatment: TOC Doxycycline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: Incorrect. Rickettsia rickettsii is the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), typically associated with rash and vascular endothelial damage, not morulae in monocytes.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: Incorrect. Rickettsia conorii causes Mediterranean spotted fever, which also does not present with morulae in monocytes.

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Incorrect. Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA), where morulae are found in granulocytes, not monocytes. The presence of morulae in granulocytes is characteristic of Anaplasma infection.

 

Educational objective:

 

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is identified by the presence of morulae in monocytes and is the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis. The proper treatment is doxycycline, and diagnosis is confirmed through blood smear, serological tests, and PCR.

 

GAME – Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis

questions.text: The image below shows strangulation by Spanish windlass method. What type of strangulation method does it belong to? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Garroting

 

Spanish windlass

 

Method: It involves tightening an iron collar (Spanish windlass) around the neck and forcing a spike against the neck into the spinal cord.

 

Garroting- It involves attacking the victim by throwing the ligature from behind over the victim's neck and then tightened by twisting with a lever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bansdola: A method of strangulation where a ligature is applied in a different manner, often using a stick or rod to twist and tighten the ligature.

 

Option C. Mugging: Refers to a method where the assailant uses their limbs, such as the crook of their elbow, to compress the neck.

 

Option D. Throttling: Throttling involves using hands to manually compress the neck, leading to asphyxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Spanish windlass method of strangulation, shown in the image, belongs to the category of garroting, which involves the use of a ligature tightened by a lever or similar mechanism.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes develops a UTI, which gets complicated with hypotension that is resistant to IV fluids. Which of the following antibiotics can be used? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Piperacillin-Tazobactam

 

The patient with diabetes has developed a urinary tract infection (UTI) complicated by hypotension resistant to IV fluids, indicating septic shock. In cases of septic shock, it is critical to start with empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics. These antibiotics are designed to cover a wide range of potential pathogens until the specific causative organism can be identified and targeted.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics suitable for such severe infections include:

 

  • Piperacillin-Tazobactam
  • Carbapenems like Meropenem or Imipenem
  • Certain third-generation cephalosporins like Ceftazidime

 

In this case, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is chosen because it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers many of the common pathogens responsible for severe infections and septic shock. Although a combination of Meropenem with Vancomycin would be ideal, the given options do not include Meropenem. Therefore, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is the best choice among the provided options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate: This antibiotic is generally not sufficient for treating severe infections or septic shock due to its narrower spectrum of activity compared to Piperacillin-Tazobactam.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: While Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, it is not as broad-spectrum as Ceftazidime and does not provide the same coverage needed for septic shock.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: This antibiotic is typically used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections and is not effective for severe systemic infections or septic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of septic shock, especially in a patient with diabetes and complicated UTI, broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Piperacillin-Tazobactam are critical for empirical therapy.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma
Small cell cancer lung
Large cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented in OPD with hemoptysis. On examination, a hilar mass was noticed. The histopathological image is shown below. Immunohistochemistry revealed that the cells were positive for p40. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous cell carcinoma

 

The given clinical history and the histopathological findings showing keratin pearls are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

 

Tumor arises in a large bronchus and are prone to massive necrosis and cavitation.

 

The tumor is diagnosed microscopically by identification of either intercellular bridges or keratinization or keratin/squamous pearls.

 

It is positive for p40 and p63 markers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma lung: Generally occurs in the peripheral regions of the lung and is often associated with mutations like KRAS, EGFR, or ALK. Immunohistochemical markers like TTF-1 and Napsin-A would be positive, not p40.

 

Option C. Small cell cancer lung: This type is strongly associated with smoking and typically occurs centrally. However, it is identified by markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56, not p40.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma: This is a diagnosis of exclusion, where the tumor lacks the histological characteristics of other types of lung cancers. It is not associated with p40 positivity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked.

 

The 1st lumbrical muscle is innervated by the median nerve. It is a small, quadrilateral muscle located in the hand that arises from the tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index finger and inserts into the extensor expansion of the index finger. Its main function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger and extend the interphalangeal joints of the index finger. The 1st lumbrical muscle is named because it is associated with the first (index) finger, and there are a total of four lumbrical muscles in the hand - one for each of the four fingers (excluding the thumb).

 

The first and second lumbrical nerves are innervated by the median nerve. The third and fourth lumbricals are innervated by the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand, including the wrist and finger extensors. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.

 

Option C. Ulnar Nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies several intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbrical muscles. However, the first lumbrical is typically innervated by the median nerve, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous Nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve primarily innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 1st lumbrical muscle of the hand is innervated by the median nerve is crucial for clinical assessments of hand function, especially in cases of nerve injury or compression syndromes like carpal tunnel syndrome, where the median nerve's functionality can be compromised.

questions.text: Which of the following option is a common size of a Foley catheter used in female patients and patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14 Fr

 

14 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 14 Fr are commonly used in adult female patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6 Fr: 6 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 6 Fr are commonly used in pediatric patients or in adults with narrow urethras. They are also used in urodynamic studies to measure bladder pressures.

 

Option C. 16 Fr: 16 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 16 Fr are commonly used in adult male patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Option D. 22 Fr: 22 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 22 Fr are commonly used in patients for suprapubic cystostomy. They are also used in patients who have undergone prostate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FOLEY’S CATHETER

 

The size in French (12F, 14F, 16F etc.) represents the outer diameter. 1 F = 1/3rd mm.

choices.text: 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts

questions.text: Which of the following patients would be classified as having primary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts

 

  • Primary amenorrhea is defined as:
    • No menstruation by age 13 in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics.
    • No menstruation by age 15 in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.
  • In this context:
    • Option A: An 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts would not be classified as having primary amenorrhea since she is not yet 13.
    • Option B: A 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts meets the criteria for primary amenorrhea because she is older than 13 and has no secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner stage 1 breasts).
    • Option C: A 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.
    • Option D: A 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts: The girl is too young to be classified as having primary amenorrhea.

 

Option C. 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Option D. 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by age 13 without secondary sexual characteristics or by age 15 with secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Ref: ACOG Committee opinion menstruation in girls and adolescents (2015), Speroff’s gynecologic endocrinology 7th edition pg401, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 450

choices.text: If the hands are visibly soiled
While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care

questions.text: A healthcare worker is performing patient care in a hospital setting. Which of the following is not a correct situation for using hand rub according to standard hand hygiene protocol? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) If the hands are visibly soiled

 

Hand rub, typically alcohol-based hand sanitizer, is not effective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with dirt, blood, or other body fluids. In such cases, healthcare workers should wash their hands with soap and water to physically remove the visible contaminants before using hand rub. This is a crucial step to ensure proper hand hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub when transitioning from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. This helps prevent the spread of pathogens and maintain aseptic conditions. It's an essential practice in infection control

 

Option C. Before donning on gloves: Correct. Hand hygiene, including the use of hand rub, is recommended before putting on gloves. This step ensures that any potential contaminants on the hands are removed before glove use, reducing the risk of contamination during procedures .

 

Option D. During direct patient contact: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub before and after direct patient contact to reduce the risk of transmitting pathogens to or from the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hand hygiene is essential for infection prevention in healthcare settings. Alcohol-based hand rubs are preferred in most cases, but soap and water should be used for visibly soiled hands and in cases of outbreaks of certain pathogens like Clostridium difficile. Hand hygiene should be performed before and after every direct patient contact, before donning gloves, and after removing gloves. Additionally, hand hygiene should be performed while moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. It is important to note that using hand rub is not appropriate if the hands are visibly soiled, as the rub cannot effectively remove dirt and debris from the hands. In such cases, soap and water handwashing is recommended.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient weighing 60 kg is on mechanical ventilation for ARDS secondary to urosepsis. The respiratory parameters are as follows: tidal volume- 360 mL; frequency- 30 breaths/min; PEEP- 5 cm of H2O; and FiO2- 90%. The arterial blood gas findings are as follows: paO2- 50 mmHg; paCO2- 38 mmHg and pH- 7.38. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase PEEP

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) requires careful management of mechanical ventilation settings to optimize oxygenation while minimizing lung injury. The patient's current settings and blood gas findings suggest hypoxemia (paO2 of 50 mmHg) with an FiO2 of 90%. The goal in managing ARDS is to maintain adequate oxygenation (paO2 > 60 mmHg) while reducing the FiO2 to less than 60% to avoid oxygen toxicity.

 

Increasing PEEP is the best option to improve oxygenation. PEEP helps to keep alveoli open, improving gas exchange and oxygenation. By increasing PEEP, we can potentially increase the paO2 and eventually reduce the FiO2 to safer levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduce FiO2: Although reducing FiO2 is a long-term goal to prevent oxygen toxicity, it is not advisable to reduce it immediately because the patient is currently hypoxemic (paO2 of 50 mmHg).

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Not appropriate as it can increase the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury in ARDS patients. The current tidal volume is within the safe range (360 mL), which is appropriate for a 60 kg patient as it falls within the recommended range of 4-6 mL/kg for ARDS patients to prevent ventilator-induced lung injury.

 

Option C. Increase respiratory rate: Increasing the respiratory rate is not necessary in this situation as the paCO2 (38 mmHg) and pH (7.38) indicate normal ventilation and no significant respiratory acidosis (paCO2 is normal).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS management, if the patient remains hypoxemic despite a high FiO2, the next step is to increase the PEEP to improve oxygenation while maintaining lung-protective ventilation strategies.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers

questions.text: Urinary alkalinization will be most useful in toxicity of which of the following drugs? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin
 

Urinary alkalinization is a key treatment in aspirin toxicity. Aspirin (salicylate) is a weak acid, and alkalinizing the urine increases the ionization of salicylates. This ionization traps salicylates in the urine, preventing their reabsorption and enhancing their elimination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: Urinary alkalinization is not a standard treatment for beta blocker toxicity. Management of beta blocker overdose typically involves supportive care and, in severe cases, specific antidotes like glucagon or high-dose insulin.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Similar to beta blockers, urinary alkalinization is not a primary treatment for calcium channel blocker overdose. Treatment often includes calcium infusions, glucagon, and other supportive measures.

 

Option C. Acetaminophen: For acetaminophen toxicity, the antidote N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is used. Urinary alkalinization is not effective for acetaminophen overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary alkalinization is most useful in the treatment of aspirin (salicylate) toxicity because it increases the elimination of salicylates by trapping them in the urine through ionization. This method is not effective for beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, or acetaminophen toxicity.

choices.text: Amniotic fluid volume
Daily fetal movement count

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of biophysical profile? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Daily fetal movement count

 

Explanation:

 

Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not a component of the BPP. DFMC, often assessed using Cardiff’s count of 10, is a separate method for monitoring fetal movements.

 

  • The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a comprehensive test used in the assessment of fetal wellbeing. It includes five components, which are scored using the Manning score:
    1. Non-stress test (NST)
    2. Amniotic fluid volume (AFV)
    3. Fetal movements
    4. Fetal tone
    5. Fetal breathing movements
  • A low Manning score is indicative of fetal hypoxia and may necessitate further clinical intervention.
  • Additionally, the Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes only two components:
    1. Non-stress test (NST)
    2. Amniotic fluid index (AFI)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid volume: Amniotic fluid volume is a component of the BPP and helps assess the amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.

 

Option B. Fetal tone: Fetal tone is another component of the BPP, assessing the baby's muscle tone.

 

Option D. Non-stress test: Non-stress test (NST) is part of the BPP and evaluates the fetal heart rate in response to fetal movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) consists of five components: NST, AFV, fetal movements, fetal tone, and fetal breathing movements. Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not part of the BPP.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 342, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 122

questions.text: Eonism can be defined as? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wearing clothes of opposite sex

 

  • Eonism /Transvestism involves wearing clothes of the opposite sex to derive pleasure.
  • Eonism is named for Charles Eon de Beaumont, a French political adventurer who died in 1810 after posing as a woman for many years.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Public display of genitalia – Exhibitionism, where an individual derives pleasure from exposing their genitals to others in public.

 

Option C. Seeing a male undressing: This can be a form of voyeurism, though it is not specifically defined as such. Voyeurism typically involves deriving pleasure from secretly observing others who are undressing or engaging in sexual activities.

 

Option D. Seeing a female undressing- Voyeurism, where an individual derives pleasure from observing females undressing.

 

Educational Objective

 

Eonism or transvestism is the act of wearing clothes of the opposite sex for pleasure, named after Charles Eon de Beaumont.

questions.text: How would you describe the tonicity of the fluid leaving the proximal convoluted tubule in the absence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isotonic

 

Fluid leaving the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT in the absence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is isotonic.

 

Normally, about 65 per cent of the filtered load of sodium and water and a slightly lower percentage of filtered chloride are reabsorbed by the proximal tubule before the filtrate reaches the loops of Henle. The PCT is the site of maximum water reabsorption under normal physiological conditions. Isosmotic reabsorption occurs in the PCT, so the amount of solute and water reabsorbed are coupled and proportional to each other. Water reabsorption in the PCT also occurs through aquaporin-1 which are active water channels. Reabsorption of sodium and water in PCT is not affected by ADH levels.

 

Thus, even in the absence of ADH, fluid is isotonic in PCT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypotonic: This is incorrect because the fluid in the PCT remains isotonic due to the proportional reabsorption of solutes and water.

 

Option C. Hypertonic: This is incorrect because the reabsorption process in the PCT maintains the isotonic nature of the fluid.

 

Option D. Depends on fluid intake: This is incorrect because the tonicity of the fluid in the PCT does not depend on fluid intake but on the intrinsic reabsorption processes that maintain isotonic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluid leaving the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) is isotonic due to the isosmotic reabsorption of solutes and water, regardless of the presence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). This ensures that the fluid entering the loop of Henle has the same osmolarity as plasma.

choices.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated
10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is keenly interested in understanding the relationship between lung cancer and smoking habits. After conducting an extensive study and analyzing his data, he finds that the attributable risk is 90%. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this result? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

 

  • In the given scenario, the attributable risk of cigarette smoking to lung cancer is 90%; hence, 90% cases of lung cancer are due to smoking as a risk factor
  • The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk.
  • Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure
  • Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

questions.text: Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by which of the following proteins: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Divalent metal transporter – 1

 

Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by divalent metal transporter-1 protein.

Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Iron is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases and then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transferrin: This protein binds iron in the bloodstream and transports it to various tissues, but it is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Ferroportin: This protein exports iron from enterocytes into the bloodstream but does not transport iron into the cells.

 

Option C. Hepcidin: This hormone regulates iron egress from enterocytes by inhibiting ferroportin but is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary transporter responsible for iron uptake into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen is the divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT1).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding memantine? (INICET NOV 2022)
 

1. Its therapeutic effect is due to its antagonistic action on NMDA receptors.
 

2. It is reserved for moderate-to-severe cases of Alzheimer’s disease.
 

3. It is used only as a monotherapy and should not be used with cholinesterase inhibitors.
 

4. It is given at a daily dose of 20-30 mg/day.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2

 

1. Its therapeutic effect is due to its antagonistic action on NMDA receptors: True. Memantine is an NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor antagonist. It works by blocking the action of glutamate at the NMDA receptors, which is thought to play a role in the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease.

 

2. It is reserved for moderate-to-severe cases of Alzheimer’s disease: True. Memantine is typically used in the treatment of moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It is not commonly used in the early stages of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

3. It is used only as a monotherapy and should not be used with cholinesterase inhibitors: False. Memantine can be used alone (as monotherapy) or in combination with cholinesterase inhibitors, such as donepezil, rivastigmine, or galantamine, in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

 

4. It is given at a daily dose of 20-30 mg/day: False. Memantine is started at a lower dose of 5 mg daily and is titrated up to a target dose, which is usually 20 mg/day. Therefore, it is more precise to say that the standard dose is up to 20 mg/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist used for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It can be used alone or in combination with cholinesterase inhibitors, and the standard maximum dose is 20 mg/day.

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deep perineal pouch

 

Option B. Deep perineal pouch: This is a space situated superior to the perineal membrane and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It contains the membranous urethra, deep transverse perineal muscles, and parts of the external urethral sphincter. Extravasation of urine is possible in deep perineal pouch.

 

When there is a rupture of the penile urethra (often due to trauma, such as a straddle injury), the extravasation of urine and blood can occur into various anatomical spaces, depending on the location and nature of the injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial perineal pouch: This is a space located in the urogenital triangle of the perineum, bounded above by the perineal membrane and below by the perineal (Colles') fascia. The pouch contains the root of the penis (including the bulb of the penis) and the associated muscles. A rupture of the penile urethra can cause extravasation of urine and blood into this space.
