Option C. Skin around penis. The skin around base of penis may get involved if the rupture is located in the bulbous part of urethra.

 

Option D. Skin around the scrotum: With a rupture of the penile urethra, especially if the rupture occurs in the bulbous part located within the superficial perineal pouch, the extravasated urine and blood can dissect through the fascial layers and present as swelling and bruising around the scrotum and base of the penis. This is often referred to as a "butterfly" pattern of bruising, as the extravasated fluid can spread anteriorly onto the anterior abdominal wall and laterally to the thighs but is typically limited superiorly by Scarpa's fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

questions.text: Patient had difficulty in walking upstairs. When he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the left-sided pelvis dropped down, but when he was standing on the left lower limb, the right-sided pelvis moved up. Which of the following is the likely lesion? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

 

WADDLING (GLUTEAL OR TRENDELENBURG) GAIT

 

  • This gait is characteristic of the gluteal muscle weakness that is seen in the progressive muscular dystrophies, but it occurs as well in chronic forms of spinal muscular atrophy, in certain inflammatory myopathies, lumbosacral nerve root compression, and with congenital dislocation of the hips.
  • It can also occur in neurogenic conditions in which the superior gluteal nerve is involved.
  • In normal walking, as weight is placed alternately on each leg, the hip is fixated by the gluteal muscles, particularly the gluteus medius, allowing for a slight rise of the opposite hip and tilt of the trunk to the weight-bearing side.
  • With weakness of the glutei, however, there is a failure to stabilize the weight-bearing hip, causing it to bulge outward and the opposite side of the pelvis to drop, with inclination of the trunk to that side.
  • The alternation in lateral trunk movements results in the roll or waddle.
  • With unilateral gluteal weakness, often the result of damage to the first sacral nerve root, tilting and dropping of the pelvis (“pelvic ptosis”) is apparent on only one side as the patient overlifts the leg when walking.
  • In several of the muscular dystrophies, an accentuation of lumbar lordosis is often seen.
  • Also, childhood cases may be complicated by muscular contractures, leading to an equinovarus position of the foot, so that the waddle is combined with walking on the toes (“toe walking”).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left superior gluteal nerve palsy. When the patient is standing on one leg, the opposite pelvis should be lifted upwards by abduction of the ipsilateral hip joint, in a normal patient. When the abductors are weak due to superior gluteal nerve paresis, the pelvis will sag, called positive Trendelenburg sign. In a patient with a positive Trendelenburg sign, the pelvis sags toward the normal unsupported side, which is the swing leg. When the left superior gluteal nerve is affected, on standing on the left lower limb, the right side pelvis will drop and when the patient stands on the right leg, the left side pelvis will be lifted up.

 

Option C. Right inferior gluteal nerve palsy. The inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle. It is therefore, responsible for extending the trunk from a forward bending position and extending the hip from sitting-to-standing or during stair-climbing or rising from a squatted position. The nerve does not confer any sensation. Injury to this nerve is most commonly iatrogenic in origin and is the most at risk nerve during total hip arthroplasty via a posterior approach. Injury typically leads to an altered gait pattern known as gluteus maximus ‘lurch’. The sequelae of nerve injury are denervation of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle. The lurching gait results from the weakening or absence of an ipsilateral hip extension. Clinically, patients may also report wasting of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle and loss of the defined shape to the affected buttock. In a normal gait cycle, the gluteus maximus begin to contract at the moment of the ipsilateral heel-strike to initiate ipsilateral hip extension. In inferior gluteal nerve injury, the trunk will extend when the heel strikes on the ground on the affected side to compensate for weak/absent hip extension. This backward trunk lurch is present in the whole stance phase of the gait cycle and locks the hip in extension. In some cases, the hamstrings muscle compensates to an extent. Therefore, in the right inferior gluteal nerve palsy, the right side hip will not extend during the initial heel strike and the trunk will lean backwards/extend.

 

Option D. Left inferior gluteal nerve palsy. In the injury of left sided gluteal nerve, the left hip will not extend during the initial heel strike, leading to backward lurch or extension of the trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On standing on the right lower limb, the left side pelvis drops and while standing on the left leg, the right side pelvis lifted up. This is indicative of right superior gluteal nerve palsy. This sign is called Trendelenburg Sign.

questions.text: Based on the depiction in the accompanying image, which model of disease causation is being illustrated? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sufficient component cause model 

 

  • The model of disease causation depicted is a sufficient component cause model.
  • It was developed by Rothman based on the idea that an outcome can only happen when a sufficient cause is present.
  • A disease can have multiple sufficient causes. But each sufficient cause can consist of a pie chart of component causes, a causal pie.
  • One component cause can be a part of more than one sufficient cause.
  • A component cause can be considered necessary if it is a part of a disease's sufficient causes.
  • In the given model, each pie chart represents a sufficient cause made of component causes.
  • Since B is present in all the charts, it can be considered a necessary cause. All the others are contributing causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epidemiological triad: An epidemiological triad depicts the interrelationship between the causative agent, the host, and the environment. All of them contribute to disease development. The aim of an epidemiological triad is to identify how to break this relationship and prevent the outbreak of the disease.

 

Option C. PERT model: PERT is used for network analysis. It is a type of quantitative management technique that helps in detailed planning and comprehensive supervision.

 

 

Option D. Web of causation model: The web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited to study chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sufficient component cause model illustrates how multiple factors contribute to disease causation, with some factors being necessary components in multiple causal pathways.

questions.text: What is the volume of the prostate in normal adult males? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20cc

 

Explanation:

 

The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.

 

The volume of the prostate gland in normal adult males can vary depending on age and other factors. However, on average, the volume of the prostate gland in an adult male is around 20-30 cubic centimeters (cc) or milliliters (mL).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical volume of the prostate in a normal adult male is around 20cc

questions.text: The image given below is a type of _______. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contusion

 

The type of injury shown in the image is a contusion.

 

A contusion is characterized by the infiltration of extravasated blood into the subcutaneous and/or subepithelial tissues. It results from the rupture of small blood vessels due to the application of blunt force.

 

  • A pure bruise lies beneath an intact epidermis.
  • Bruises are caused by damage to veins, venules, and small arteries.
  • The usual bruise from a blunt impact is situated in the subcutaneous tissues, often in the fat layer. (Fat individuals tend to bruise more easily than thin individuals due to the greater volume of soft subcutaneous tissue.)
  • Delayed bruising is a common phenomenon, where a bruise may become more prominent after hours or days due to continued bleeding from ruptured vessels, with blood percolating from deeper tissues toward the epidermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abrasion: Abrasion, also known as gravel rash, is the destruction of the superficial layers of the epidermis, usually due to friction against a rough surface. Abrasions can be classified into scratches, grazes, pressure abrasions, or impact abrasions.

 

Option C. Laceration: Laceration refers to a tear or split of the skin, mucous membranes, or muscles caused by blunt force trauma. The shape and depth of a laceration can help determine the cause of the injury.

 

Option D. Stab wound: A stab wound is caused by a sharp object (e.g., knife or scissors), producing a wound that is deeper than it is wide with clean, inverted edges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contusions are caused by blunt force trauma, leading to subcutaneous bleeding (bruising) without breaking the skin. The delayed appearance of bruises is common, and their progression provides clues to the timing and severity of the injury.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Inj. Amphotericin B for 4-8 weeks, followed by oral itraconazole
﻿﻿﻿Inj. Amphotericin B for 8 weeks, followed by oral posaconazole
﻿﻿﻿Inj. Fluconazole, followed by oral fluconazole
﻿﻿﻿Inj. Amphotericin B, followed by flucytosine

questions.text: A patient presented with periorbital pain and nasal discharge. On examination, the findings shown in the image below. She is an immunocompromised patient currently on HAART. Which of the following antifungal regimen should be prescribed to this patient along with HAART? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inj. Amphotericin B for 8 weeks, followed by oral posaconazole

 

An immunocompromised patient presenting with peri-orbital swelling and black necrosed lesion is suggestive of mucormycosis, an opportunistic fungal infection.

 

  • Amphotericin B is the first-line treatment for mucormycosis due to its broad-spectrum antifungal activity. Posaconazole is used for consolidation therapy following initial treatment with Amphotericin B, especially in cases of severe infection or in immunocompromised patients.
  • Treatment of the underlying immunodeficiency along with surgical debridement might be needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inj. Amphotericin B for 4-8 weeks, followed by oral itraconazole: This regimen is not the most recommended for mucormycosis. Itraconazole is less effective compared to posaconazole for mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Inj. Fluconazole, followed by oral fluconazole: Fluconazole is not effective against mucormycosis. It is primarily used for infections caused by Candida and Cryptococcus species.

 

Option D. Inj. Amphotericin B, followed by flucytosine: Flucytosine is used in combination with Amphotericin B for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, not mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis requires aggressive treatment with Amphotericin B followed by consolidation therapy with posaconazole, particularly in immunocompromised patients. This combination helps ensure both initial and sustained control of the fungal infection.

questions.text: An experiment is being conducted on a dog blood pressure to study the effect of acetylcholine. The blood pressure is recorded at each intervention and is shown below. What does phase 4 in the graph indicate? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Nicotinic action of acetylcholine

 

For demonstrating nicotinic actions (on ganglia) of acetylcholine, two criteria are required:

 

  • High dose of acetylcholine (around 5 mg).
  • Muscarinic receptors must be blocked by giving atropine (to avoid death of the animal due to overactivity of muscarinic receptors)

 

About the given graph:

 

 

  • In phases 1 and 2, Acetylcholine is given at doses of 2 mcg and 50 mcg. This leads to a drop in the BP due to its action in the muscarinic receptors.
  • In phase 3 when its muscarinic action is blocked by atropine, administration of 50 mcg of Acetylcholine does not cause a fall in BP.
  • But in phase 4, when Ach is administered at higher dose of 5 mg, it acts on the Neuronal Nicotinic receptors located in CNS, ganglia and adrenals, leading to their stimulation and release of norepinephrine, which causes the BP to shoot up. Thus, Phase 4 in the graph indicates the nicotinic action of acetylcholine at higher doses.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Muscarinic action of acetylcholine: Muscarinic actions are demonstrated in Phases 1 and 2, where acetylcholine causes a drop in blood pressure. This option is incorrect for Phase 4.

 

Option B. Potentiation of acetylcholine: Potentiation would suggest an increased effect due to repeated or combined actions, which is not the primary mechanism demonstrated in Phase 4.

 

Option C. Antagonism of acetylcholine: Antagonism would imply inhibition of acetylcholine’s effects. Phase 3 demonstrates antagonism (by atropine) but not Phase 4.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase 4 in the graph indicates the nicotinic action of acetylcholine, characterized by a rise in blood pressure due to the stimulation of neuronal nicotinic receptors after administering a high dose of acetylcholine (5 mg) following the blockade of muscarinic receptors with atropine.

questions.text:
A persistent alcoholic patient presents with convulsions and impaired sensorium. He has been drinking for ten years and consumes 24 units every day. His most recent drink was two days ago. He is discovered to have auditory hallucinations as well as secondary delusions. What method will you employ to manage this patient?

 

  1. Diazepam
  2. Thiamine
  3. Naltrexone
  4. Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, specifically delirium tremens, characterized by tremors, altered sensorium, hallucinations, seizures, and agitation.

 

1. Diazepam: Benzodiazepines, like diazepam, are the first line of treatment for alcohol withdrawal symptoms and can help reduce the severity of symptoms, prevent seizures, and can be titrated based on the severity of withdrawal.

 

2. Thiamine: Chronic alcoholics are at risk for thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, leading to Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is important to administer thiamine before or with the first dose of glucose-containing fluids or foods to prevent precipitating or exacerbating Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Naltrexone: This is an opioid antagonist that is used to decrease alcohol cravings. It is not directly useful in treating acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

4. Flupenthixol depot injection: This is an antipsychotic medication. It is not the primary treatment for alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 472-473.

questions.text:
Identify true statements about familial adenomatous polyposis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Autosomal recessive inheritance
  2. If not treated, all cases progress to adenocarcinoma colon.
  3. KRAS mutations cause familial adenomatous polyposis
  4. It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is a hereditary condition characterized by the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum, often numbering in the hundreds to thousands. The condition is caused by mutations in the APC gene (chromosome 5q), leading to autosomal dominant inheritance.

 

True Statements:

 

Statement 2: If not treated, all cases of FAP will progress to colorectal adenocarcinoma. This is because the polyps have a high potential to become malignant if not removed or if the patient does not undergo a prophylactic colectomy.

 

Statement 4: FAP is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium, which is often used as a marker for the condition, especially in screening family members.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1: FAP is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, not autosomal recessive. This means that a single copy of the mutated APC gene can cause the disease.

 

Statement 3: FAP is primarily caused by mutations in the APC gene, not KRAS. While KRAS mutations are involved in colorectal cancer progression, they are not the cause of FAP.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roenne's nasal step

 

  • Roenne's nasal step is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma.
  • Roenne's nasal step is a visual field defect. It is the result of two arcuate scotomas running in different arcs and meeting at the horizontal meridian. This forms a right-angled defect in the nasal side of the visual field.

 

Roenne’s nasal step

 

 

  • Early glaucomatous changes:
    • Increase in cup-disc ratio (C/D ratio) to >0.4
    • Splinter hemorrhages near the optic disc margin
    • Atrophy of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Advanced glaucomatous changes:
    • Marked increase in C/D ratio (0.7 or more)
    • Thinning of the neuroretinal rim
    • Nasal shifting of the retinal vessels or bayonetting
    • Pulsations of retinal arterioles at the disc margin.
    • If the damage progresses, all neural tissue is destroyed and the optic nerve appears white and deeply excavated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bayonetting: This refers to the appearance of blood vessels on the optic disc where the vessels appear to sharply bend or 'bayonet' due to the structural changes in the optic disc from glaucomatous damage, particularly as the neuroretinal rim thins and the cup enlarges.

 

Option C. Increased cup-disc ratio: A hallmark of glaucomatous damage to the optic nerve, where the optic cup enlarges relative to the overall disc, often exceeding a ratio of 0.5, which is considered abnormal and suggestive of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Baring of nasal arteries: This describes the exposure or baring of the nasal retinal arteries as a result of thinning of the nerve fiber layer in glaucoma. It is a less commonly described feature compared to others but can occur as part of the broader pattern of optic nerve head changes in glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roenne's nasal step, while indicative of the functional impact of glaucoma, does not represent a direct observation of the optic disc but is rather a manifestation of the disease's effect on the visual field.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about proto-oncogenes? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. KIT has decreased expression in GIST.
  2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.
  3. ERBB2 over-expression is associated with breast carcinomas.
  4. PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 Only

 

ERBB2, also known as HER2, is a proto-oncogene that encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase. Overexpression of HER2 is strongly associated with breast carcinomas, specifically HER2-positive breast cancers. HER2 is a significant marker in breast cancer, as its overexpression or amplification can lead to more aggressive tumor growth and is a target for specific therapies like trastuzumab.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. KIT has decreased expression in GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors): This statement is incorrect. KIT, also known as CD117, is commonly overexpressed in GISTs. The detection of KIT is often used diagnostically to confirm GIST.

 

2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung carcinoma: This statement is incorrect. KRAS mutations are more commonly associated with non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC), particularly adenocarcinoma of the lung, as well as colorectal and pancreatic cancers. 

 

4. PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers: This statement is incorrect. PDGFR-β (Platelet-derived growth factor receptor beta) is generally overexpressed in gliomas and leukemias, rather than being suppressed in colorectal cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ERBB2 encodes for HER2, which is involved in Breast carcinoma. ERBB1 encodes for EGFR, which is involved in Adenocarcinoma of lung.
  • Genes involved in GIST are → DOG1 > CD117 (cKIT) > CD34
  • KRAS mutations are cause of Lung, colorectal and pancreatic carcinoma. Gain of function mutation is seen in Adenocarcinoma of lung.
  • PDGFR-β over-expression is seen in Glioma and Leukemia.

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) updated its guidelines in 2016, recommending a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality. This guideline is structured to ensure comprehensive monitoring and support throughout the pregnancy:

 

  1. 1st Trimester:
    • Contact 1: up to 12 weeks
  2. 2nd Trimester:
    • Contact 2: at 20 weeks
    • Contact 3: at 26 weeks
  3. 3rd Trimester:
    • Contact 4: at 30 weeks
    • Contact 5: at 34 weeks
    • Contact 6: at 36 weeks
    • Contact 7: at 38 weeks
    • Contact 8: at 40 weeks

 

These visits are designed to monitor the health of the mother and fetus, provide timely interventions, and offer essential health education.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality.

 

Ref: The 2016 WHO model for positive pregnancy experience, MOHFW guidelines for antenatal care, ACOG guidelines for antenatal care (2017).

questions.text: A young male with a H/o dyslipidemia having ABC-A1 mutation shows the following. See the image and tell the diagnosis. (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tangier’s disease

 

Tangier's disease is an inherited disorder characterized by significantly reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in the blood. This condition can lead to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and organs. Individuals with Tangier's disease may have enlarged orange tonsils and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease as shown in the picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman's Disease: Wolman's disease is a severe form of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) deficiency, a rare genetic disorder. It is characterized by the complete absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the buildup of fats in various tissues and organs. Symptoms typically appear in infancy and may include hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), splenomegaly (enlarged spleen), diarrhea/steatorrhea (fatty stools), and vomiting. This condition can be life-threatening.

 

Option B. Gaucher's Disease: Gaucher's disease is another genetic disorder caused by the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. It results in the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucocerebroside in various organs and tissues, particularly the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Common symptoms include an enlarged spleen and liver, anemia, low platelet counts, and bone abnormalities. There are different types of Gaucher's disease, and the severity can vary.

 

Option D. Tay-Sachs Disease: Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system. It is caused by the absence or deficiency of an enzyme called hexosaminidase A, which leads to the buildup of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the brain and nerve cells. Symptoms typically appear in early childhood and include developmental regression, loss of motor skills, and a cherry-red spot in the eye. Tay-Sachs disease is progressive and ultimately fatal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia

 

ABC-A1 transporters are required for efflux of intracellular free cholesterol and phospholipids across the plasma membrane to combine with apolipoproteins, forming nascent high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) particles (see fig).

 

  • So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia).
  • Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Enlarged lymph nodes
    • Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals. It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase

questions.text: Identify the given bone marrow biopsy instrument. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Klima needle

 

The instrument shown is a Klima needle, which is used for bone marrow aspiration and biopsy.

 

  • Klima and Salah’s needles are both reusable bone marrow aspiration and biopsy needles made of stainless steel.
  • The Klima needle is distinguished by having a guard that screws along the length of the needle, but it does not have a side screw.
  • Salah’s needle also has a guard, but it is situated 2 cm from the tip and has a side screw for added stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salah's needle:


While similar to the Klima needle, Salah’s needle has a distinct side screw and guard located closer to the tip, which helps differentiate it from the Klima needle.

 

 

Option C. Jamshidi needle:


The Jamshidi needle has a tapered end, which helps reduce crush artifacts when obtaining bone marrow samples. It is often used for both diagnostic biopsy and aspiration.

 

 

Option D. Islam needle:


The Islam needle has a core securing device at the tip to hold the core of bone during the biopsy procedure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klima needle is used for bone marrow biopsy and is characterized by its guard without a side screw. It is crucial to differentiate between biopsy needles like Klima, Salah, Jamshidi, and Islam based on their structural features and specific use in medical procedures.

questions.text: What is the microscopy technique to produce high contrast image of transparent, live bacteria? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phase contrast microscopy

 

Phase-contrast microscopy (PCM) is an optical microscopy technique that converts phase shifts in light passing through a transparent specimen to brightness changes in the image. Phase shifts themselves are invisible, but become visible when shown as brightness variations.

 

Contrast is improved by using the difference in thickness or refractive index of structures within and around the cell. Difference in intensity of light is created as rays pass through varied refractive indices and produces contrast thus making the structures within the cells and its surroundings clearly visible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Option C. The electron microscope uses a beam of electrons and their wave-like characteristics to magnify an object's image, unlike the optical microscope that uses visible light to magnify images.

 

Option D. Polarized microscopy is used to visualize the intracellular structures using differences in birefringence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase contrast microscopy is the technique used to produce high contrast images of transparent, live bacteria by converting phase shifts into brightness changes.

questions.text: A woman presents with lesions on the inner thighs and peri-anal region. They are nodular, 4-6 mm in size, and appear pale. The histopathological image shows multiple intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies consistent with Henderson-Patterson bodies. The diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Molluscum contagiosum

 

Clinical history along with histological image showing intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies suggests a diagnosis of Molluscum contagiosum.

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a poxvirus infection of the skin and the mucous membranes.

 

There are four types of molluscum contagiosum viruses (MCVs), MCV-1 to -4, with MCV-1 being the most prevalent and MCV-2 being most often sexually transmitted.

 

The infections are common in young children between 2 and 12 years of age and are transmitted through direct contact or shared articles (e.g., towels).

 

Molluscum may affect any area of the skin but is most common on the trunk, arms, and legs. In adults, molluscum infections are typically sexually transmitted and affect the genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs.

 

The average incubation period is 6 weeks.

 

Diagnosis is based on the characteristic clinical appearance of pearly, domeshaped papules with a dimpled center. The papules measure 1 to 5 mm in diameter, and their central waxy core contains cells with intracytoplasmic viral inclusions called as Molluscum bodies or Henderson Patterson bodies.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trichodysplasia spinulosa: This is a rare viral infection associated with immunosuppression and does not typically present with the described clinical or histopathological features.

 

Option B. Condyloma accuminata: Caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), this condition presents as warty growths, typically on the genital and perianal regions, but it does not produce Henderson-Patterson bodies.

 

Option D. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, this sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis presents with ulcerative lesions rather than nodular papules and does not show the characteristic Henderson-Patterson bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection that presents with dome-shaped papules containing Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are diagnostic of this condition.

choices.text: MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in all of these conditions, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg

 

Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg: This is a contraindication for thrombolysis. Elevated blood pressure increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications during thrombolysis. Therefore, blood pressure must be controlled to below 185/110 mmHg before initiating thrombolytic therapy.

 

Thrombolysis is a treatment used to dissolve blood clots in certain types of stroke patients. It is most effective when administered within a specific time window from the onset of symptoms and under certain conditions to ensure patient safety and efficacy of the treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct: This indicates that the infarct size is within a range that is generally considered safe for thrombolysis. More extensive infarcts (> 1/3rd of the middle cerebral artery territory) are a contraindication due to the higher risk of hemorrhagic transformation.

 

Option C. Ischemia < 2 hours and D. Onset of symptoms < 4 hours: Both of these options fall within the critical time window for thrombolysis, which is generally considered up to 4.5 hours from symptom onset. Treatment within this time frame can significantly improve outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombolysis is contraindicated in patients with blood pressure higher than 185/110 mmHg at the time of treatment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a severe headache is scheduled to undergo a CT scan. During history taking, which of the following will you definitely ask for before the commencement of the scan? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LMP

 

Explanation:

 

The most important information to obtain during a history in a 28-year-old woman of reproductive age who has been referred for a CT scan is the last menstrual period (LMP). Since it is imperative to rule out pregnancy before taking a CT scan, last menstrual period is the most appropriate answer to this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Use of cochlear implant: While important in MRI to prevent damage to the implant from the magnetic field, it is not typically a concern in CT scans which use X-rays.

 

Option C. History of fall: Although relevant to the medical history, it is not critical specifically before a CT scan unless symptoms suggest complications that a CT scan could exacerbate.

 

Option D. History of hypertension: Important in overall patient assessment but does not directly influence the decision to perform a CT scan as critically as confirming pregnancy status does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inquiring about the Last Menstrual Period (LMP) is essential for any woman of childbearing age before undergoing diagnostic procedures involving radiation, such as a CT scan, to avoid potential harm to an unborn baby.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding sirtuins? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism.
  2. Promotes genes that increase longevity.
  3. They are of 7 types.
  4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Sirtuins are a family of proteins that have been widely studied for their role in regulating various cellular processes, including aging, metabolism, and stress responses. Here's a detailed breakdown of each statement:

 

  1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism: Sirtuins, particularly SIRT1, have been shown to enhance insulin sensitivity and promote glucose metabolism, which is crucial for maintaining energy homeostasis.
  2. Promotes genes that increase longevity: Sirtuins are known to regulate gene expression in ways that promote longevity. They are involved in the deacetylation of proteins that contribute to cell survival, repair, and metabolism, which are associated with extended lifespan in various organisms.
  3. They are of 7 types: There are seven known sirtuins in humans, designated SIRT1 through SIRT7, each with specific functions in different cellular compartments.
  4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases: Sirtuins function as NAD+-dependent deacetylases, a class of enzymes that remove acetyl groups from histone and non-histone proteins, influencing gene expression and protein activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity, glucose metabolism, promoting genes associated with longevity, and playing a significant role in various cellular processes.

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

Column A:

A. Malaria
B. Tuberculosis
C. Leprosy
D. Actinomycosis

 

Column B:

1. ZN stain

2. Fite-Faraco stain

3. Gram stain

4. Giemsa stain
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

The correct pairs are as follows:

 

Option A. Malaria – Giemsa stain (4): Giemsa stain is the gold standard for malaria diagnosis. It helps visualize Maurer's clefts (seen in Plasmodium falciparum) and Schüffner's dots (seen in Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale).

 

Option B. Tuberculosis – ZN stain (1): Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) stain is used to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis, as it helps identify acid-fast bacilli in sputum samples.

 

Option C. Leprosy – Fite-Faraco stain (2): The Fite-Faraco stain is used to visualize Mycobacterium leprae, which causes leprosy. This stain highlights the acid-fastness of the bacillus with better sensitivity than the ZN stain for this organism.

 

Option D. Actinomycosis – Gram stain (3): Gram stain is typically used to identify Actinomyces, which are Gram-positive filamentous bacteria involved in actinomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each pathogen has a preferred staining method for its detection:

 

  • Giemsa stain for malaria (Plasmodium species).
  • Ziehl-Neelsen stain for tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis).
  • Fite-Faraco stain for leprosy (Mycobacterium leprae).
  • Gram stain for actinomycosis (Actinomyces species).

questions.text: The absence of loud S1 in mitral stenosis would indicate all of the following, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild mitral stenosis

 

The first heart sound (S1) is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of systole. In mitral stenosis, the loudness of S1 can vary depending on several factors. A loud S1 is typically associated with the early stages of mitral stenosis when the valve leaflets are still relatively mobile. However, in certain conditions, S1 can become softer.

 

In mild mitral stenosis without significant calcification usually results in a loud S1. This is because the mitral valve leaflets are still relatively mobile and can close forcefully. Therefore, mild mitral stenosis is the correct exception in this context, as it does not typically cause a soft S1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcified valve: When the mitral valve becomes calcified, it loses its mobility. This results in a softer S1 because the valve leaflets are not able to close rapidly or forcefully.

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation can lead to an increased preload in the left ventricle, which can in turn affect the closure of the mitral valve, making S1 softer. Additionally, mitral regurgitation, which often coexists with mitral stenosis, can also soften S1.

 

Option C. First degree heart block: In first degree AV block, there is a prolonged PR interval. This delayed conduction can lead to a less forceful closure of the mitral valve, resulting in a softer S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis, a loud S1 is typically seen in the early stages with mobile valves, while a soft S1 can indicate valve calcification, aortic regurgitation, or first degree heart block. Mild mitral stenosis without calcification usually results in a loud S1

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors of vulval cancer except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vulval hamartoma

 

Vulval cancer has several known risk factors, which include:

 

  • Chronic vulval irritation: Persistent irritation and inflammation can contribute to the development of vulval cancer.
  • Immunosuppressive conditions: Conditions such as pregnancy and HIV infection can compromise the immune system, increasing the risk of vulval cancer.
  • HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Infection with HPV, particularly strains 16 and 18, is a significant risk factor.
  • Smoking: Smoking is a known risk factor for various cancers, including vulval cancer.
  • Condyloma (anogenital warts): Caused by HPV, these warts can lead to changes in vulval cells that may progress to cancer.
  • Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs): History of STDs can increase the risk due to the association with HPV and chronic inflammation.
  • Vulvar dystrophies: Conditions like lichen sclerosus can predispose individuals to vulval cancer.

 

Vulval hamartoma is not a risk factor for vulval cancer. Hamartomas are benign, disorganized clusters of tissue that do not typically transform into malignant tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval dystrophy: Vulval dystrophies, such as lichen sclerosus, are risk factors for vulval cancer due to chronic irritation and inflammation.

 

Option C. Smoking: Smoking is a well-documented risk factor for many cancers, including vulval cancer.

 

Option D. Vulval warts: Vulval warts, often caused by HPV, can lead to cellular changes that increase the risk of vulval cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulval hamartomas are not a risk factor for vulval cancer, while chronic irritation, immunosuppressive conditions, HPV infection, smoking, anogenital warts, STDs, and vulvar dystrophies are known risk factors.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 680, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 334

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of ventricular action potential in the correct order: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
  2. Repolarizing K+ currents
  3. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  4. Transient outward flow of potassium
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, D, A, B

 

The ventricular action potential is characterized by a sequence of changes in membrane potential and ionic currents. The correct sequence is as follows:

 

  1. C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels: This is the initial depolarization phase (Phase 0). When the membrane potential reaches the threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, leading to a rapid influx of Na+ ions and a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  2. D. Transient outward flow of potassium: This corresponds to Phase 1. Shortly after the peak of the action potential, transient outward K+ channels open, causing a brief efflux of K+ ions which results in a slight repolarization.
  3. A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels: This is Phase 2, the plateau phase. Voltage-gated L-type calcium channels open, allowing Ca2+ to enter the cell. The influx of Ca2+ is balanced by the efflux of K+ through delayed rectifier K+ channels, maintaining a plateau in the membrane potential.
  4. B. Repolarizing K+ currents: This is Phase 3. The Ca2+ channels close, but the delayed rectifier K+ channels remain open, leading to a net efflux of K+ and returning the membrane potential to its resting value.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for ventricular action potential is as follows:

 

C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

D. Transient outward flow of potassium

A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels

B. Repolarizing K+ currents

choices.text: High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.text: The dead body of a 4-year-old child who was playing around the riverside and accidentally drowned in the river is recovered. There is frothing seen from his mouth and nose. Which of the below postmortem findings is not seen in a case of drowning? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to antemortem drowning.

 

This finding is unrelated to drowning and would suggest chronic arsenic poisoning rather than an acute drowning incident.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway
  • Water in the stomach and small intestine
  • Water in middle ear
  • Cerebral edema
  • Bloated and cyanosed face
  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.
  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs
  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils
  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours
  • Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist 
  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voluminous and ballooned out lungs: Seen in drowning due to the inhalation of water.

 

Option C. Paltauf's hemorrhage in sub pleura: Hemorrhages found beneath the pleura, associated with drowning.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist: Indicates a struggle and is a sign of antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of drowning, typical findings include frothing from the mouth and nose, voluminous lungs, and cadaveric spasm with debris. High arsenic concentration in hair shafts is not associated with drowning.

questions.text:
Consider the causes of alopecia. Which among the following cause(s) non-scarring alopecia? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Non-scarring alopecia is caused by androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium (1, 2, and 3). Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a type of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

  • Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease causing non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease associated with several autoimmune conditions, including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis. It mainly affects the scalp, but may also involve the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, it can lead to total hair loss on the scalp (alopecia totalis) or the entire body (alopecia universalis).
  • Telogen effluvium is a type of non-scarring alopecia marked by diffuse shedding of normal hair due to the premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle. It can be either acute or chronic:
    • Acute telogen effluvium typically occurs 2–3 months after stressful events such as high fever, surgery, or postpartum hormonal changes (telogen gravidarum). This condition often resolves spontaneously.
    • Chronic telogen effluvium persists for more than six months and is often associated with thyroid disorders, iron-deficiency anemia, or malnutrition.
  • Androgenetic alopecia is a non-scarring alopecia characterized by a reduction in hair fiber production and follicle miniaturization. It is related to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), an androgenic metabolite, and has two forms:
    • Male-pattern hair loss typically causes frontal hairline recession and vertex thinning.
    • Female-pattern hair loss results in mid-frontal scalp thinning with minimal involvement of the temporal region.
  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia, on the other hand, is a type of scarring (cicatricial) alopecia, leading to permanent hair loss due to follicular destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3 and 4: While androgenic alopecia (option 3) causes non-scarring alopecia, frontal fibrosing alopecia (option 4) is a scarring form of alopecia, making this option incorrect.

 

Option C. 2, 3, and 4: Although telogen effluvium (option 2) and androgenic alopecia (option 3) are types of non-scarring alopecia, frontal fibrosing alopecia (option 4) is scarring, which makes this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Only 4: Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a scarring type of alopecia, so it cannot be classified as non-scarring, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-scarring alopecia includes androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium. These conditions result in hair loss that does not involve permanent destruction of the hair follicles, distinguishing them from scarring types of alopecia like frontal fibrosing alopecia.

questions.text: Identify the nerve passing around the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common peroneal nerve

 

The structure marked in the image is the fibula's neck.

 

The common peroneal nerve supplies motor fibers to the muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg, including the fibularis longus and fibularis brevis muscles, which evert the foot and plantarflex the ankle joint. It also provides sensory fibers to the skin over the lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot.

 

Injuries to the common peroneal nerve can occur due to trauma or compression, and can result in weakness or paralysis of the muscles it innervates, as well as sensory loss over the affected area. Common peroneal nerve injuries can be treated with conservative measures such as physiotherapy or surgery in severe cases.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sural nerve: The sural nerve is a sensory nerve in the calf region. It is formed by branches from both the common peroneal and tibial nerves. The sural nerve provides sensation to the posterolateral aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot. It runs more distally in the leg and is not closely associated with the neck of the fibula.

 

Option C. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve is another major branch of the sciatic nerve. After the division of the sciatic nerve, the tibial nerve continues its course in the posterior compartment of the leg, supplying muscles there and then continuing into the foot. It is primarily responsible for plantar flexion of the foot and toe flexion. The tibial nerve does not have a close relation with the neck of the fibula as it runs more medially in the leg.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve originates from the lumbar plexus and supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh. It is responsible for hip flexion and knee extension. This nerve is located in the anterior aspect of the thigh, far away from the neck of the fibula, and has no direct relation with it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Common peroneal nerve (also known as common fibular nerve), a significant branch of the sciatic nerve, follows a course along the thigh's posterior compartment and wraps around the fibula's neck, making it susceptible to injury. After encircling the fibula, it splits into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves, which innervate the leg's lateral and anterior compartments and contribute sensory functions to parts of the foot.

choices.text: Rocky mountain spotted fever

questions.text: Which disease causes the lesion shown in the image below? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scrub typhus

 

The lesion shown in the image is eschar. It is seen in scrub typhus.

 

Scrub typhus is an infectious disease caused by the rickettsial bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

It is transmitted to humans by the bite of the larva of trombiculid mites. Later it causes disseminated vasculitis and perivascular inflammation ultimately leading to significant vascular leakage leading to end-organ injury.

 

Clinical features usually arise after an incubation period of 6-21 days and manifest as fever, headache, myalgia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. An eschar which usually begins as a primary papular lesion later crusts to form a black ulcer with central necrosis is a distinct feature of scrub typhus although its presence varies in different regions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: A classic case of Rocky mountain spotted fever (RMSF) involves a rash that appears 2-4 days after the onset of fever as small, flat, pink, macules on the wrists, forearms, and ankles and spreads to include the trunk and sometimes the palms of hands and soles of feet.

 

Option B: Malaria is a protozoal disease caused by Plasmodium species characterized by periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option D: COVID-19 is a highly contagious viral disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

 

Educational Objective

 

Scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, is characterized by an eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with fever and systemic symptoms.

choices.text: E1, E2, E5
E6, E7
L1, L2

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the proteins of the virus act as oncogenes?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E6, E7

 

The image shows the life cycle of the human papilloma virus, and the E6 and E7 proteins act as oncogenes

 

 

  • HPV oncogenes E6 and E7 deregulate host cell cycle by binding and inactivating tumor suppressor genes p53 and pRb.
  • Binding of E6 gene to p53 causes degradation of p53.
  • E7 gene binds to pRb and disrupts the complex between pRb and E2F leading to uncontrolled proliferation. HPV, human papilloma virus.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.

choices.text: In children, equally among males and females.
In adults, equally among males and females.
In adults, occurs more in males than in females.
In children, occurs more in females than in males.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with sudden-onset blindness for the past 4 hours. However, on history taking, it is noted that she is not concerned about it. However, she is concerned that her mother passed away recently and that she should have spent more time with her. Physical examination findings are normal. Which of the following is true about the condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In children, occurs more in females than in males.

 

The clinical presentation described is suggestive of conversion disorder (also called functional neurological symptom disorder). This condition is characterized by neurological symptoms that are not consistent with known neurological or medical conditions. In this case, the sudden-onset blindness with normal physical examination results and a lack of concern about the blindness (referred to as la belle indifférence) is a classic presentation of conversion disorder.

 

Conversion disorder frequently follows psychosocial stressors, as seen in this girl who recently experienced the death of her mother. These symptoms are thought to represent unconscious psychological conflict manifesting in physical symptoms. There is no underlying physical cause for the symptoms, and the symptoms are not deliberately produced.

 

The correct answer, D. In children, occurs more in females than in males, is accurate because conversion disorder is more common in females, particularly during childhood and adolescence. This gender disparity is especially evident in children and young adults, where females are disproportionately affected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In children, equally among males and females: This is incorrect. Conversion disorder is not equally distributed among males and females. It is significantly more common in females, especially during childhood and adolescence.

 

Option B. In adults, equally among males and females: This is incorrect. Conversion disorder is more common in females in both children and adults. The disorder does not show equal prevalence between the sexes at any age.

 

Option C. In adults, occurs more in males than in females: This is incorrect. Conversion disorder is more prevalent in females across all age groups, including adults. There is no evidence to suggest it occurs more in males at any stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conversion disorder often follows psychological stress and is characterized by sudden neurological symptoms without a medical explanation. It commonly presents with motor or sensory deficits and is more prevalent in females, especially in children and adolescents.

choices.text: ER +, PR +, HER2 –
ER +, PR -, HER2 –
ER -, PR -, HER2 –
ER -, PR -, HER2 +

questions.text: What finding on immunohistochemical staining is consistent with basal-like breast cancer in a 59-year-old female presenting with a breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ER-, PR-, HER2-

 

ER -, PR -, HER2 –: Basal-like breast cancer is characterized by being negative for estrogen receptor (ER -), progesterone receptor (PR -), and HER2 (HER2 –). This profile is consistent with basal-like breast cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ER +, PR +, HER2 –: This profile indicates that the tumor is estrogen receptor-positive (ER +) and progesterone receptor-positive (PR +) but HER2-negative (HER2 –). This profile is not consistent with basal-like breast cancer.

 

Option B. ER +, PR -, HER2 –: This profile suggests that the tumor is estrogen receptor-positive (ER +) but progesterone receptor-negative (PR -) and HER2-negative (HER2 –). This is not consistent with basal-like breast cancer.

 

Option D. ER -, PR -, HER2 +: This profile indicates that the tumor is negative for estrogen receptor (ER -) and progesterone receptor (PR -) but HER2-positive (HER2 +). This profile is not consistent with basal-like breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal-like or triple-negative breast cancer is characterized by the absence of estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) on immunohistochemical staining. Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-coloured tissue, with ER and PR staining the nucleus brown, while HER2 staining the cell membrane brown.

questions.text: A patient presented with violent, flinging movements. Where is the lesion causing the hemiballismus seen? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subthalamic nucleus

 

Hemiballismus is characterized by involuntary, violent, flinging movements, typically on one side of the body. This condition is most commonly associated with a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus. The subthalamic nucleus plays a crucial role in regulating movements, and damage to this area can lead to the excessive, uncontrolled movements seen in hemiballismus. This differentiates it from lesions in other parts of the basal ganglia, which are associated with different movement disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Putamen: Lesions in the putamen are more commonly associated with chorea, which involves rapid, involuntary, and irregular movements, rather than the violent flinging movements of hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Caudate nucleus: Similar to the putamen, lesions in the caudate nucleus typically result in chorea. The caudate nucleus is part of the striatum, and its dysfunction does not usually present with the violent movements characteristic of hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Globus pallidus: Lesions in the globus pallidus often result in athetosis, which involves slow, writhing movements. This is different from the abrupt and forceful movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemiballismus, characterized by violent, flinging movements, is most commonly caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.

questions.text: What is the reason behind Senile Atrophy? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced blood supply

 

Senile atrophy is seen when there is a reduced blood supply to a tissue.

 

  • Atrophy is decrease in cell size and/or number due to decreased demand or functional loss.
  • 2 pathways responsible for it: Ubiquitin Pathway (via Proteasomes) and Autophagy (Defense mechanism).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Denervation: Atrophy due to loss of nerve supply is known as denervation atrophy, commonly seen in conditions like poliomyelitis.

 

Option B. Decreased nutrition: This refers to atrophy due to inadequate nutrient supply, leading to cachexia.

 

Option C. Decreased workload: This refers to disuse atrophy, where tissues reduce in size due to inactivity, such as muscle wasting in immobilized limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Senile atrophy is primarily due to reduced blood supply, leading to tissue shrinkage and loss of function with aging.

choices.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain.
Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

 

Laparoscopic surgeries have become popular as they result in lesser post-operative pain, are cosmetically better, and result in an earlier return to normal physiological function (Options A, B, and C). Patients are discharged from the hospital earlier, with a lower incidence of complications, as compared to open surgeries. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer, as it is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery.

 

This statement is incorrect. Laparoscopic surgery is associated with shorter hospital stays compared to traditional open surgery. Patients typically spend less time in the hospital and recover faster, which is one of the key advantages of this approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain: Smaller incisions and less tissue trauma typically result in less post-operative pain compared to traditional open surgery.

 

Option B. Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions: This is an advantage of laparoscopic surgery. The smaller incisions are not only cosmetically appealing but also result in reduced scarring and a lower risk of wound infections.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function: Patients often recover more quickly and can resume their normal activities sooner due to the minimally invasive nature of the procedure.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the hospital with high-grade fever and altered consciousness. On examination, the patient had neck rigidity and pain when bending the neck. A lumbar puncture was performed and it showed a WBC count of 1500 cells/ L, majority being neutrophils, elevated pressure with protein of 120 mg/dL, and a CSF glucose level of 70 mg dL & blood glucose level - 300 mg dL). How will you manage the index case? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vancomycin + ceftriaxone

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory results provided strongly suggest a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. The CSF analysis shows significant findings including a high WBC count predominantly composed of neutrophils, elevated protein, and a relatively low CSF glucose level considering the elevated blood glucose. The CSF glucose level, when compared to the blood glucose, gives a ratio that is suggestive of bacterial meningitis (a ratio of 0.4 or less is highly indicative).

 

Meningitis can present with symptoms such as high-grade fever, altered consciousness, neck rigidity, and positive meningeal signs like Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs. The diagnosis is confirmed by CSF analysis, which typically shows:

 

  • Neutrophilic pleocytosis
  • Increased protein levels
  • Decreased glucose concentrations
  • Presence of microorganisms on Gram stain and culture

 

The initial treatment of bacterial meningitis should include broad-spectrum antibiotics that cover the most common pathogens. A combination of a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone and vancomycin is recommended to cover for Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Piperacillin + tazobactam: Piperacillin + tazobactam is used in certain situations such as hospital-acquired infections or when there is no response to ceftriaxone. However, it is not the first-line treatment for community-acquired bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Amphotericin + flucytosine: Amphotericin + flucytosine are antifungal agents used to treat fungal meningitis, not bacterial meningitis. Fungal meningitis presents differently and typically in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Antitubercular therapy: Antitubercular therapy is considered when the CSF profile shows low glucose, high protein, and lymphocytic predominance, which is typical for tuberculous meningitis. The provided CSF findings do not match those of tuberculous meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin combined with a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone is the recommended initial treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis.

choices.text: High fetal head station

questions.text: All are causes of uterine dysfunction, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiparity

 

Explanation:

 

  • Multiparity is not a cause of uterine dysfunction; rather, nulliparity (the condition of a woman who has never given birth) is a recognized cause. Uterine dysfunction, particularly hypotonic uterine dysfunction, is associated with several factors, but multiparity is generally associated with a more efficient labor process due to the body's previous experience with childbirth.

 

Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction:

 

  • Neuraxial analgesia: The use of epidural or spinal anesthesia can interfere with uterine contractions.
  • Chorioamnionitis: This is an infection of the amniotic fluid and membranes, which can lead to inflammation and impaired uterine contractility.
  • Nulliparity: First-time mothers (nulliparous women) are more likely to experience uterine dysfunction due to the unconditioned nature of the uterine muscles.
  • Other factors:
    • Mechanical disruption of myometrial function by a fibroid or pelvic tumor
    • Maternal obesity
    • Uterine mullerian anomaly
    • Increased maternal age
    • Malposition and malpresentation of the fetus
    • Contracted pelvis

 

Other options:

 

Option A. High fetal head station: High fetal head station can be associated with labor dystocia and uterine dysfunction as it may indicate issues with the descent of the baby.

 

Option C. Multiparity: Neuraxial block (e.g., epidural) can interfere with effective uterine contractions, leading to uterine dysfunction.

 

Option D. Chorioamnionitis: Chorioamnionitis, an infection, can impair uterine contractions and lead to dysfunctional labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nulliparity, not multiparity, is a cause of uterine dysfunction. Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction include neuraxial analgesia, chorioamnionitis, nulliparity, and mechanical factors such as fibroids or pelvic tumors.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg459, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 416

questions.text: Which of the following physiological adaptations is generally not observed at high altitudes? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis

 

The physiological adaptation that does not happen at high altitudes is respiratory acidosis. Respiratory alkalosis is the physiological adaptation seen at high altitudes due to hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary vasoconstriction: Correct, as it is a physiological response to low oxygen levels to improve gas exchange.

 

Option B. Polycythemia: Correct, as it increases the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity.

 

Option D. Hypoxia: Correct, as it is the primary condition caused by low oxygen levels at high altitudes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The principal means by which acclimatization to high altitude comes about are

 

  1. A great increase in pulmonary ventilation - increase in pulmonary ventilation on rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of carbon dioxide, reducing the Pco2 and increasing the ph of the body fluids.
  2. Increased numbers of red blood cells,
  3. Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs,
  4. Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues
  5. Increased ability of the tissue cells to use oxygen despite low Po2.
  6. Cellular Acclimatization - cell mitochondria and cellular oxidative enzyme systems are slightly more plentiful than in sea-level inhabitants

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Interlobular septations
  2. Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation
  3. Pleural effusion
  4. Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of fungal pneumonia shows interlobular septations, peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation, and pleural effusion. HRCT of fungal pneumonia shows a nodule (not a cavity) with surrounding ground-glass opacities.

 

A nodule surrounded by ground-glass attenuation on HRCT imaging is seen in aspergillosis, candidiasis, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, coccidioidomycosis, and paracoccidioidomycosis. Cavitation on HRCT is seen in cases of community-acquired pneumonia due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, S. aureus, and gram-negative bacilli.

 

Aspergillosis is a fungal disease caused by Aspergillus species. Pulmonary aspergillosis has been categorized into saprophytic, allergic, and invasive forms.

 

HRCT findings of various types of aspergillosis are as follows:

 

  • Aspergilloma (saprophytic) shows a mass with soft-tissue attenuation, which is separated from the thoracic wall by airspace called the air crescent sign. Multiple nodules and bilateral involvement may be seen.
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA-allergic) shows hypodense mucous plugs.
  • Angioinvasive aspergillosis shows multiple nodules surrounded by a halo of ground-glass attenuation (halo sign) or pleural-based wedge-shaped areas of consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2, 4: Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities are more often associated with bacterial pneumonia or other causes of lung abscesses, not typically fungal pneumonia like aspergillosis or Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

 

Option B. 1, 3, 4: While pleural effusion and interlobular septations are seen in fungal infections, cavitary lesions are more commonly associated with bacterial infections rather than fungal.

 

Option D. 2, 3, 4: This option includes cavitary lesions and pleural effusion but excludes interlobular septations, which are typically seen in fungal pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fungal pneumonia on HRCT typically shows interlobular septations, peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation, and pleural effusion with a nodule surrounded by ground-glass attenuation.

questions.text: Match the following drugs in column A to their site of action in column B?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2


The correct match is as follows:

 

 

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts at the proximal convoluted tubules.
  • Torsemide is a loop diuretic that acts by inhibiting Na+-K+-2Cl channel at the thick ascending limb of the Loop of Henle.
  • Chlorthalidone, a thiazide-like diuretic, inhibits the Na-CI symporter in the distal convoluted tubule.
  • Vasopressin, or ADH, is secreted by the posterior pituitary and mainly acts on the collecting duct, and increases the reabsorption of free water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetazolamide acts on the proximal convoluted tubule, Torsemide on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, Chlorothiazide on the distal convoluted tubule, and Vasopressin on the collecting duct.

choices.text: Niemann pick disease
Fish eye disease

questions.text: Identify the given image: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gaucher’s disease

 

  • Gaucher's disease is an inherited genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of a fatty substance called glucocerebroside in various organs, particularly the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.
  • Symptoms include bone pain, anemia, enlarged organs (hepatosplenomegaly), a swollen and painful belly, easy bruising, and fatigue.
  • Gaucher's disease is most common in Jewish people of Eastern and Central European descent (Ashkenazi).
  • It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase, which is responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wolman's disease:

  • Wolman's disease is a rare autosomal recessive lipid storage disease.
  • It is caused by mutations in the LIPA gene, which encodes lysosomal acid lipase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down lipids.
  • Individuals with Wolman's disease have a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the accumulation of cholesterol and triglycerides in various organs, including the liver, spleen, and intestines.
  • Symptoms often appear in infancy and may include enlarged liver and spleen, abdominal distension, diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

 

Option C. Niemann-Pick disease:

  • Niemann-Pick disease is a rare inherited disorder that affects the body's ability to metabolize fat (cholesterol and lipids) within cells.
  • There are several subtypes of Niemann-Pick disease, including types A, B, and C, each caused by different genetic mutations.
  • Symptoms can vary depending on the subtype but may include hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), neurological problems, and respiratory difficulties.
  • Type C Niemann-Pick disease, in particular, can lead to cognitive and motor impairment.

 

Option D. Fish eye disease:

  • Fish eye disease is a rare genetic disorder and is a variant of familial lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) deficiency.
  • It is characterized by a deficiency of the LCAT enzyme, which plays a role in cholesterol metabolism.
  • Fish eye disease leads to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and can cause eye problems, including corneal opacities and vision impairment.
  • Unlike the more severe form of LCAT deficiency, known as LCAT deficiency, Fish eye disease typically has milder symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows crumpled tissue paper appearance of macrophage cells (see images below) which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. This disease is a type of sphingolipidoses and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme β-glucosyl ceramidase.

choices.text: Temperature >38 degrees Celsius or <36 degrees Celsius

questions.text: All the following are criteria for SIRS, except ______. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systolic BP <90 mmHg

 

Systolic BP <90 mmHg is not a criterion for SIRS (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome).

 

SIRS is diagnosed when two of the following criteria are present:

 

  1. Hyperthermia (>38°C) or hypothermia (<36°C)
  2. Tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute) or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO₂) <32 mmHg
  3. Tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute)
  4. White blood cell count >12 × 10⁹/L or <4 × 10⁹/L, or >10% band forms (immature neutrophils)

 

Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature >38°C or <36°C: Is a part of the SIRS criteria.

 

Option C. Respiratory rate >20 breaths/min: Is a criterion for SIRS (tachypnea).

 

Option D. Heart rate >90/min: (tachycardia) is also one of the criteria for SIRS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SIRS criteria include hyperthermia/hypothermia, tachycardia, tachypnea, and abnormal white blood cell count. Systolic BP is not included as a direct diagnostic criterion for SIRS.

choices.text: Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days
Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

 

A Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear shows many red blood cells (RBCs) infected with classic, ring-shaped and headphone-shaped trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum parasite. High degree of parasitemia and RBCs infected with two or more trophozoites were seen, a finding typical of P. falciparum malaria.

 

Cerebral malaria is a complicated form of malaria associated with multisystem organ dysfunction and high degree of morbidity and mortality. These patients often present with impaired consciousness, delirium and convulsions. It is a medical emergency where prompt diagnosis and early institution of treatment can be lifesaving. Intravenous quinine or artesunate are the mainstays of treatment in cerebral malaria.

 

Management of Cerebral Malaria:

 

  • Artesunate: Administered intravenously at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg immediately, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then once daily if necessary.
  • Alternative Treatment:
    • Artemether: 3.2 mg/kg intramuscularly initially, followed by 1.6 mg/kg once daily.
    • Quinine dihydrochloride: 20 mg of salt/kg infused over 4 hours, followed by 10 mg of salt/kg infused over 2-8 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg intravenously for 7 days: Doxycycline is not the first-line treatment for severe malaria. It is typically used as a secondary prophylactic measure or in combination with other antimalarial drugs.

 

Option B. Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days: Clindamycin is not used for the treatment of malaria. It is an antibiotic that is used for bacterial infections.

 

Option D. Chloroquine intramuscularly 8 hourly for 3 days: Chloroquine is ineffective against Plasmodium falciparum due to widespread resistance. It is also not suitable for treating severe or cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment with intravenous artesunate, which is the most effective and rapid-acting medication for severe malaria.

questions.text:
Which is the correct sequence for the correction of hypospadias? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Urethroplasty
  2. Meatoplasty
  3. Orthoplasty
  4. Glanuloplasty
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 → 1 → 4 → 2

 

The correct sequence for the correction of hypospadias is Option C. 3 → 1 → 4 → 2.

 

The main principles of surgery in hypospadias, in sequence, include:

 

  1. Orthoplasty: Corrects chordee (the abnormal curvature of the penis), which is the first step in the procedure to ensure proper straightening of the penis.
  2. Urethroplasty: Repositioning and tubularization of the urethra to ensure the proper opening at the distal end of the penis.
  3. Glanuloplasty: Reconstruction of the glans, forming the tip of the penis and covering the urethral opening.
  4. Meatoplasty: Reconstruction of the distal urethral meatus, which is the final step to ensure a functional and anatomically correct urethral opening.
