Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by a ventrally placed urethral meatus, a hooded foreskin, and ventral chordee (bending of the penis). The correction aims to restore both functional and cosmetic normality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. This sequence places urethroplasty first, which is incorrect because chordee (orthoplasty) needs to be corrected first to ensure proper straightening before other steps.

 

Option B. This is a common but incorrect option, as it places urethroplasty before glanuloplasty, while glans reconstruction should be done before distal urethral meatoplasty.

 

Option D. The sequence is incorrect, placing urethroplasty and orthoplasty in the wrong order.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for hypospadias repair is orthoplasty first (to correct chordee), followed by urethroplasty, glanuloplasty, and finally meatoplasty to reconstruct the urethral opening.

questions.text: A farmer presents with pain and discharge in his left eye. He says that he sustained an injury caused by a leaf a few days back. What is the finding seen in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypopyon  

 

The finding seen in the image is hypopyon.

 

  • Hypopyon is an accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, typically seen in the lower part of the chamber as a whitish exudate.
  • In fungal corneal ulcers, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungus can penetrate into the anterior chamber without causing a perforation.
  • Hypopyon associated with anterior uveitis is immobile because of the high fibrin content in the exudate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Hyphema is a hemorrhage in the anterior chamber. It commonly occurs after a blunt ocular injury. The bleeding is from the iris root or ciliary body face. The blood settles inferiorly forming a fluid level.

 

 

Option B: Aqueous flare refers to the haziness of the normally clear fluid in the anterior chamber. It reflects the presence of protein due to the breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier. The presence of flare indicates active inflammation.

 

Option C: Arlt line is the scarring on the conjunctiva in the area of sulcus subtarsalis. It can be a single line, irregularly shaped, or star-shaped. Common causes are trachoma, healed traumatic wounds, or surgical scars.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypopyon is points to severe intraocular inflammation needing prompt treatment to preserve eye function and prevent potential complications. The presence of hypopyon after an injury with organic material highly suggests a fungal etiology, requiring specific antifungal treatment alongside broad-spectrum antibacterial coverage.

questions.text: All are long acting reversible methods of contraception, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Female sterilization

 

Explanation:

 

Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARC) are those which are administered at a frequency of less than once per month. LARC methods include:

 

  • Intrauterine devices (IUDs): Such as CuT 380A with a lifespan of 10 years, and the Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG IUD) with a lifespan of 5 years.
  • Implants: Implanon, which contains etonorgestrel, has a lifespan of 3 years, and Norplant II, which contains LNG, also has a lifespan of 3 years.
  • Injectable contraceptives: Including Depo-Provera (DMPA) which is administered as 150 mg every 3 months, and Norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN) which is administered as 200 mg every 2 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestin injection: This is a form of LARC. Injectable contraceptives like DMPA and NET-EN are given at intervals of 2 to 3 months.

 

Option B. Progestin implants: These are also considered LARC. Implanon and Norplant II are examples of progestin implants with a duration of action up to 3 years.

 

Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices: Both types of IUDs are classified as LARC. The CuT 380A lasts for up to 10 years, and the LNG IUD lasts for up to 5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARC) include intrauterine devices (IUDs), progestin implants, and injectable contraceptives, but do not include permanent methods like female sterilization.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 107,112, 127, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 491-492,479,

questions.text:
Match the following therapeutic methods used in the management of psoriasis with their possible side effects. (INICET NOV 2022) 

 

Column A

1. PUVA

2. Cyclosporine

3. Methotrexate

4. Acitretin

 

Column B

a. Abortifacient

b. Effective but is highly nephrotoxic

c. Long-term use increases the risk of skin cancer

d. Mucositis, teratogenic
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

  1. PUVA (Psoralen + UVA):
    Long-term use increases the risk of skin cancer.
    PUVA is highly effective in treating psoriasis but has the potential for both acute and chronic side effects. Chronic use is associated with an increased risk of     non-melanoma skin cancer (such as squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma).
  2. Cyclosporine:
    Effective but is highly nephrotoxic.
    Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant primarily associated with     renal impairment (nephrotoxicity), metabolic disturbances, and an increased risk of malignancies. It is less frequently used now due to these side effects.
  3. Methotrexate:
    Abortifacient.
    Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist used to treat psoriasis and other autoimmune conditions. It has abortifacient properties and is used in the management of     molar pregnancies. Methotrexate is also associated with mucositis, teratogenicity, and hepatotoxicity.
  4. Acitretin:
    Mucositis, teratogenic.
    Acitretin, a systemic retinoid, is highly teratogenic and causes mucocutaneous side effects such as     mucositis and hyperlipidemia. Women are advised to avoid conception for 3 years after stopping acitretin due to its teratogenic effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d: This incorrectly matches Cyclosporine (a) with abortifacient properties, which is incorrect as this applies to Methotrexate. Methotrexate (3) should be associated with a, not Cyclosporine (2).

 

Option C. 1-b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a: This mismatches PUVA and Cyclosporine. PUVA should be associated with the risk of skin cancer (c), not nephrotoxicity (b), and Cyclosporine is nephrotoxic, not linked to mucositis (d).

 

Option D. 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d: PUVA is associated with skin cancer risk, not nephrotoxicity, and Cyclosporine is nephrotoxic, not associated with skin cancer. This option misplaces the side effects for both PUVA and Cyclosporine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In psoriasis treatment, be aware of the side effects of key therapies:

 

  • PUVA increases the risk of skin cancer with long-term use.
  • Cyclosporine is highly nephrotoxic.
  • Methotrexate has abortifacient properties.
  • Acitretin causes mucositis and is highly teratogenic.

questions.text:
A healthcare worker in a remote primary healthcare clinic is reviewing the Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) on a vial of a vaccine that has been stored in the clinic for some time. Which of the following statements regarding the utility and interpretation of the VVM is/are correct?" (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare.
  2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat.
  3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine.
  4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM.
  5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is in an acceptable range.
  6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.

 

Other Options:

 

3. A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.

 

4 & 5. Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.

 

6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: New drug application is filed after phase 4
Phase 4 is also called post-marketing surveillance
Phase 3 are open label studies without any blinding
Phase 2 is done on healthy individuals

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding clinical trials? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Phase 4 is also called post-marketing surveillance

 

Phase 4 clinical trials are also called post-marketing surveillance. This statement is correct. Phase 4 trials are conducted after a drug has been approved and marketed to monitor its long-term effectiveness and safety.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. New drug application is filed after phase 4: This statement is incorrect. The New Drug Application (NDA) is filed after successful completion of Phase 3 clinical trials, not Phase 4. Phase 4 occurs after the drug has been approved and marketed.

 

Option C. Phase 3 are open label studies without any blinding: This statement is incorrect. Phase 3 clinical trials are typically randomized and double-blinded to eliminate bias and ensure robust results. Open label studies, where both the participants and investigators know which treatment is being administered, are less common in Phase 3 trials.

 

Option D. Phase 2 is done on healthy individuals: This statement is incorrect. Phase 2 clinical trials are conducted on patients who have the condition that the drug is intended to treat. Phase 1 trials, on the other hand, are usually done on healthy volunteers to assess safety and dosage.


Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of HIV is started on combined active antiretroviral therapy (cART). After 5 months of treatment, he develops hyperpigmentation in the palms and soles. What is the most likely drug causing this? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emtricitabine

 

The most likely drug causing hyperpigmentation of the hands and soles is emtricitabine.

 

Emtricitabine is an anti-retroviral drug that acts by inhibiting nucleoside reverse transcriptase (NRTI). It is generally well-tolerated and has minimal toxic effects. One of the known adverse effects is hyperpigmentation of the skin, particularly in sun-exposed areas, as well as the palms and soles. Other side effects may include headache, vomiting, and nausea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nelfinavir: Nelfinavir is a protease inhibitor that is more commonly associated with causing diarrhea or loose stools, which usually resolves within a month of starting treatment. It does not commonly cause hyperpigmentation.

 

Option C. Abacavir: Abacavir is another NRTI but is known for its potential to cause a life-threatening hypersensitivity syndrome, which typically presents with fever, abdominal pain, and maculopapular rash. This reaction occurs within 6 weeks of starting the drug and requires immediate discontinuation. Hyperpigmentation is not a known side effect of Abacavir.

 

Option D. Zidovudine: Zidovudine is an NRTI associated with side effects like malaise, fatigue, myalgia, anorexia, and insomnia. It can also cause nail hyperpigmentation and bone marrow suppression, but it is not as strongly associated with hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles as emtricitabine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emtricitabine is an NRTI that can cause hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles, especially in individuals on long-term antiretroviral therapy. It is essential to monitor patients for this side effect, although it is typically benign.

questions.text: Which of the following is a gram-positive organism that shows the following appearance on Ziehl-Neelsen staining? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The characteristic morphology of Nocardia is a branching, filamentous, gram-positive rod when observed under the microscope. Nocardia can resemble Actinomyces species on gram stain.  However, Nocardia is an obligate aerobe that stains weakly positive on acid-fast staining.

 

Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a “beaded” appearance on acid-fast staining. Nocardia is catalase-positive and urease positive.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli are acid fast but non-branching

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae bacilli are less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus; therefore, 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

 

Option D. Actinomyces are gram-positive but non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

 

The following image shows the filamentous gram-positive stained actinomyces:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia can be identified by its branching filamentous structure on gram stain and weak acid-fast positivity due to the presence of mycolic acid in its cell wall, distinguishing it from other gram-positive and acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: Match the following drugs in Column A with their contraindications in Column B? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

  • Morphine is contraindicated in head injury due to the following reasons:
    • It causes miosis and in patients with head injury who are in a comatose state, the progress of the patient after giving drugs is assessed by pupillary reaction. So, if the pupil already remains constricted due to morphine, the assessment of progress cannot be done.
    • Morphine leads to respiratory depression and if in the patients with head injury, if the respiratory rate is already depressed, it will get aggravated.
    • Respiratory depression will lead to accumulation of CO2, leading to vasodilatation and increased intracranial pressure.
  • Amiodarone can cause QT prolongation and even precipitate Torsade de pointes.
  • Vigabatrin is contraindicated in pregnancy as it is teratogenic.
  • Estrogen preparations are known to increase the risk of thromboembolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Morphine is contraindicated in head injury due to its effects on pupil size and respiratory depression. Amiodarone is associated with QT prolongation and potential arrhythmias. Vigabatrin is teratogenic and contraindicated in pregnancy. Estrogen increases the risk of thromboembolic events.

choices.text: Loss of knee jerk
Reduced muscle tone

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia is started on magnesium sulfate. What is the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of knee jerk

 

  • Therapeutic range: The therapeutic range of magnesium for the prevention of seizures in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L.
  • Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs): The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of DTRs, specifically the knee jerk reflex. This occurs when plasma magnesium levels reach 7-10 mEq/L.
  • Respiratory depression: When plasma magnesium levels reach 10-12 mEq/L, respiratory depression occurs. Beyond 12 mEq/L, respiratory paralysis and respiratory arrest can occur.
  • Cardiac arrest: Cardiac arrest can happen if serum magnesium levels exceed 25 mEq/L.
  • Monitoring: A patient on magnesium sulfate is monitored for toxicity by checking clinical signs, including DTRs, urine output, and respiratory rate.
  • Treatment of toxicity: Treatment for magnesium sulfate toxicity involves administering calcium gluconate or calcium chloride (1g intravenously) and discontinuing magnesium sulfate, which usually reverses mild to moderate respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypotension: Hypotension is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity.

 

Option C. Respiratory depression: Respiratory depression occurs at higher magnesium levels (10-12 mEq/L), after the loss of knee jerk reflex.

 

Option D. Reduced muscle tone: Reduced muscle tone is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity and is less specific than the loss of DTRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of deep tendon reflexes (knee jerk).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition page 759

choices.text: Topically applied sulfonamide antibacterial
Topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
Opioid receptor agonist

questions.text: Dorzolamide is a: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

 

Dorzolamide is a topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It helps in decreasing the rate of formation of aqueous humor in the eye, therefore useful in the management of glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topically applied sulfonamide antibacterial agents include silver sulfadiazine, Mafenide acetate, sulfacetamide etc.

 

Option C. Second-Generation Sulfonylureas are oral antidiabetic agents which act via increasing sensitivity of the insulin receptors and stimulate the release of insulin from the pancreas. It is used to manage type-2 diabetes mellitus. It includes Glipizide, Glyburide etc.

 

Option D. Opioid receptor agonist is the class of drugs which bind to the opioid receptors in the body. It includes Morphine, Pethidine, Fentanyl etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dorzolamide is a topical ocular carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing the production of aqueous humor, making it effective in the treatment of glaucoma. This distinguishes it from sulfonamide antibacterials, second-generation sulfonylureas, and opioid receptor agonists, which are used for different medical conditions.

choices.text: Sporothrix schenckii
Staphylococcus aureus
Nocardia asteroides

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Although Staphylococcus aureus can cause various skin infections, including cellulitis, abscesses, and impetigo, it does not typically spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics in the characteristic pattern of lymphocutaneous spread. Staphylococcus aureus usually causes localized infections.

 

Other Options

 

Organisms that can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Causes sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener's disease," which presents with nodular lymphangitis, characterized by lesions following the lymphatic drainage.

 

Option C. Nocardia asteroides: Nocardiosis can present with cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions that spread along lymphatics, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes swimming pool granuloma or fish tank granuloma, presenting with skin lesions that spread along lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective

 

While Sporothrix schenckii, Nocardia asteroides, and Mycobacterium marinum are known to spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, causing lymphocutaneous lesions, Staphylococcus aureus typically causes localized skin infections and does not exhibit this pattern of spread.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin like hands, arms, chest, etc. She also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-dsDNA antibodies

 

The patient exhibits symptoms including erythematous lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin, arthralgia, and breathlessness, which are characteristic of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). The rash described is typical of an SLE rash and not dermatomyositis, which presents with rashes over the knuckles known as Gottron's papules.

 

For diagnosing SLE, anti-dsDNA antibodies are very useful due to their high specificity. Although their sensitivity is relatively low (30-50%), the specificity is very high (>90-95%), making them reliable markers for confirming the diagnosis of SLE. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are also associated with disease activity in SLE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antihistone antibodies: These are primarily associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus, not classic SLE.

 

Option C. Anticentromere antibodies: These are typically seen in limited forms of scleroderma, particularly CREST syndrome, and are not associated with SLE.

 

Option D. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): While ANA is a good initial screening test for SLE due to its high sensitivity, it lacks specificity. ANA can be positive in a variety of autoimmune conditions, thus it is not as specific as anti-dsDNA antibodies for diagnosing SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for diagnosing Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), despite their moderate sensitivity.

questions.text:
Arrange the cells according to their positions from the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules? (INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Spermatogonia

2. Primary spermatocyte

3. Spermatid

4. Spermatozoa

5. Myoepithelial cell
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 5,1,2,3,4

 

From the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules, the cells are arranged in the order of:

 

  • Myoepithelial cells
  • Spermatogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Spermatozoa

 

In the seminiferous tubules, cells are organized in a specific sequence from the basal layer towards the lumen as part of the spermatogenesis process. The order reflects the developmental stages of sperm cells:

 

5. Myoepithelial cells: These cells, located at the basal layer, support the structure and function of the seminiferous tubules.

 

1. Spermatogonia: These are the stem cells located just above the basal membrane, which undergo mitotic divisions to produce more spermatogonia or differentiate into primary spermatocytes.

 

2. Primary spermatocytes:  Situated above the spermatogonia, these cells undergo meiosis I to form secondary spermatocytes.

 

3. Spermatid: Derived from the secondary spermatocytes after meiosis II, these cells are closer to the lumen and undergo spermiogenesis to become spermatozoa.

 

4. Spermatozoa: These are the final, mature male gametes that are nearest to the lumen of the tubule, ready to be released into the reproductive tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

From the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules, the cells are arranged in the order of:

 

  • Myoepithelial cells
  • Spermatogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Spermatozoa

questions.text: Based on the image, a 60-year-old male patient with diabetes presents with progressive skin lesions. What could be the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

The image above displays a central rodent ulcer, which indicates basal cell carcinoma. This malignant tumor exhibits characteristics of slow local invasion and mainly affects the pilosebaceous skin.

 

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC):

 

  • The most significant predisposing factor for basal cell carcinoma is exposure to ultraviolet radiation. Other risk factors include ionizing radiation, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and arsenic exposure.
  • Basal cell carcinoma predominantly affects middle-aged or elderly men with a history of excessive sun exposure, often among individuals with white skin, aged between 40 to 80 years.

 

Morphologically, basal cell carcinoma can be of 2 types:

 

1. Localized types: These are more common and include:

 

  • Nodular and nodulocystic BCC: Representing the majority of cases, these appear as pearly, waxy nodules with rolled borders and sometimes central ulceration or depression, known as umbilication.

 

 

  • Pigmented BCC: These are similar to nodular BCC but contain melanin, giving them a darker appearance.
  • Nevoid BCC: This type is rarer and can resemble benign moles.

 

2. Generalized types: These are less common and can be more challenging to treat due to their growth patterns:

 

  • Superficial multifocal and spreading BCC: Often appearing as scaly, erythematous patches that can be mistaken for eczema or psoriasis.
  • Infiltrative BCC: These grow more aggressively and can invade deeper tissues.
  • Cicatrizing (or sclerosing) BCC: This type can cause scarring as it grows.

 

While nodular BCC is the most common form, it is important for medical practitioners to recognize the less common types due to their growth patterns and potential for tissue destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

 

  • It typically presents as a firm, red nodule or a flat sore with a scaly crust as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • While it's possible for diabetic patients to develop SCC, the description provided fits BCC more closely.

 

Option C. Melasma

 

  • It is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is usually seen on the face.
  • It is more common in women, especially during pregnancy, and is not typically associated with progressive lesions.

 

Option D. Discoid lupus erythematosus

 

  • It often presents as a chronic rash with red, inflamed, and scaly patches that can cause scarring, usually on the face, ears, and scalp, as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is an autoimmune condition and not directly linked to diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient, progressive pearly or waxy skin lesions, especially if located on sun-exposed areas, are likely indicative of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 4.15, 51.3, 88.10-12, 141.1-16

Robbins basic pathology 10th edition page no 1148

Bailey & Loves short practice of surgery 27th edition Page no 599, 604-6011

questions.text: Which of the following suture materials is commonly used in neurosurgery and microsurgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nylon

 

Nylon is a non-absorbable suture material and is commonly used in neurosurgery, microsurgery, and ophthalmic surgery due to its low tissue reaction and high tensile strength.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polyglactin: Polyglactin (Vicryl) is an absorbable braided suture material and is commonly used in general surgical practices for gut anastomoses, vascular ligatures, subcuticular wound closures, and ophthalmic surgery.

 

Option C. Polypropylene 1-0 & Option D. Polypropylene 2-0: Polypropylene is a non-absorbable suture material and is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair. Polypropylene 1-0 and 2-0 refer to the size or diameter of the suture, with 1-0 being larger than 2-0. These sutures are too thick to be used in microsurgery.

 

Therefore, options B, C, and D are incorrect as they do not match the given description.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
Acute myeloid leukemia
Chronic myelogenous leukemia

questions.text: The given peripheral smear is associated with which of the following leukemias? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

 

The peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

The blood contains large numbers of small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells are usually disrupted in the process of making smears, producing so-called smudge cells. Lymphocytes are of same size and configuration with a uniform appearance called as "convent-girl" appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL): The peripheral smear in ALL typically shows a high number of lymphoblasts, which are larger than normal lymphocytes and have a high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio. There would be an absence of smudge cells, which are characteristic of CLL.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): AML is characterized by the presence of myeloblasts in the peripheral blood smear. These cells are larger, have more cytoplasm, and may contain Auer rods. Again, smudge cells are not a feature of AML.

 

Option D. Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML): The peripheral smear in CML shows a full spectrum of myeloid cells, from myeloblasts to mature neutrophils, often with an increase in basophils and eosinophils. Smudge cells are not a characteristic finding in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains
Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation

questions.text: 2,3 BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues because:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation:

 

Option C. Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation: This is the correct explanation. 2,3 BPG binds to a specific site in hemoglobin's central cavity, which is surrounded by histidine and lysine residues. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, favoring the release of oxygen molecules from hemoglobin into the surrounding tissues. The formation of salt bridges as a result of this binding contributes to the release of oxygen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not directly affect ATP production or break links between globin chains.

 

Option B. It increases ATP production: This statement is not correct. 2,3 BPG is not involved in ATP production.

 

Option D. Inhibits Taut structure formation: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not inhibit the formation of the Taut structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production
  • 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) plays a crucial role in regulating oxygen delivery by binding to deoxyhemoglobin and stabilizing the T (taut) state, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thereby promoting oxygen unloading to tissues.

 

 

  • When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.

choices.text: Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction is given sildenafil. Which of the following mediates the action of sildenafil? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. cGMP

 

  • Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitor.
  • The corpus cavernosum produces nitric oxide during arousal that stimulates the formation of cGMP. cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle of the corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, engorgement of the corpus cavernosum, and erection.
  • By inhibiting PDE 5, the hydrolysis if cGMP is prevented, thus leading to erection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: cAMP (cyclic adenosine monophosphate) is another second messenger involved in various biological processes, but it is not the primary mediator in the mechanism of action of sildenafil for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium plays a critical role in muscle contraction and various cellular functions, but it is not directly involved in the mechanism of action of sildenafil for treating erectile dysfunction.

 

Option D. Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate: These molecules are involved in different signaling pathways, such as the phosphatidylinositol pathway, but they are not relevant to the action of sildenafil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sildenafil, a PDE5 inhibitor, enhances and prolongs erections by preventing the breakdown of cGMP, which is the primary mediator responsible for smooth muscle relaxation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis during arousal.

questions.text: Match the following teratogenic drugs with their teratogenic effects: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

The correctly matched pairs of teratogenic drugs and their effects is 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a.

 

  1. Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorders and prophylaxis of mania. It is c/I in pregnancy as it leads to Ebstein’s anomaly in the fetus, which is characterised by arterialization of the right ventricle and a box shaped heart.
  2. Warfarin leads to defect in the growth of the cartilage (chondrodysplasia punctata) characterized by depressed nasal bridge, stippled epiphyses etc. Warfarin embryopathy is maximally seen when it is used between 6-9 weeks.
  3. Thalidomide causes proximal limb defect or Phocomelia. Thalidomide acts via inhibiting angio-genesis, inhibiting cereblon and suppressing immune responses.
  4. Chloramphenicol inhibits peptidyl transferase. It causes Bone Marrow suppression and leads to grey baby syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The teratogenic effects of certain drugs is crucial for managing medication use during pregnancy. Lithium can cause Ebstein’s anomaly, Warfarin is associated with saddle nose and growth retardation, Thalidomide causes limb malformations, and Chloramphenicol can lead to Grey Baby Syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior gluteal artery

 

  • Origin: The inferior gluteal artery is typically a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, usually below the piriformis muscle. It supplies the gluteal muscles (mainly gluteus maximus), and also gives off branches that participate in anastomoses around the hip joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iliolumbar Artery

 

  • Origin: This arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It ascends posteriorly to supply the iliacus muscle, the iliac bone, and the lumbosacral region. Its branches also participate in anastomoses with the lumbar arteries.

 

Option B. Lateral Sacral Artery

 

  • Origin: This too arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: Generally, there are two lateral sacral arteries (superior and inferior) that descend to supply the sacrum and coccyx. They anastomose with the median sacral artery and with each other. Some branches of the lateral sacral arteries also supply the meninges of the sacral part of the spinal cord.

 

Option D. Superior Gluteal Artery

 

  • Origin: This artery arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, usually above the piriformis muscle. It supplies the gluteal muscles and also contributes to the anastomotic network around the hip joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

 

  1. Vaginal artery (in females)
  2. Uterine artery (in females)
  3. Inferior vesical artery (in males) or vaginal artery (in females): supplies the urinary bladder and reproductive organs.
  4. Middle rectal artery: supplies the rectum and anal canal.
  5. Internal pudendal artery: supplies the perineum, external genitalia, and the lower anal canal.
  6. Obturator artery: supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh, external genitalia, and the hip joint.
  7. Inferior gluteal artery: supplies the muscles of the gluteal region.
  8. Superior vesical artery: supplies the urinary bladder and the vas deferens.

choices.text: This action can be reversed by phenylephrine.
﻿﻿﻿It cannot be reversed by levallorphan.
﻿﻿﻿It is caused by activation of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.
﻿﻿﻿Tolerance develops to this adverse effect on long-term use.

questions.text: A patient with a history of substance addiction is admitted to the hospital due to the overdose of the addictive substance. The patient has slow heart rate, respiratory depression, and low blood pressure. His ocular findings are shown below. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is caused by activation of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.
 

The pupil is constricted in the given image and as the history describes the patient to be an addict, who is brought to the hospital in an intoxicated state. The clinical features like pin-point pupils, bradycardia, hypotension, respiratory depression suggests that this is a case of opioid intoxication.


Opioid induced miosis:

 

  • The pupillary constriction caused by opioids result due to the activation of the Edinger Westphal Nucleus. Therefore, topical use of opioids in the eye does not induce miosis. It will be seen only on systemic administration of opioids.
  • The miosis induced by opioids cannot be reversed by mydriatic drugs like phenylephrine or anticholinergic drugs. Rather it can be reversed by opioid antagonists like naloxone and levallorphan.
  • Tolerance does not develop to opioid induced miosis even on long term use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. This action can be reversed by phenylephrine: Phenylephrine is a mydriatic agent that causes dilation of the pupil by stimulating alpha-1 adrenergic receptors. It would not reverse opioid-induced miosis, which is due to central nervous system effects rather than direct effects on the iris muscles.

 

Option B. It cannot be reversed by levallorphan: Levallorphan is an opioid antagonist that can reverse the effects of opioid toxicity, including miosis. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option D. Tolerance develops to this adverse effect on long-term use: Tolerance to opioid-induced miosis does not typically develop, even with long-term use of opioids. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opioid-induced miosis is caused by activation of the Edinger-Westphal nucleus, and it is a characteristic sign of opioid intoxication. This effect cannot be reversed by phenylephrine, and tolerance does not develop to this effect with long-term opioid use. Opioid antagonists like naloxone and levallorphan can reverse the miosis caused by opioid overdose

questions.text:
Identify the incorrectly matched pair(s) of pharyngeal arch and its artery?

 

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery
  3. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery
  4. 4th arch - Subclavian artery
  5. 6th arch - Aorta on the left side
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. v

 

Explanation

 

All the given pairs of pharyngeal arteries and their arteries are correctly matched except for 'v' (option C).

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch has its blood supply on the left side from the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus, not from the aorta.

 

Other options

 

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery: Correct. The maxillary artery is indeed a derivative of the first pharyngeal arch.
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery: Correct. The hyoid artery (or the stapedial artery in its embryonic context) is derived from the second pharyngeal arch.
  3. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery: Correct. The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to portions of the common carotid artery and the proximal part of the internal carotid artery.
  4. 4th arch - Subclavian artery: Correct on the right side. The fourth pharyngeal arch is associated with the development of the right subclavian artery and part of the aortic arch on the left side.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, with a smoking history of 20 pack years, presented in OPD with breathlessness and chest pain. Further investigations revealed a lung tumor. On staining, cells are positive for chromogranin. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Small cell carcinoma 

 

History of chronic smoking and lung tumor cells staining positive for chromogranin suggests small cell carcinoma of the lung.

 

SMALL CELL CARCINOMAS:

 

  1. This highly malignant tumor has a distinctive cell type.
  2. Strongly associated with cigarette smoking
  3. This lung cancer type is most commonly associated with ectopic hormone production
  4. Electron microscopy shows
    • Dense-core neurosecretory granules are present along the bronchial epithelium which can secrete polypeptide hormones
    • Presence of neuroendocrine markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD57 (in 75% of cases) and parathormone-like and other hormonally active products suggest derivation of this tumor from neuroendocrine progenitor cells of the lining bronchial epithelium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenocarcinoma: This is the most common subtype of lung cancer, especially in non-smokers, and it typically involves peripheral lung lesions. It is characterized by markers like TTF-1, NAPSIN-A, and CEA, rather than chromogranin.

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type is also associated with smoking but is more likely to present centrally in the lungs. It shows keratinization and intercellular bridges on histology and is associated with markers like p40 and p63, not chromogranin.

 

Option C. Large cell carcinoma: This diagnosis is typically a diagnosis of exclusion and does not have a specific marker like chromogranin. It is also more common in non-smokers and presents as a peripheral tumor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure tone audiometry
  2. Tympanometry
  3. Free field audiometry
  4. Speech audiometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

When otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are absent, it indicates a potential cochlear pathology, specifically affecting the outer hair cells. Further testing is required to assess the extent and nature of hearing loss, as well as to rule out any retrocochlear pathology.

 

2. Tympanometry: This test assesses the condition of the middle ear and tympanic membrane mobility by creating variations in air pressure in the ear canal. It is useful to determine if the absence of OAEs might be related to middle ear issues, such as fluid, which can mask cochlear function.

 

4. Speech Audiometry: This test evaluates the ability to understand speech and also provides information about the clarity of speech perception. It helps to determine the speech recognition threshold and is crucial for diagnosing the degree and type of hearing loss when OAEs are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure Tone Audiometry: While this test is crucial for determining the threshold levels of hearing and the degree of hearing loss across different frequencies, it was not specified as one of the correct responses in this context.

 

3. Free Field Audiometry: Generally used for young children or individuals who cannot reliably use headphones, this test measures hearing sensitivity to sounds presented in an open field. However, it requires a controlled sound field, which is not always practical for immediate follow-up when OAEs are absent.

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 29

questions.text: An old lady sustained a fall and developed a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later. What is your diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subdural hematoma

 

The given clinical scenario of an elderly individual experiencing a headache and neurological symptoms following a fall is highly suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH). Subdural hematomas occur due to bleeding between the arachnoid membrane and the dura mater, which typically results from the rupture of bridging veins. These veins are more prone to injury in elderly patients due to brain atrophy, which increases the distance the veins need to traverse.

 

Elderly individuals, alcoholics, and patients on anticoagulant therapy are at higher risk for developing subdural hematomas. Often, these injuries are triggered by even minor or trivial trauma.

 

A non-contrast CT scan is the preferred diagnostic modality for detecting a subdural hematoma. On CT imaging, acute SDH appears hyperdense (bright), while chronic SDH appears hypodense (dark).

 

Key features of subdural hematomas on CT include:

 

  • Crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) appearance.
  • Hemorrhage may spread across suture lines (unlike epidural hematomas).
  • Typically unilateral (85% of cases).

 

If the subdural hematoma is large (>1 cm), causes a midline shift >5 mm, or there is a neurological decline (e.g., a drop in Glasgow Coma Scale by two or more points), surgical intervention (craniotomy) is indicated for evacuation of the hematoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multi-infarct dementia (MID): MID is a type of vascular dementia that occurs due to multiple small infarctions or strokes, often leading to cognitive decline and memory loss. This type of dementia is common in the elderly, but it is not associated with trauma or sudden neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe meningioma: Meningiomas are benign brain tumors that arise from the meninges. They usually grow slowly and can cause progressive symptoms depending on their location. Frontal lobe tumors may result in personality changes and cognitive decline but are not related to trauma.

 

Option C. Korsakoff syndrome: Korsakoff syndrome is a memory disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, most commonly seen in alcoholics. It primarily affects the ability to form new memories (anterograde amnesia) and may be accompanied by confabulation. However, this condition is not typically linked to traumatic injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subdural hematoma is caused by the rupture of bridging veins between the dura and arachnoid mater, often due to minor trauma in the elderly or patients on anticoagulants. Diagnosis is confirmed through a non-contrast CT scan, and surgical intervention is required in severe cases with significant mass effect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with Graves' disease with eye signs and enlarged thyroid is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. What medication can be administered in the preoperative period to minimize intraoperative bleeding in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Potassium iodide

 

Potassium iodide, which can be given 10 days before the surgery to reduce intraoperative bleeding during total thyroidectomy. This is because iodide alone produces transient remission and may reduce vascularity, thereby marginally improving safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used to prepare the patient for surgery by inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and causing beta-adrenergic blockade. However, it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding during thyroidectomy. It is beneficial in thyroid storm.

 

Option C. Propylthiouracil: Propylthiouracil is an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid synthesis and peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. It is used to render the patient euthyroid before surgery, but it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Option D. Betamethasone: Betamethasone is a glucocorticoid that reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. However, it is not used preoperatively in thyroidectomy to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in an overactive thyroid gland, known as hyperthyroidism. In this condition, the immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing it to produce more thyroid hormone than the body needs. As a result, the thyroid gland becomes hyperactive, leading to various symptoms associated with hyperthyroidism. Graves' disease is the most prevalent cause of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is _______. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is follicular conjunctivitis.

 

Other ocular symptoms associated with COVID-19 include:

 

  • Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis
  • Dry eye disease
  • Episcleritis
  • Chemosis
  • Photophobia

 

However, these occur less frequently. The most prevalent ocular symptoms reported by COVID-19 patients are dry eye or foreign body sensation, along with redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.

 

Severe intraocular complications can include:

 

  • Retinal artery occlusions
  • Hemorrhages
  • Cotton-wool spots (caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy)

 

The ACE-2 receptors present in the cornea and conjunctiva make the ocular surface a potential target tissue for SARS-CoV-2 infection.

 

Sometimes, conjunctivitis may be the only symptom of COVID-19, highlighting the need for patients with these signs to undergo nasopharyngeal RT-PCR testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uveitis: Uveitis is an inflammation of the uveal tract and is not a common manifestation in COVID-19 patients. While viral infections can cause uveitis, it is much less common than conjunctivitis in COVID-19 cases.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: Mucormycosis (commonly referred to as "black fungus") is a secondary fungal infection seen in immunocompromised COVID-19 patients, particularly those with uncontrolled diabetes or those treated with steroids. It is not considered a primary ocular manifestation of COVID-19 itself.

 

Option D. Papillary conjunctivitis: Papillary conjunctivitis, characterized by large papillae in the conjunctiva, is not the most common type of conjunctivitis seen in COVID-19. Follicular conjunctivitis is more frequently associated with viral infections like COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is follicular conjunctivitis. Patients with conjunctivitis as the sole symptom of COVID-19 should be tested with nasopharyngeal RT-PCR, as ocular involvement can be an early or even sole indicator of SARS-CoV-2 infection.

questions.text:
Which of the following equipment is required for putting intravenous cannula in a newborn?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. 22G cannula

  2. 24G IV cannula

  3. 5-mL syringe

  4. Adhesive tape

  5. Normal saline
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2,3,4,5

 

Explanation:

 

2. 24G IV cannula: This refers to a 24-gauge (24G) cannula, which is typically used for neonates and infants due to its smaller diameter, making it suitable for their small and fragile veins.

3. 5-mL syringe: While placing an IV cannula, it's essential to have a syringe attached. The syringe helps to test the patency of the cannula once it's in the vein (flashback of blood can be seen), and it also assists in gently flushing the cannula with normal saline to ensure it's correctly positioned.

4. Adhesive tape: Once the cannula is in position, adhesive tape or a securement device is necessary to stabilize and fix the cannula in place, preventing it from dislodging.

5. Normal saline: Normal saline is used for flushing the cannula once it's in place to ensure patency. It's also utilized to keep the cannula patent if it's not immediately hooked up to an IV line.

 

Other Option:

 

1. 22G IV cannula: A 22-gauge (22G) cannula is larger and may be used for older infants or children but is often too large for a newborn's tiny veins. Hence, it is not typically used for neonates.

 

Educational Objective :

 

For placing an IV cannula in a newborn, the equipment required includes a 24G needle, a 5-mL syringe, adhesive tape, and normal saline.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the targets of their actions: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1
 

  • Trastuzumab is used in HER2/neu positive breast cancers.
  • Infliximab is anti-TNFα monoclonal antibody used in the management of Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Sirolimus acts by inhibiting the progression of cell cycle from G1 to S phase by blocking mTOR. It is used in the prevention of transplant rejection.
  • Imatinib is a BCR-ABL inhibitor that is used in the treatment of CML.
     

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with left-sided hemiparesis. Damage to which part of the internal capsule leads to this presentation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior limb

 

The internal capsule is a white matter structure in the brain that contains many important tracts, including those for motor and sensory functions. Damage to specific parts of the internal capsule can result in different clinical presentations based on the fibers that are affected.

 

Posterior limb is the part of the internal capsule that carries corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, which are responsible for motor and sensory functions. Damage to the posterior limb can result in contralateral hemiparesis (weakness on the opposite side of the body). Therefore, a lesion in the posterior limb of the right internal capsule would lead to left-sided hemiparesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: This part of the internal capsule contains optic radiations, which are involved in visual processing. Damage here would lead to visual deficits rather than motor or sensory deficits.

 

Option B. Sublentiform: This part carries auditory radiations and is involved in hearing. Damage to this part would result in auditory deficits, not motor weakness.

 

Option C. Anterior limb: This part of the internal capsule contains frontopontine fibers and thalamocortical radiations, which are involved in cognitive and executive functions. Damage here might affect cognition but not typically result in hemiparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule can lead to contralateral hemiparesis due to the involvement of motor and sensory pathways.

questions.text: An anti-arrhythmic drug, which is effective in both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias, is shown to have the following effect on action potential. Which of the following is the most likely drug? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. Quinidine

 

  • Quinidine and procainamide are class IA anti-arrhythmic agents. These blocks Na+ channel along with potassium channel as well. This increases action potential duration (APD), which leads to QT prolongation.

     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tocainide: Tocainide is a Class IB anti-arrhythmic drug. These drugs block Na+ channels and open K+ channels, reducing the slope of phase 4 of the action potential. This effect shortens the action potential duration.

 

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-receptor blocker and a Class II anti-arrhythmic. It works primarily by inhibiting sympathetic input to the heart, reducing heart rate, and decreasing the force of contraction. It does not directly affect the action potential duration in the same way as Class I drugs.

 

Option D. Lignocaine: Lignocaine (Lidocaine) is a Class IB anti-arrhythmic drug. It shortens the action potential duration by blocking Na+ channels and opening K+ channels. This effect is the opposite of what is shown in the graph.

 

Note –

 

Class 1c agents like Flecainide and Encainide block sodium channels with no action on potassium channel. The image below illustrates the action potential changes when a class 1c anti-arrhythmic is used.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class IA anti-arrhythmic agents like Quinidine prolong the action potential duration by blocking sodium and potassium channels, making them effective in treating both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. This effect is clearly reflected in the graph provided, distinguishing it from other classes of anti-arrhythmic drugs.

questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is caused by which of the following deletion? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylalanine at 508

 

  • Correct. Cystic fibrosis is primarily caused by the deletion of Phenylalanine at position 508 in the CFTR gene. This mutation leads to a malfunctioning CFTR protein, which results in the characteristic symptoms of cystic fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine at 508: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Tyrosine at position 508. The critical deletion is of Phenylalanine at this position.

 

Option C. Tryptophan at 508: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Tryptophan at position 508. The deletion of Phenylalanine at this position is the key mutation associated with cystic fibrosis.

 

Option D. Lysine at 805: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Lysine at position 805. The F508del mutation is the most common and well-known mutation in cystic fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis is due to mutation in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein by deletion of one codon which give rise to phenylalanine at position 508 of this protein. Mnemonic: F-fibrosis, F- Phenylalaine

 

This protein helps in movement of H2O and chloride ion in and out of cell and helps in the formation of mucus secretion and saliva.

 

In normal conditions, the channel allows the formation of thin layer of mucus. But in cystic fibrosis, a thick layer of mucus is formed (see fig) causing airway obstruction leading to infection and ultimately scarring of lung tissue.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presented in OPD with complaints of fever, night sweats, and weight loss for 2 months. On examination, lymphadenopathy was present. They were non-tender, rubbery in consistency, located in the supraclavicular and inguinal regions on both sides. Peripheral smear showed the presence of bi-nucleated cells. Which markers can be identified in this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. CD15
  2. CD30
  3. CD19
  4. CD3
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

Clinical history and the histopathological examination showing bi-nucleated cells, called Reed Sternberg cells points to a diagnosis of Hodgkins lymphoma. RS cells are CD 15+ and CD30+.

 

Reed-Sternberg cells marker –

 

  • CDI5
  • CD30 (most sensitive)
  • PAX-5 (most SPECIFIC)

 

 

Reed Sternberg Cells are non-specific since it is seen in conditions like:

 

  • Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Non- Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Infection Mononucleosis
  • Sarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

CD19 (3) and CD3 (4): These markers are associated with B and T cells, respectively. CD19 is a B-cell marker, and CD3 is a T-cell marker. They are not typically associated with Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Hodgkin's lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells characteristically express CD15 and CD30, making these markers essential for diagnosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Stellate cells
  2. Basket cells
  3. Purkinje cells
  4. Granular cells
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum contains stellate and basket cells.

 

The molecular layer is the outermost layer of the cerebellar cortex. It includes:

 

  • Stellate cells and basket cells: These cells receive excitatory input from parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on Purkinje cells.
  • The dendrites of Purkinje cells: Although Purkinje cells themselves are not in this layer, their dendrites extend into the molecular layer.

 

This layer contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers, giving it a pale appearance on H&E staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1, 3: Purkinje cells are located in the Purkinje layer, not the molecular layer. The dendrites of Purkinje cells extend into the molecular layer, but the cell bodies reside in the middle layer of the cerebellum.

 

Option C. 2, 4: Granular cells are located in the granular layer (innermost layer), not the molecular layer. The granular layer contains the cell bodies of granular cells and Golgi cells.

 

Option D. 2, 3: Purkinje cells are in the Purkinje layer, while basket cells are in the molecular layer. Therefore, this combination is incorrect because Purkinje cells are not present in the molecular layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum contains stellate cells and basket cells that form inhibitory synapses on Purkinje cells. Purkinje cells are located in their own middle layer, and granular cells reside in the innermost granular layer.

questions.text: On Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining oocysts of size 8-10 µm cysts are visible. Identify the organism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclospora

 

Cyclospora cayetanensis is a coccidian parasite that causes the gastrointestinal disease cyclosporiasis. The organism produces oocysts that are 8-10 µm in diameter, which can be detected by Ziehl-Neelsen staining. The oocysts exhibit a variable acid-fast staining property and can also autofluoresce under ultraviolet light.

 

Cyclospora oocysts have the following characteristics:

 

  • Size: 8-10 µm in diameter.
  • Staining: They show variable acid-fast staining.
  • Autofluorescence: They exhibit blue-green autofluorescence under ultraviolet light.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Isospora: Isospora (now known as Cystoisospora) produces larger oocysts, typically 20-30 µm in size, and contains two sporocysts with four sporozoites each. It does not match the 8-10 µm size described.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are smaller, measuring 4-6 µm in diameter, and consistently exhibit acid-fast staining and bright auramine fluorescence. They do not match the size range described.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are a group of spore-forming unicellular parasites that do not fit the description of having 8-10 µm oocysts visible with Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text:
The following are parvovirus-related manifestations. Identify the incorrect pair? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia
  2. Polymyalgia rheumatica - young women
  3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women
  4. Erythema infectiosum - infants
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2

 

Polymyalgia rheumatica is closely associated with giant cell arteritis in women above 50yrs.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia: Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, particularly in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia. The virus affects erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia in these patients.

 

3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe fetal complications, including hydrops fetalis, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by severe edema in the fetus.

 

4. Erythema infectiosum - infants: Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease, is a common manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection in young children, not just infants. It presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polymyalgia rheumatica is typically seen in women above 50 years old and is not related to parvovirus infection in young women. Parvovirus B19 is more commonly associated with conditions such as erythema infectiosum in children, pure red cell aplasia in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia, and hydrops fetalis in pregnant women.

 

Additional Information

 

Parvo virus infection -

 

Common symptoms of parvovirus B19 (B19V) infection include a mild nonspecific prodromal illness that may consist of fever (15-30% of patients), malaise, headache, myalgia, nausea, and rhinorrhea; typically beginning 5-7 days after initial infection

 

A diffuse maculopapular rash can appear 1-4 days later and fades to a lacy erythematous rash, which may be pruritic and may spread gradually toward the distal extremities. Most seropositive patients have no history of this classic biphasic illness. The clinical symptoms widely vary, and the classic "slapped cheek" rash is much more common in young children called as erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease,

 

 

Alternatively, parvovirus B19 infection may manifest with purpuric rash, erythema multiforme, or pruritus of the soles of the feet. Parvovirus B19 may cause a papular-purpuric "gloves-and-socks" syndrome (PPGSS), which manifests as an erythematous exanthem of the hands and feet with a distinct margin at the wrist and ankle joints.

 

Transient small joint arthropathy may be the main clinical presentation of parvovirus B19 in adults.

 

Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia is seen  in patients with immunosuppression.

 

Patients with severe anemia due to transient aplastic crisis (TAC) may present with pallor, fatigue, or signs of an aplastic crisis.

 

Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss.

questions.text: What does the zero pressure indicate in the pressure-volume curve? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

 

The pressure-volume curve represents the relationship between the lung volumes and the transpulmonary pressures. Zero pressure in this context usually refers to the point where the pressure inside the lungs is equal to the atmospheric pressure, indicating a state of no net airflow. This point corresponds to the functional residual capacity (FRC), which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation.

 

  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC): It is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. This capacity includes the expiratory reserve volume (ERV) and the residual volume (RV). FRC is an important measure because it represents the balance point between the elastic recoil forces of the lungs and the chest wall.

 

 

The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. The normal value is about 2.5 liters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Residual volume is the air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort.

 

Option C: Tidal volume is the amount of air that moves in during each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration, during quiet breathing.

 

Option D: Inspiratory reserve volume is the air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in addition to the tidal volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zero pressure in the pressure-volume curve indicates the functional residual capacity, which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation.

questions.text: Delayed hypersensitivity is due to? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

  • Delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) is a form of cell-mediated immune response that occurs typically 24-72 hours after exposure to the antigen. This response is primarily mediated by T-helper 1 (Th1) cells which secrete a variety of cytokines, including Interferon gamma (IFN-γ). IFN-γ is crucial in activating macrophages and enhancing their microbicidal activity, which is a key component of the DTH response. This type of hypersensitivity is important in defense against intracellular pathogens such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interleukin-2 (IL-2) - IL-2 is primarily involved in the activation and proliferation of T cells but is not the primary mediator of delayed hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option C. Interleukin-12 (IL-12) - IL-12 plays a role in the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells and can promote IFN-γ production, but it is not the direct mediator of DTH.

 

Option D. Interleukin-4 (IL-4) - IL-4 is associated with the differentiation of naive T cells into Th2 cells and promotes humoral immunity, which is not involved in delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interferon gamma is the key cytokine responsible for mediating delayed hypersensitivity reactions by activating macrophages and enhancing their pathogen-killing capabilities.

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Plasma contains various components like ions, inorganic and organic molecules that help in the transport of substances across various parts of the body, such as Albumin, globulin, and fibrinogen fractions.

 

  1. Thyroxine is carried by transthyretin, also called thyroid-binding pre-albumin.
  2. Fatty acids are carried by albumin, which is a major carrier protein and osmotic regulator. It also transports hormones, amino acids, vitamins, and steroids.
  3. Hemoglobin binds to haptoglobin, which prevents free hemoglobin from being excreted in the urine.
  4. Heme binds with hemopexin for heme recycling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasma transporters like prealbumin, albumin, haptoglobin, and hemopexin play crucial roles in the transport and recycling of thyroxine, fatty acids, hemoglobin, and heme respectively.

questions.text: Which among the following organs has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kidney

 

The arteriovenous oxygen difference (A-V O2 difference) is a measure of the amount of oxygen extracted by the tissues from the blood. The greater the oxygen utilization by the tissues, the larger the A-V O2 difference.

 

  • Kidney: The kidney has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference. This is because the primary function of the kidneys is to filter large volumes of blood through the glomeruli rather than to metabolize oxygen extensively. As a result, the oxygen extracted by the renal tissues is relatively low compared to the amount of blood flow, resulting in a low A-V O2 difference.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain: The brain has a higher arteriovenous oxygen difference due to its significant metabolic activity and oxygen consumption to support its functions. The brain requires a constant and substantial supply of oxygen for neuronal activity, resulting in a higher A-V O2 difference compared to the kidney.

 

Option C. Skin: The skin also has a relatively low oxygen consumption compared to organs like the brain and liver, but its arteriovenous oxygen difference is still higher than that of the kidney. The skin is primarily involved in protective functions and thermoregulation, requiring less oxygen.

 

Option D. Liver: The liver has a moderate to high arteriovenous oxygen difference due to its metabolic functions, including detoxification, synthesis of proteins, and other vital activities that require substantial oxygen consumption. The liver's metabolic demands make its A-V O2 difference higher than that of the kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The kidney has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference among the given organs due to its primary function of blood filtration, which requires relatively low oxygen extraction. This results in a low A-V O2 difference compared to organs like the brain and liver that have higher metabolic and oxygen consumption demands.

questions.text: All of the following can be used in first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

 

Explanation:

 

  • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate:
    • This method is typically used for second-trimester abortions. It involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space to induce abortion. However, it is rarely used nowadays due to advancements in other safer and more effective methods.
  • Medical methods of first-trimester abortion:
    • Mifepristone + misoprostol: A combination of mifepristone (a progesterone receptor antagonist) and misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) is a common and effective method for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy.
  • Surgical methods of first-trimester abortion:
    • Manual vacuum aspiration: This is a safe and effective method for terminating a pregnancy in the first trimester.
    • Dilatation and curettage: Another surgical method used to evacuate the contents of the uterus in the first trimester.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone + misoprostol: Mifepristone + misoprostol is a commonly used combination for medical termination in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Manual vacuum aspiration: Manual vacuum aspiration is a standard procedure for first-trimester abortion.

 

Option C. Dilatation and evacuation: Dilatation and evacuation is another method used in the first trimester to terminate a pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is not used for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg364,369, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg203

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Metastatic calcification except: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin D deficiency

 

Metastatic calcification is associated with Hypercalcemia (Vitamin D toxicity), not Vitamin D deficiency.

 

 

Tumors having Dystrophic calcification: Psammoma bodies present

 

M – Meningioma, Mesothelioma

 

O – Ovary (Serous cystadenoma)

 

S – Salivary gland tumor

 

T – Thyroid (Papillary thyroid cancer)

 

P – Prolactinoma

 

G – Glucagonoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal failure: Chronic kidney disease can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia, both of which contribute to hypercalcemia and subsequent metastatic calcification.

 

Option B. Accumulation of calcium phosphate: This typically occurs in the context of renal failure or parathyroid hormone-related issues, leading to metastatic calcification.

 

Option D Parathyroid activation secretion: Hyperparathyroidism, whether primary or secondary, causes an increase in serum calcium, leading to metastatic calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metastatic calcification is associated with conditions that lead to hypercalcemia, not with conditions that result in normal or low calcium levels, such as Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint.
  2. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus.
  3. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct.
  4. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2,3

 

Explanation:

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2: True. The buccal branch, which is indeed a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, emerges from behind the mandibular ramus. This nerve primarily supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the cheek and buccal mucosa.

 

Statement 3: True. The lingual nerve, a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It famously arcs around the submandibular duct, a notable anatomical feature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1: Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve actually arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, not the anterior division, and it does indeed emerge from behind the temporomandibular joint.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. The ophthalmic nerve is not a branch of the mandibular nerve. Instead, it is an independent division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), originating from the trigeminal ganglion located in the middle cranial fossa. It is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the forehead, scalp, and parts of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mandibular nerve's complex branching includes both sensory and motor components that are essential for facial sensation and movements. Understanding its branches, such as the buccal and lingual nerves, and their courses, is critical in dental, surgical, and diagnostic practices.

questions.text:
Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases causes increased pulmonary blood flow? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Ebstein anomaly
  2. Tetralogy of Fallot
  3. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
  4. Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4

 

Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC) are both cyanotic congenital heart diseases that cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

 

3. Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA): In TGA, the positions of the pulmonary artery and the aorta are switched, which results in deoxygenated blood being circulated throughout the body. The mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood occurs, leading to increased pulmonary blood flow because the deoxygenated blood is directed to the lungs.

 

4. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC): In TAPVC, the pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, they connect to the right atrium or systemic veins, causing a mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. This also leads to increased blood flow to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 4: Ebstein anomaly does not cause increased pulmonary blood flow. Ebstein anomaly involves downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, leading to decreased pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Both Ebstein anomaly and Tetralogy of Fallot cause decreased pulmonary blood flow. Tetralogy of Fallot includes pulmonary stenosis, which limits blood flow to the lungs.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Tetralogy of Fallot causes decreased pulmonary blood flow due to the presence of pulmonary stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyanotic congenital heart diseases such as Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) and Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC) cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: What is the cause of tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Unburnt particles  

 

  • Tattooing is a term used to describe the punctate abrasions observed when skin comes into contact with partially burned or unburned grains of gunpowder.
  • They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing
  • They are seen in near (30-50cm) to mid-range of shooting

 

Firearm injuries:

 

 

Blackening – due to deposit of smoke

 

 

 

Grease collar - due to the deposition of the lubricant of the bullet in the tissues

 

Burn injuries - occur due to flame released during the firing.

 

Other Options:
