Option B. Smoke: Causes blackening, not tattooing.

 

Option C. Impact: Refers to the force of the bullet causing tissue damage but does not explain tattooing.

 

Option D. Muzzle impression: Occurs when the muzzle of the firearm makes contact with the skin, leaving an impression, but does not cause tattooing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is caused by unburnt particles of gunpowder embedding into the skin.

questions.text: A female patient was clinically diagnosed to have hypothyroidism. Measurements of the following parameters were obtained: TSH; combined protein levels; and total and free T3, T4, and rT3. Which one of the following options represents her condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

Laboratory investigations in a patient with hypothyroidism would show low levels of total and free T3, T4, and rT3 with high TSH levels, and normal combined protein levels.

 

Normally, the hypothalamus releases thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH), which stimulates the pituitary gland to release thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). TSH then stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4. When thyroid hormone production is deficient (hypothyroidism), TSH levels rise in an attempt to stimulate the gland further.

 

  • Elevated TSH with low free T4 levels is indicative of primary hypothyroidism.
  • In contrast, secondary hypothyroidism (due to pituitary failure) would show low TSH and low T3/T4 levels.
  • Tertiary hypothyroidism (due to hypothalamic dysfunction) also results in low TSH and low T3/T4.

 

Patients with hypothyroidism typically present with fatigue, dry skin, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, bradycardia, and depression. Physical findings may include cool extremities, puffy face, and periorbital edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 (High T3, T4, and Low TSH): This combination suggests hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.

 

Option B. 2 (Low T3, T4, Normal TSH): This could indicate euthyroid sick syndrome rather than primary hypothyroidism.

 

Option C. 3 (High T3, T4, Normal TSH): This may represent conditions with normal thyroid function or thyroid hormone resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In primary hypothyroidism, you typically see low free T3 and T4 levels with elevated TSH. Proper diagnosis and management are crucial, and hypothyroidism is often treated with levothyroxine to normalize hormone levels.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents to the surgical emergency with a history of peptic ulcer disease and pain in abdomen, bloating, and obstipation for 3 days. What is the next line in management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Given scenario of history of peptic ulcer disease with acute abdomen suggests a peptic ulcer perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV fluids: Administering intravenous (IV) fluids is essential to address potential dehydration or peritonitis, to stabilise the patient.

 

Option B. CECT abdomen (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen): Performing a CECT abdomen is a diagnostic step that can help identify the cause of the patient's symptoms, such as complications related to peptic ulcer disease, including perforation or other abdominal pathologies.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: An exploratory laparotomy may be necessary if the patient's condition deteriorates or if there are signs of a surgical emergency, such as peritonitis or suspected perforation.

 

In summary, option D is correct because it covers the initial steps in managing this patient comprehensively, including addressing fluid balance (IV fluids), diagnostic imaging (CECT abdomen), and considering surgical intervention (exploratory laparotomy) if indicated by the clinical presentation and imaging findings

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perforation of a hollow viscus is a life-threatening condition caused by the rupture of the alimentary tract.
  • This results in the leakage of enteric contents, leading to acute bacterial peritonitis.
  • Clinical features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation.
  • Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm.
  • CECT is the most sensitive investigation to detect minimal/suspected pneumoperitoneum.
  • Management includes IV fluids and exploratory laparotomy.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of HIV is started on combined active antiretroviral therapy (cART). After few months of treatment, he develops palmo-plantar hyperpigmentation. What is the most likely drug implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Emtricitabine


Emtricitabine is an NRTI (Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor) which can lead to hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles.

 

Other options:


Option A. Nelfinavir is a protease inhibitor. It can cause diarrhea or loose stools, dyslipidemia, lipodystrophy and hyperlipidemia.


Option C. Abacavir is an NRTI that can lead to Steven Johnson Syndrome.


Option D. Zidovudine is an NRTI that can cause nail hyperpigmentation, bone marrow suppression, myopathy, hepatotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emtricitabine, an NRTI used in the treatment of HIV, is known to cause palmo-plantar hyperpigmentation as a side effect. This differentiates it from other antiretroviral medications such as nelfinavir, abacavir, and zidovudine, which have different side effect profiles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Mumbai presents to a clinic with fatigue and weakness. His family has a history of chronic diseases, but he himself has been asymptomatic until recently. The physician explains the different stages of disease progression and the interventions required. Which of the following best matches the stages with their relevant descriptions? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

  • Natural history of disease refers to the progression of a disease in an individual over time, in the absence of treatment. It has two phases, a period of pre-pathogenesis and a period of pathogenesis.

 

 

  • The period of pre-pathogenesis is before the onset of disease in humans.
  • An interaction between the agent, host and the environment occurs in this phase before the pathogenesis.
  • It starts with appropriate exposure to or accumulation of factors sufficient for the disease process to begin in a susceptible host.
  • The exposure is a microorganism in an infectious disease. For lung cancer, it is any factor that initiates the process, such as asbestos fibres or components in tobacco smoke.
  • Primary prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period.
  • The period of pathogenesis starts after the disease process has been triggered and pathological changes occur without the individual being aware of it.
  • It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death, or disability.
  • The subclinical or asymptomatic period between exposure and onset of symptoms is called the incubation period for infectious diseases, and the latency period for chronic diseases.
  • The onset of clinical symptoms is the beginning of the clinical stage of the disease.
  • Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period.
  • Rehabilitation has been defined as the use of medical, social, educational, and vocational measures for training the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability.
  • It is a part of tertiary prevention like providing callipers for walking patients and arranging schooling after being affected by polio.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen.
Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus.
Palpation begins at the site of pain.
Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe abdominal pain. Identify the false statement given about the examination of the abdomen: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palpation begins at the site of pain.

 

Palpation in the examination of a patient with abdominal pain should never start at the site of pain. Instead, it should begin away from the painful area to avoid causing the patient unnecessary discomfort and to prevent muscle guarding that might obscure findings. This approach allows the examiner to gather information about the non-painful areas first and approach the painful site last, ensuring a more accurate and less distressing examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen: This statement is correct. Hemoperitoneum, which is bleeding into the peritoneal cavity, can cause reddish or purplish discoloration on the flanks, known as Grey Turner’s sign. This is a significant indicator of internal bleeding, particularly in cases of acute pancreatitis or trauma.

 

Option B. Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus: This statement is correct. Cullen’s sign is the appearance of bluish discoloration around the umbilicus, which indicates intraperitoneal hemorrhage. It is often associated with conditions such as ruptured ectopic pregnancy or acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation: This statement is correct. Guarding (voluntary or involuntary muscle contraction) and rigidity (a constant, board-like hardness of the abdominal muscles) are classic signs of peritoneal irritation or inflammation, such as that seen in peritonitis. These signs suggest that there may be an underlying acute inflammatory or infectious process in the abdomen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When examining a patient with abdominal pain, always begin palpation away from the site of pain to ensure a more accurate and less distressing assessment.

questions.text: The following clinical examination was performed. What lesion would cause an exaggerated reflex? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper motor neuron

 

The clinical examination shown in the image involves testing the ankle jerk reflex, which is a deep tendon reflex. Exaggerated or hyperactive reflexes are typically a sign of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. UMN lesions occur in the neural pathways above the level of the anterior horn cell in the spinal cord, which includes the brain and the spinal cord itself. When these pathways are damaged, there is a loss of inhibitory control over the lower motor neurons, leading to hyperreflexia (exaggerated reflexes).

 

Upper motor neuron lesions are characterized by:

 

  • Hyperreflexia (exaggerated reflexes)
  • Spasticity
  • Positive Babinski sign
  • Weakness without significant muscle atrophy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyneuropathy: This condition affects multiple peripheral nerves and is typically associated with diminished or absent reflexes rather than exaggerated reflexes.

 

Option B. Radiculopathy: Damage to the nerve roots also results in lower motor neuron signs, including reduced reflexes and weakness in the distribution of the affected nerve root.

 

Option D. Lower motor neuron: Lesions here cause diminished or absent reflexes due to direct damage to the anterior horn cells or peripheral nerves that innervate muscles.

 

Educational Objective:


Exaggerated reflexes, such as an exaggerated ankle jerk reflex, are indicative of an upper motor neuron lesion. Lower motor neuron lesions, including those caused by polyneuropathy and radiculopathy, typically result in diminished or absent reflexes.

questions.text: Selenocysteine is present in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione peroxidase

 

Option B. Glutathione peroxidase: Glutathione peroxidase is an enzyme that contains selenocysteine in its active site. It plays a vital role in protecting cells from oxidative damage by catalyzing the reduction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides using glutathione as a cofactor.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Glutathione reductase: Glutathione reductase is an enzyme involved in the reduction of oxidized glutathione (GSSG) back to its reduced form (GSH). It does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Option C. Thioredoxin peroxidase: Thioredoxin peroxidase (also known as peroxiredoxins) is a group of thiol-containing proteins involved in breaking down hydrogen peroxide during oxidative stress. It does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Option D. Thioredoxin oxidase: Thioredoxin oxidase is not a known enzyme. There is an enzyme called thioredoxin reductase, which is involved in maintaining the redox state of thioredoxin, but it does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enzymes which require amino acid selenocysteine at their catalytic site are:
  1. Glutathione Peroxidase
  2. Thioredoxin Reductase
  3. Iodothyronine deiodinase
  • Codon for selenocysteine: UGA
  • This AA is formed by co–translational (during translation) modification (not by post-translational modification).

questions.text: A patient with heart disease has breathlessness on going to the bathroom. What grade does he belong to? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NYHA 3

 

This patient with heart disease experiences dyspnea while performing an activity of daily living (going to the bathroom), which classifies him as NYHA Class 3.

 

The New York Heart Association (NYHA) classification system is used to classify patients with heart disease based on their functional disability:

 

  • NYHA Class I: No limitation of physical activity; ordinary activity does not cause symptoms.
  • NYHA Class II: Slight limitation of physical activity; comfortable at rest, but ordinary activity causes symptoms.
  • NYHA Class III: Marked limitation of physical activity; comfortable at rest, but less than ordinary activity (e.g., walking to the bathroom) causes symptoms.
  • NYHA Class IV: Unable to carry out any physical activity without symptoms, or symptoms at rest.

 

In this case, the patient's breathlessness when going to the bathroom indicates a significant limitation, making him fall under Class III.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NYHA 4: Class 4 indicates severe limitations, where the patient is unable to perform any activity without symptoms or experiences symptoms even at rest, which is more severe than this patient’s current condition.

 

Option C. MMRC 4 and D. MMRC 5: The Modified Medical Research Council (MMRC) Dyspnea Scale is used to assess dyspnea in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). This classification scale does not apply to patients with heart disease. The MMRC scale is used to assess the degree of breathlessness in COPD, ranging from 0 to 4, where higher numbers indicate more severe breathlessness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The NYHA classification is commonly used to evaluate patients with heart failure based on their level of physical activity and symptom severity. Class III patients experience significant limitations in activity, where even mild exertion (such as going to the bathroom) causes symptoms like breathlessness.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male underwent NCCT abdomen for suspected renal calculi. An incidental finding was noted in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydatid cyst

 

Explanation:

 

The above CT image showing a calcified lesion in the liver with a lamellar wall which indicates hydatid disease.

 

Caused by Echinococcus granulosus → Humans – accidental host

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Typically presents as a solid tumor with irregular borders and might show vascular invasion or enhancement after contrast administration, not typically calcified.

 

Option B. Fibronodular hyperplasia: Refers to a benign liver lesion that generally does not demonstrate the clear, calcified, and layered appearance of a hydatid cyst.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: Would more likely present as a fluid-filled lesion with possible air-fluid levels and peripheral enhancement after contrast, not the lamellar calcification seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydatid cysts in the liver are recognized on CT scans by their calcified, lamellar structure and are an important differential when considering cystic liver lesions, particularly in regions where Echinococcus is endemic.

questions.text: Match the following: (INCET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

Explanation:

 

1. Football sign: This sign is associated with pneumoperitoneum, where an accumulation of gas in the peritoneal cavity gives a silhouette resembling a football on X-ray images.

 

 

2. Rat tail sign: Typically seen in carcinoma of the esophagus, this sign describes the tapering of the esophageal lumen due to the tumor, resembling a rat’s tail..

 

 

3. String sign: Found in CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis), it refers to the appearance of a narrowed, elongated channel through the pylorus.

 

 

4. Inverted umbrella sign: This is seen in cases of TB (tuberculosis), particularly referring to the appearance of a contracted cecum and narrow ileocecal junction

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is seen in methanol intoxication? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

 

Methanol intoxication leads to metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap & high osmolal gap. Methanol is metabolized in the body to formic acid, which is a strong acid. The accumulation of formic acid in the bloodstream results in an increase in hydrogen ion concentration, leading to acidosis. The high anion gap indicates that there are unmeasured anions (such as formate) contributing to the acidosis. In addition to causing a high anion gap, methanol intoxication also leads to a high osmolal gap, which is another diagnostic clue in cases of toxic alcohol ingestion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication does not cause alkalosis. Instead, it causes acidosis due to the production of formic acid.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because the acidosis caused by methanol intoxication is characterized by a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formate, a byproduct of methanol metabolism.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap: This statement is incorrect because methanol intoxication leads to acidosis, not alkalosis, and the anion gap is elevated, not normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol intoxication causes metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap due to the accumulation of formic acid.

questions.text:
Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to which of the following persons?(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)

 

  1. Sharing the same clothes, towels
  2. Living with a patient with leprosy for > 6 month
  3. Contact of age more than 2 years
  4. Contact for more than 20 hours per week.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to contacts 2, 3 and 4.

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to the following contacts:

 

  • Being identified as a contact, i.e., a person who has been in close contact with the index case for 20 hours (option 4) or more per week for more than 3 months (option 2) (Exception is blanket approach where no link with an index case needs to be established.)
  • Age: More than 2 years (option 3); if younger than 2 years, the child can be given SDR at the age of 2, in follow up visits of contacts (if meeting all other inclusion criteria.)
  • Consent of the contact obtained. Depending on the country situation, this can be written or a verbal consent. In case of children, consent should be obtained from the parent or guardian, and sometimes an assent from the grown-up children.
  • Sharing the same clothes and towels (Option 1), while a potential route of transmission, is not generally considered a primary criterion for chemoprophylaxis.

 

Exclusion criteria

 

  • Persons with possible signs and/or symptoms of leprosy;
  • Persons with possible signs and/or symptoms of TB or confirmed with TB;
  • Persons with a history of liver or kidney disorders;
  • Pregnancy; SDR can be given after the delivery;
  • Persons who have received rifampicin in the last two years e.g. as treatment of TB, leprosy or as prophylaxis (e.g. contact of another index case);
  • Persons with history of allergy to rifampicin;
  • Refusal to take SDR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy is crucial for contacts who have had significant exposure to an individual with leprosy, particularly those living in the same household or in close contact for extended periods.

 

Rifampicin:

 

  • A single dose of 600 mg kills more than 99% of the susceptible organisms present at the start of treatment, that is as much as 3 to 6 months of daily treatment with the combination dapsone plus Clofazimine.
  • Rifampicin has become established as a highly potent bactericidal drug, and it acts by inhibiting the bacterial DNA dependent RNA polymerase.
  • Single Dose of Rifampicin (SDR) is used in chemoprophylaxis.
  • Chemoprophylaxis must be initiated only 4 weeks after treatment for leprosy has begun in the patient so as to ensure the patient is non-infectious.

 

 

Ref - Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page no 242

Leprosy/Hansen disease: Contact tracing and post-exposure prophylaxis

https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789290228073 (page 23, 24)

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3051288/

questions.text: Match the following cancers with their corresponding criteria for the minimum number of lymph nodes required for pathological staging: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The minimum number of lymph nodes required for accurate staging are 16 for stomach carcinoma, 12 for colon carcinoma, 6 for gall bladder carcinoma, and 10 for breast carcinoma.

choices.text: 1st trimester USG is the best assessment
Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period
In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG
Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation calculation: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

 

  • Gestational age or period of gestation (POG) refers to the duration of pregnancy calculated from the first day of last menstrual period
  • Calculating the EDD:
    • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
    • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day)
      • Add 9 months + 7 days
      • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
      • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer
    • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND
      • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
      • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1st trimester USG is the best assessment: Correct, because the 1st trimester USG provides the most accurate dating method.

 

Option C. In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG: Correct, because calculating gestational age in IVF pregnancies relies on the day of embryo transfer or fertilization.

 

Option D. Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester: Correct, because CRL is the best measure for assessing the period of gestation in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg127

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with a midline neck swelling that moves on deglutition. Ultrasound revealed a 2 cm x 2 cm nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid, extending into the strap muscles. The histopathology image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Papillary cancer of thyroid

 

The clinical scenario and the image showing papillae lined by cells with overlapping nuclei and Orphan Annie eye nuclei indicate a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

 

Histologically, the following features are present

 

  1. Papillary pattern - Papillae composed of fibrovascular stalk and covered by single layer of tumor cells is the predominant feature. Papillae are often accompanied by follicles.
  2. Tumor cells. The tumor cells have characteristic nuclear features due to dispersed nuclear chromatin imparting it ground glass or optically clear appearance and clear or oxyphilic cytoplasm also called Orphan Annie nuclei.
  3. Invasion - Invade the capsule and intra-thyroid lymphatics
  4. Psammoma bodies - Small, concentric, calcified spherules called psammoma bodies in the stroma.

 

Papillary carcinoma thyroid microscopy shows branching papillae having fibrovascular stalk covered by a single layer of cuboidal cells having ground nuclei. Colloid-filled follicles and sloid sheets of tumor cells are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary cancer of thyroid: This cancer arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid and is associated with elevated calcitonin levels. Histologically, it shows a solid growth pattern with amyloid deposits, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Option B. Follicular cancer of thyroid: This type of thyroid cancer typically shows a follicular growth pattern with invasion into blood vessels or the capsule. The cells do not have the distinct nuclear features (Orphan Annie nuclei) seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Thyroglossal cyst: This is a benign cystic lesion that usually presents as a midline neck mass that moves with swallowing or tongue protrusion. It does not present with a nodule in the thyroid gland or the histological features described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized by Orphan Annie nuclei, psammoma bodies, and a papillary architecture, which are key diagnostic features.

questions.text: Based on the ECG given below, which of the following drugs is NOT used in the management of the condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The ECG shows a case of atrial fibrillation, characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and the absence of distinct P waves. Instead, there are fibrillatory waves that can be seen in the baseline. Atrial fibrillation is a common type of irregular heart rhythm where the atria beat chaotically and irregularly.

 

Adenosine is not used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It is primarily indicated for the treatment of regular narrow complex tachycardias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Adenosine works by temporarily blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node, which can help reset the heart rhythm in cases of regular tachycardias. However, in irregular rhythms like atrial fibrillation, adenosine is contraindicated because it can induce atrial fibrillation or exacerbate the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It helps control the heart rate by slowing down the conduction through the AV node.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation. It can help to convert atrial fibrillation to a normal sinus rhythm and maintain it.

 

Option D. Diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation by slowing conduction through the AV node.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenosine should not be used in the management of atrial fibrillation due to its potential to induce or worsen the condition.

questions.text: A patient, who is a known case of HIV with a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm, presents with 5 days of cough and high-grade fever without chills and rigors. There is no history of diarrhea, vomiting, or nuchal rigidity. Chest x-ray is normal. What treatment will you give? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Co-trimoxazole only

 

In a patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm presenting with symptoms such as cough and fever, but with a normal chest x-ray, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a likely diagnosis. PCP is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, especially when the CD4 count is below 200 cells/cu.mm.

 

The treatment of choice for PCP is co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole). It is essential to start treatment empirically in suspected cases of PCP because delayed treatment can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. The dose of co-trimoxazole is typically higher for treating PCP than for prophylaxis.

 

Steroids are indicated in severe cases of PCP to reduce inflammation, specifically if the patient has hypoxemia (PaO2 < 70 mmHg) or an alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient > 35 mmHg. In this scenario, there is no data indicating severe disease, so co-trimoxazole alone is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid + Azithromycin: This combination is used for bacterial pneumonia, not PCP. Given the normal chest x-ray and the patient's clinical presentation, bacterial pneumonia is less likely.

 

Option B. Co-trimoxazole + steroids: Steroids are added in severe cases of PCP. However, there is no evidence in this case of severe hypoxemia or an increased A-a gradient to justify the use of steroids along with co-trimoxazole.

 

Option D. Antitubercular treatment: There is no indication from the clinical presentation or the normal chest x-ray that the patient has tuberculosis. Antitubercular treatment is therefore not appropriate in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HIV patients with a CD4 count below 200 cells/cu.mm and presenting with cough and fever but a normal chest x-ray, co-trimoxazole is the first-line treatment for suspected PCP

 

Note - For a patient with a CD4 count of 200 and lower respiratory tract symptoms:

 

  • PCP Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray is normal or negative.
  • Bacterial Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray shows consolidation or examination reveals bronchial breath sounds.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

The correct match for Wullstein’s classification is a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

  1. Type II – 2. graft placed over the incus
  2. Type III – 4. columella tympanoplasty
  3. Type IV – 3. Cavum minor
  4. Type V – 1. Fenestration tympanoplasty

 

  1. Type II (Ossiculoplasty): Malleus partially eroded; ossicular chain reconstruction involves placing a graft over the incus.
  2. Type III (Columella Effect): Malleus and incus eroded; new TM coupled to the stapes head, referred to as columella tympanoplasty.
  3. Type IV (Cavum Minor): Stapedial head also eroded; new TM and new ossicular coupling to the stapes footplate.
  4. Type V (Fenestration Operation): Creating a fenestra and coupling the ossicular chain to the scala vestibuli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty provides a systematic approach to different types of middle ear reconstructions based on the extent of ossicular damage and required surgical repair.

questions.text: A hospital is investigating the effectiveness of statins in a multiple-centric clinical trial. The study involves 4000-5000 patients and half of them have received the drug while the other half was given a placebo. Both the subjects and the investigators are unaware of which group is getting the drug and which group is being administered the placebo. Which of the following phases of clinical trial corresponds to this scenario? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Phase 3  


As the study is being conducted in multiple centers in a double blinded manner, where neither the physician nor the patients know what they are receiving, therefore this trial is in Phase 3.

 

The phases of clinical trials are as follows: -

 

 

  • Phase Zero trials are called micro-dosing studies. It is an optional trial done by some companies on small number of healthy volunteers to know the pharmacokinetics of the drug. Dose used is one-hundredth of the final human dose or 100 microgram (whichever is lower).
  • Pre-clinical trials are animal studies. The drugs are first tested on the small animals like rats, guinea pig etc. to know the complete pharmacokinetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The described clinical trial, with its large sample size, multiple centers, double-blind design, and focus on confirming the efficacy of statins, corresponds to a Phase 3 clinical trial. This phase is crucial for determining whether the drug is effective and safe for widespread use.

choices.text: Annual new case detection rate per lac
Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

questions.text: A public health official is evaluating the effectiveness of a health system in emphasizing early detection of leprosy in a community setting. Which of the following metrics would be most indicative of the system's commitment to early identification?" (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade 2 disability is useful in determining whether the health system is giving importance to identifying leprosy in the community.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment completion rate: This measures the effectiveness of treatment adherence and success but does not directly reflect the system's ability to detect cases early.

 

Option B. Annual new case detection rate per lac: While it shows the number of new cases detected, it doesn't indicate how early these cases are being detected.

 

Option C. Treatment initiation rate: This measures how quickly diagnosed patients begin treatment but does not indicate how early the cases are being detected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability is a key indicator of the effectiveness of a health system in detecting leprosy early.
  • Lower proportions suggest better early detection efforts

questions.text: Which of the following represents maximum amplitude in Thromboelastography? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelet

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a test that measures the viscoelastic properties of blood as it clots under low shear conditions, mimicking sluggish venous flow. The maximum amplitude (MA) on a TEG tracing represents the final strength of the clot and is predominantly determined by the number and function of platelets and fibrin interaction.

 

  • Platelets play a crucial role in forming the solid clot structure, which is reflected by the MA. Thus, the maximum amplitude in TEG is directly associated with platelet function and quantity.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intrinsic and Option C. Extrinsic: These terms refer to different pathways of the coagulation cascade, not directly to the maximum amplitude in TEG.

 

Option D. vWD: von Willebrand Disease affects platelet adhesion due to deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, but the maximum amplitude is a function of platelet interaction with fibrin, not directly of vWD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum amplitude in Thromboelastography represents platelets. TEG is a non-invasive test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot.

choices.text: Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidas

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine, except: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

 

  • Hyponatremia is more commonly observed in individuals taking oxcarbazepine compared to those taking carbamazepine.
  • Both of these antiepileptic drugs can contribute to hyponatremia by enhancing the effects of ADH (antidiuretic hormone), leading to increased retention of water, which in turn reduces the osmolarity and causes hyponatremia. However, the incidence of hyponatremia appears to be higher with oxcarbazepine when compared to carbamazepine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotension: Hypotension is more commonly seen with carbamazepine. It can affect cardiovascular function and lead to decreased blood pressure.

 

Option C. Rash: Rash is a common side effect of both drugs, but it is more frequently seen with carbamazepine. Skin reactions can range from mild to severe, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

 

Option D. Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidases (GGT): Elevated GGT levels are more commonly associated with carbamazepine use. GGT is an enzyme found in the liver, and its elevated levels can indicate liver enzyme induction or liver injury, which is more common with carbamazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. While both drugs can cause similar side effects due to their similar mechanisms of action, certain adverse effects, such as hypotension, rash, and elevated GGT levels, are more frequently seen with carbamazepine.

questions.text: Which marked structure causes lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, along with flexion at the knee joint?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in the image are:

 

Option A. 1- Rectus femoris

Option B. 2- Vastus lateralis

Option C. 3- Adductor longus

Option D. 4- Sartorius

 

Sartorius is involved in lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, and flexion at the knee. The structure marked '4' is sartorius.

 

The sartorius muscle is a long, thin muscle that runs down the front of the thigh. It is the body's longest muscle and is sometimes referred to as the tailor muscle because of the position that tailors often adopt while working. The sartorius muscle originates from the anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it, and runs obliquely across the thigh to insert into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity. It joins the aponeurosis of the gracilis and semitendinosus muscles to form the pes anserinus.

 

The sartorius muscle is responsible for several actions, including flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh, as well as flexion of the leg. Because of its location and actions, it is involved in many activities that require movement of the lower limb, such as walking, running, and climbing stairs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the anterior compartment of thigh (spinal segments in bold are the major segments innervating the muscle)

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy was brought to OPD with complaint of fatigue. Serum investigations revealed findings as given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Hemoglobin – 9 g/dl

 

Mean cell volume (MCV) – 60 fL

 

Mean cell Hb (MCH) – 20 pg

 

Serum Ferritin – 185 mcg/L

 

Total leukocyte count – Elevated lymphocyte and Neutrophils

 

[Reference normal values for this question: Serum Ferritin: 50-200 mcg/L; Mean cell volume (MCV) - 80-100 fL; Mean cell Hb (MCH) - 27-31 pg]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thalassemia

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, along with laboratory findings, strongly suggests thalassemia.

 

  • MCV of 60 fL and MCH of 20 pg are both very low, indicating microcytic hypochromic anemia, which is typical in thalassemia.
  • Serum ferritin is within the normal range (185 mcg/L), which rules out iron-deficiency anemia, as that condition would typically present with low ferritin levels.
  • The elevated lymphocyte and neutrophil counts could be a secondary response but are not specific to thalassemia.

 

Thalassemia is characterized by a reduction in the synthesis of globin chains (alpha or beta), leading to ineffective erythropoiesis and anemia. The microcytosis and hypochromia (low MCV and MCH) are hallmarks of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia of chronic disorder: Typically presents with normal to reduced MCV and low serum iron, but ferritin is usually raised, not within the normal range.

 

Option C. Iron-deficiency anemia: Would show low serum ferritin, low MCV, and low MCH, but the serum ferritin here is normal.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: Would not typically present with low MCV and MCH, as sickle cells tend to be normocytic or macrocytic.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: SARS CoV-2 diagnosis is done by all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Southern blotting

 

  • Southern blotting is not a standard method for SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis. It is a technique primarily used for the detection and analysis of DNA fragments, not RNA viruses like SARS-CoV-2. 
  • Diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) primarily involves detecting viral RNA or immune response markers. Let's break down the options:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR) —Used

  • Gold standard for detecting viral RNA.
  • RNA is reverse-transcribed to DNA, then amplified.
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
     

 

Option B. Real-Time PCR —Used

  • Often used in combination with RT (i.e., RT-qPCR).
  • Provides quantitative data and real-time amplification curves.

 

Option C. Southern Blotting —Not used

  • Southern blotting is used to detect DNA, not RNA.
  • It is not suitable for viral RNA detection.

 

Option D. Immunoassays — Used

  • Used for antibody detection (IgM, IgG) or antigen detection.
  • Examples: ELISA, lateral flow assays (like rapid tests).
  • Useful for screening, epidemiological surveillance, and past infection confirmation.
     

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Brunt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Explanation:

 

  • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase.
  • It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by a mousy or musty odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites.

 

Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase causes isovaleric acidemia, which is associated with a rancid, cheesy, or sweaty feet odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid.

 

Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase: Deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase leads to tyrosinemia type I, which is characterized by a boiled cabbage or rotten mushrooms odor due to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium

 

  • Glycogen phosphorylase is primarily activated indirectly by calcium ions. An increase in intracellular calcium levels triggers the activation of phosphorylase kinase, which, in turn, activates glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium acts as a secondary messenger to stimulate this cascade of enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6 Phosphate: Glucose 6-phosphate, a product of glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown), actually inhibits glycogen phosphorylase. It is part of a negative feedback mechanism to prevent excessive glycogen breakdown when glucose levels are sufficient.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. Instead, insulin plays a role in promoting glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase and inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase.

 

 

Option D. Glucose: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose signal that glucose is available for energy production, leading to the inhibition of glycogenolysis and glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen phosphorylase is activated indirectly through the calcium signaling pathway, which initiates a series of enzymatic reactions ultimately leading to the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. This mechanism allows the regulation of glycogen breakdown in response to cellular energy needs.

questions.text: The daughter of a woman who received diethylstilbestrol during her pregnancy is at higher risk for? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clear cell adenocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was previously prescribed to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and other pregnancy complications. It was later discovered to be a teratogen and is no longer used.
  • Exposure to DES in utero is known to cause the following conditions:
    • In girls:
      • T-shaped uterus
      • Cockscomb cervix
      • Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma
    • In boys:
      • Micropenis
      • Hypospadias
      • Undescended testes

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of cervical cancer. It arises from the ectocervix, at the squamocolumnar junction. This type of cancer is not specifically associated with DES exposure.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma arises from the endocervix and is not specifically linked to DES exposure.

 

Option D. Sarcoma botryoides: Sarcoma botryoides is a type of rhabdomyosarcoma that arises from the cervix. It presents as a pinkish polypoidal growth filling up the vagina completely and causes blood-tinged watery discharge. It is not associated with DES exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DES exposure in utero is specifically associated with an increased risk of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg42

questions.text: The patient, aged 60, shows a lesion as depicted in the image below. Additionally, he reports that he felt a spider crawling in the area of the lesion when he woke up. What is the most probable diagnosis based on this information? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes zoster infection

 

The above image shows confluent, red, vesicular lesions in a single dermatome along with spider crawling sensation (paraesthesia) is highly suggestive of Herpes zoster infection.

 

  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Irritant contact dermatitis

 

It typically presents with erythema and scaling and can include blistering, but it is not usually unilateral or confined to a dermatomal pattern as seen in the image.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis

 

This causes an itchy, red rash and may lead to blisters. The distribution is typically at the site of contact with the allergen and not dermatomal.

 

Option D. Herpes Simplex infection: It presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, usually around the lips or genital region as shown in the image below. It does not follow a dermatomal pattern.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a 60-year-old patient presenting with a unilateral vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution, the most likely diagnosis is herpes zoster infection.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

choices.text: Anaerobic respiration produces carbon dioxide
Low pH mainly activates lysosomal enzymes
Renal perfusion is enhanced

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department with signs and symptoms of shock. Which of the following statements regarding shock is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low pH mainly activates lysosomal enzymes

 

Low pH mainly activates lysosomal enzymes: In cases of shock, reduced tissue perfusion and oxygen supply can lead to cellular hypoxia and acidosis (low pH). Low pH can activate lysosomal enzymes within cells, leading to cellular damage and tissue injury. This is one of the mechanisms contributing to organ dysfunction in shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaerobic respiration produces carbon dioxide: Anaerobic respiration occurs in cells when there is insufficient oxygen to support aerobic respiration. It produces lactic acid as a metabolic byproduct, not carbon dioxide. Carbon dioxide is primarily produced during aerobic respiration.

 

Option C. Peripheral vasodilation: Shock often involves systemic vasodilation, but it's not limited to peripheral vasodilation. In distributive shock, like septic shock, there is widespread vasodilation, including peripheral and central blood vessels, which can result in decreased blood pressure and poor tissue perfusion.

 

Option D. Renal perfusion is enhanced: In shock, including various types of shock such as hypovolemic, distributive, or cardiogenic shock, renal perfusion is typically compromised due to decreased cardiac output or blood volume. The kidneys receive less blood flow in an attempt to redirect blood to vital organs like the brain and heart. This reduction in renal perfusion can lead to acute kidney injury (AKI).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shock is a state of circulatory failure resulting in tissue hypoperfusion and hypoxia. Prolonged shock eventually leads to irreversible tissue damage. In cases of shock, there is inadequate oxygenation. Thus, cells switch from aerobic to anaerobic respiration where lactic acid, not carbon dioxide, is produced. The accumulation of lactic acid in the blood leads to systemic acidosis.

 

Lysosomes are membraned organelles that enclose all the hydrolysing enzymes capable of breaking down biological polymers. The lysosomal enzymes are only active in acidic pH (low pH value) and this pH is maintained within the organelle. Hypoxic tissue injury during shock causes membrane damage, and extravasation of the enzymes from lysosomes. Thus, leading to tissue death.

questions.text: A young man sustained a scorpion sting 2 hours ago. On examination, his blood pressure is 154/94 mm Hg; Heart Rate 72 beats/minute, and respiratory rate 32 breaths/minute. He also complains of breathlessness. Which of the following is the preferred drug for management of this patient? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prazosin


Scorpion venom causes release of a large amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals which can lead to hypertension, tachycardia, breathlessness due to pulmonary edema etc. These effects are counteracted by using Prazosin, which is a selective α1 blocker.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Metoprolol: This is a beta-blocker used primarily for managing hypertension, heart rate control, and other cardiovascular conditions. It is not typically used in the management of scorpion stings, as it doesn't directly address the pathophysiological effects of the venom.

 

Option B. Ivabradine: This drug is used to reduce heart rate in certain conditions such as chronic heart failure and angina. It is not indicated for treating symptoms of scorpion sting.

 

Option D. Frusemide: This is a diuretic, primarily used to treat conditions like hypertension and edema. It does not have a direct role in managing the effects of a scorpion sting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin is the preferred drug for managing the symptoms of a scorpion sting, as it counteracts the effects of catecholamines released due to the venom, providing relief from hypertension and pulmonary edema. Other drugs listed do not directly address the primary pathophysiological effects of a scorpion sting.

choices.text: Weakly basic drugs
Weakly acidic drugs

questions.text: Alkalinization of urine will be helpful in the treatment of poisoning due to?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Weakly acidic drugs

 

Alkalinization of urine is effective in treating overdoses of weakly acidic drugs. By increasing the pH of the urine, it promotes the ionization of these drugs. Ionized drugs are less likely to be reabsorbed in the kidney tubules and are more readily excreted. This principle is particularly applied in cases of aspirin (salicylate) poisoning.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Weakly basic drugs: Urinary alkalinization is not typically used for weakly basic drugs. Basic drugs are more likely to be reabsorbed in an alkaline environment, making this approach counterproductive.

 

Option B. Strong acids: Strong acids are not significantly affected by urinary pH, so alkalinization would not be particularly beneficial.

 

Option C. Strong bases: Similar to strong acids, strong bases are not significantly impacted by changes in urinary pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkalinization of urine is an effective strategy to enhance the excretion of weakly acidic drugs by increasing their ionization and reducing their reabsorption in the renal tubules, thus promoting their elimination from the body. This method is particularly useful in cases of poisoning with weak acids, such as aspirin (salicylates).

questions.text: A patient is brought with altered sensorium and seizures. Attendant shows the laboratory report which reveals elevated transaminases. Which of the following can be used in this condition? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oxazepam
 

Oxazepam is a short acting Benzodiazepine, which has no active metabolites and can be used safely in a patient with active liver disease. Other BZDs that can be used include Temazepam, Lorazepam, Estazolam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midazolam: Midazolam is metabolized in the liver through oxidative pathways and produces active metabolites. It is not the best choice for patients with liver impairment.

 

Option B. Diazepam: Diazepam is metabolized in the liver to active metabolites, which can accumulate in patients with liver dysfunction, potentially leading to prolonged sedation and toxicity.

 

Option C. Alprazolam: Alprazolam is also metabolized in the liver through oxidative processes and has active metabolites. It is not recommended for patients with significant liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with liver impairment, such as those with elevated transaminases, it is crucial to use medications that are not heavily reliant on hepatic metabolism and do not produce active metabolites. Oxazepam, being metabolized via conjugation, is a safer option in such scenarios compared to other benzodiazepines like midazolam, diazepam, and alprazolam.

 

Remember with mnemonic ‘STOLE’

 

Short-acting Benzodiazepines

 

  • Temazepam
  • Oxazepam
  • Lorazepam
  • Estazolam

choices.text: Inhibits HMG Co reductase
Activates PPAR alpha
Binds to deoxycholic acid
Inhibit intestinal absorption of cholesterol

questions.text: A patient who is on treatment for hyperlipidemia develops gallstones. What is the mechanism of action of the causative drug that was given to this patient? ((INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Activates PPAR alpha

 

Fibrates, such as clofibrate, fenofibrate, and gemfibrozil, are used to treat hyperlipidemia. These drugs work by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα). The activation of PPARα leads to:

 

  1. Increased synthesis of lipoprotein lipase, which accelerates the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins.
  2. Reduced production of VLDL and chylomicrons.
  3. Lower levels of triglycerides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Statins inhibit HMG CoA reductase. These drugs are used as lipid-lowering agents in dyslipidemia and are associated with statin-induced myopathy. These drugs do not lead to development of gallstones.

 

Option C. Bile Acid Sequestrants bind to deoxycholic acid and prevent its reabsorption in the intestine. It may result in deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins.

 

Option D. Ezetimibe is a drug that acts by inhibiting intestinal absorption of cholesterol

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrates are lipid-lowering agents that work by activating PPARα. While effective at reducing triglycerides and VLDL, they can increase the risk of gallstone formation due to increased cholesterol content in bile. This is an important consideration when choosing lipid-lowering therapy, especially in patients at risk for cholelithiasis.

questions.text:
The lipid profile of a patient who suffered from acute coronary syndrome is given below. What drug can be used to treat this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  • Serum low-density lipoprotein: 127 g/dL
  • Serum high-density lipoprotein: 32 mg/dL
  • Serum triglycerides: 278 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atorvastatin 80 mg

 

Atorvastatin 80 mg can be used to treat this condition. The first line of therapy in controlling cholesterol in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) is starting a high-intensity statin. High-intensity statins include atorvastatin (40–80 mg) and rosuvastatin (20–40 mg).

 

Statins are competitive inhibitors of HMG-CoA reductase, which leads to a decrease in cholesterol biosynthesis. This mechanism effectively reduces low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and triglyceride levels, both of which are elevated in this patient’s lipid profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate reduces lipoprotein levels by interacting with peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR-α) and stimulating lipoprotein lipase. Fenofibrate is typically used for treating hyperlipoproteinemia and severe hypertriglyceridemia (>1000 mg/dL), which is not the case in this patient, as the triglycerides are elevated but not that high.

 

Option B. Rosuvastatin + Fenofibrate: The combination of rosuvastatin and fenofibrate was previously used to reduce atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk. However, recent studies have indicated no added benefit from combining these two drugs, leading to the recommendation against this combination therapy.

 

Option C. Rosuvastatin 10 mg: Rosuvastatin 10 mg is considered a low-intensity statin and is mainly used for primary prevention in patients who are at risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease but have not yet developed significant coronary events. For secondary prevention, as in this patient with acute coronary syndrome, a high-intensity statin like atorvastatin 80 mg or rosuvastatin 20–40 mg is recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, such as those who have experienced an acute coronary syndrome, should be treated with high-intensity statins to reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events. Atorvastatin (40–80 mg) and rosuvastatin (20–40 mg) are the main options in this category.

choices.text: Alternative RNA splicing

questions.text: Due to which phenomenon, B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alternative RNA splicing

 

B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to alternative RNA splicing.

 

Alternative splicing is the process that selectively removes introns or exons, or parts thereof, to generate multiple messenger RNAs (mRNAs) from a single precursor mRNA (pre-mRNA).

 

Humoral immunity is mediated by antibodies, which are produced by B lymphocytes.

 

Upon maturation, B lymphocytes produce IgM as the first type of immunoglobulin, followed by immunoglobulin IgG, IgE, and IgA, as a result of irreversible rearrangement of the immunoglobulin gene after activation.

 

In contrast, the IgM-to-IgD transition is produced through alternative splicing of a long primary mRNA transcript from the Ig heavy chain gene, IGH. The nuclear RNA-binding protein, HuR, is well known for its function in mRNA splicing and nuclear export.

 

Other options:

 

Options A. Somatic hypermutation and C. Affinity maturation: Affinity maturation is the process by which antibodies gain increased affinity, avidity, and anti-pathogen activity and is the result of somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled to selection for antigen binding.

 

Option D. Allelic exclusion: Allelic exclusion is a process by which only one allele of a gene is expressed while the other allele is silenced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

B cells express both IgM and IgD through alternative RNA splicing, allowing the simultaneous expression of these two immunoglobulins.

choices.text: Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends
At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding late decelerations? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

 

The false statement about late decelerations among the given options is option C - At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline.

 

Typically, a late deceleration causes a fall in the fetal heart rate (FHR) by a depth of <10 to 20 bpm below the baseline. It is usually not accompanied by accelerations (Option D).

 

Late decelerations are smooth, gradual (Option B) symmetrical declines in the FHR that begin at or after the peak of uterine contraction and end only after the contraction has ended (Option A).

 

Late decelerations are usually indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia. Other causes of late decelerations include hypotension from epidural anesthesia, excessive use of oxytocin, maternal hypertension, diabetes, and placental abruption.

 

A late deceleration plus decreased variability in FHR is predictive of fetal acidemia and neonatal morbidity.

 

The given CTG shows late decelerations and their relationship with the uterine contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends: This is correct. Late decelerations typically begin after the peak of the uterine contraction and persist beyond the end of the contraction. This is due to uteroplacental insufficiency and the delay in oxygen delivery to the fetus.

 

Option B. They are smooth and gradual: This is correct. Late decelerations show a smooth and gradual decrease in fetal heart rate, usually due to reduced oxygenation of the fetus caused by impaired placental function.

 

Option D. Not associated with accelerations: This is correct. Late decelerations are typically not associated with accelerations, which are indicative of fetal well-being. The absence of accelerations alongside late decelerations can suggest fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Late decelerations are characterized by a gradual, symmetrical decrease in fetal heart rate that begins after the peak of uterine contractions and persists beyond their end. They are typically caused by uteroplacental insufficiency and are a concerning sign for fetal hypoxia.

choices.text: MHC class II deficiency on lymphocytes
MHC class I deficiency on lymphocytes

questions.text: In a patient with bare lymphocytic disease, graft vs host reaction does not occur due to: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MHC class II deficiency on lymphocytes

 

In a patient with bare lymphocytic disease, graft vs host reaction does not occur due to MHC class II deficiency on the lymphocytes.

 

Bare lymphocyte disease occurs due to mutations in transcription factors that are required for the expression of class II MHC molecules. This leads to the absence of class II MHC molecules, which in turn results in the impaired development of CD4+ T cells. Since CD4+ T cells are essential for both cellular immunity and assisting B cells, the absence of MHC class II results in a combined immunodeficiency.

 

Without functional CD4+ T cells, the immune system cannot mount the typical response required for graft vs host disease (GVHD), which is the reason GVHD does not occur in these patients. MHC class II deficiency leads to a failure in antigen presentation to CD4+ helper T cells, crucial for initiating and propagating immune responses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement deficiency: Complement deficiency affects the ability of the immune system to lyse pathogens and participate in immune complex clearance. It does not directly affect the occurrence of GVHD, which is primarily mediated by T cells recognizing foreign MHC molecules.

 

Option B. Deficiency of CD4 T lymphocytes: While this is related to the condition, the root cause is not directly a CD4 deficiency but rather a MHC class II deficiency, which leads to the impaired development of CD4+ T cells. The problem lies in the lack of MHC class II expression, not the lymphocytes themselves.

 

Option D. MHC class I deficiency on lymphocytes: MHC class I is involved in presenting antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, not CD4+ T cells. Deficiency of MHC class I affects cellular immunity against viral infections but does not explain the lack of GVHD in bare lymphocytic disease, which is primarily related to MHC class II deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bare lymphocytic disease results from a deficiency in MHC class II molecules, leading to the impaired development of CD4+ T lymphocytes, and thereby causing a combined immunodeficiency. The lack of MHC class II prevents graft vs host disease from occurring in these patients.

questions.text:
Match the following: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1 - Kleptomania
2 - Pyromania
3 - Mutilomania
4 - Dipsomania

 

A - Intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks
B - Intense desire to mutilate
C - Intense desire to steal items of trivial value
D - Intense desire to burn things
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

The correct option is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

 

Impulse control disorders are characterized by the repeated failure to resist an impulse, drive, or urge to perform an act that is rewarding to the person, at least in the short term, despite the long-term harm either to the individual or to others. These disorders involve marked distress about the behavior pattern or impairment in personal, family, social, educational, or other important areas of functioning.

 

These disorders include:

 

  1. Pyromania: The deliberate setting of fires on more than one occasion.
  2. Kleptomania: The recurrent inability to resist urges to steal objects that are of little or no personal use.
  3. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder (not directly in this question but part of impulse control disorders).
  4. Intermittent explosive disorder: Repeated episodes of impulsive, aggressive, violent behavior.

 

Kleptomania is the repeated failure to resist impulses to steal objects of trivial value, and the act is not driven by personal need. The stolen items are typically returned, given away, or kept hidden.

 

Pyromania involves the intentional setting of fires, and is associated with disorders like substance abuse, depression, and personality disturbances.

 

Dipsomania refers to an irresistible impulse to consume alcoholic beverages at periodic intervals.

 

Mutilomania is the irresistible urge to mutilate animals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Impulse control disorders include kleptomania (urge to steal), pyromania (urge to set fires), dipsomania (urge to drink alcohol), and mutilomania (urge to mutilate). These behaviors are driven by compulsions and often result in distress or impairment despite their immediate rewarding nature.

questions.text:
Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  2. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence.
  3. Cotrimoxazole is not given.
  4. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

The true statements regarding UTI in children are:

 

  • Bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence.
  • Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is performed in children with recurrent UTIs.

 

The most common cause of UTI in children is Escherichia coli (E. coli), not Streptococcus pneumoniae (hence, statement 1 is incorrect). Bowel and bladder dysfunction can lead to incomplete emptying of the bladder, increasing the risk of bacterial infections and subsequent UTI recurrence.

 

Cotrimoxazole is used as both treatment and prophylaxis for UTI in children, particularly to prevent recurrent infections (making statement 3 incorrect).

 

MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to evaluate structural abnormalities, such as vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), which can contribute to infection risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 3, 4: This is incorrect as Streptococcus pneumoniae is not the most common cause of UTI in children, and cotrimoxazole is indeed used for UTI treatment and prevention.

 

Option C. 2, 3, 4: This option is partially correct, but cotrimoxazole is used for UTI treatment, so statement 3 is incorrect.

 

Option D. 1, 4: Incorrect because Streptococcus pneumoniae is not the most common cause of UTI in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pediatric patients, Escherichia coli is the most common pathogen causing UTIs. Risk factors for recurrent UTIs include bladder and bowel dysfunction. Evaluation of recurrent UTIs typically involves a micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) to assess for structural issues like vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). Cotrimoxazole is commonly used for treatment and as prophylaxis to prevent recurrent infections.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules helps the leukocytes roll over the endothelial cells in the vessels? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E-selectin

 

E-selectin, present on the endothelial cells, is responsible for helping leukocytes roll over the endothelium during the initial stages of inflammation. This rolling is a weak interaction that allows leukocytes to slow down and prepare for stronger adhesion mediated by integrins, followed by transmigration across the endothelium into tissues.

 

Selectins are adhesion molecules that play a critical role in leukocyte-endothelium interactions:

 

  • L-selectin: Found on leukocytes.
  • E-selectin: Expressed on the endothelial cells.
  • P-selectin: Found in platelets and endothelial cells.

 

Rolling is the first step in the recruitment of leukocytes to the site of injury or infection, followed by firm adhesion, transmigration, and migration through the endothelial layer to the site of tissue damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cadherins: Cadherins are adhesion molecules, but they are primarily involved in cell-cell adhesion within tissues and are not directly involved in leukocyte rolling.

 

Option B. Platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1 (PECAM-1): PECAM-1 plays a role in diapedesis (the movement of leukocytes through the endothelium) rather than in the rolling process.

 

Option D. Cd11a: CD11a, part of the integrin family, is involved in firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium, not the rolling process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E-selectin facilitates the rolling of leukocytes on the endothelium, which is the first step in the process of leukocyte extravasation during inflammation. This is followed by stronger adhesion through integrins and migration to the site of tissue injury.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Untreated cataract

 

According to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey (2015-19), the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment (MSVI) is untreated cataract.

 

MSVI is defined as visual acuity of <6/18 to 3/60 in the better eye, even with available correction. Cataracts are a leading cause of vision loss globally, particularly in individuals over the age of 50 years, due to the clouding of the lens that can occur with aging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Refractive error: Refractive errors are a common cause of visual impairment but are more prevalent in patients under 49 years and are generally correctable with glasses or other corrective measures.

 

Option C. Glaucoma: Glaucoma, although a significant cause of visual impairment, accounts for a smaller proportion of cases compared to cataracts, especially in older populations.

 

Option D. Diabetic retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy can lead to visual impairment, but its prevalence as a cause of moderate-severe visual impairment is lower compared to cataracts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Untreated cataracts are the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment in individuals over the age of 50, according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19. Cataracts are a treatable cause of blindness and emphasize the need for timely surgical intervention to restore vision.

questions.text: Neurogenic shock is associated with _______. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypotension + bradycardia

 

Neurogenic shock is associated with hypotension and bradycardia.

 

This type of shock occurs due to a loss of sympathetic tone in the peripheral vascular system, which leads to vasodilation and decreased vascular resistance. The result is hypotension. In contrast to other types of shock (which often involve compensatory tachycardia), neurogenic shock is unique because of bradycardia, due to the disruption of sympathetic innervation to the heart and unopposed vagal (parasympathetic) activity.

 

Neurogenic shock is most commonly caused by spinal cord injuries, particularly injuries to the cervical or upper thoracic regions, which disrupt the autonomic nervous system's ability to regulate blood pressure and heart rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertension + tachycardia: These findings are not typical of neurogenic shock. Hypertension and tachycardia may be seen in other conditions, such as adrenergic crises or hypertensive emergencies.

 

Option B. Hypotension + tachycardia: This is more characteristic of other types of shock, like hypovolemic or septic shock, where compensatory tachycardia is seen as a response to low blood pressure.

 

Option D. Hypertension + bradycardia: While bradycardia can occur in neurogenic shock, hypertension is not typically associated with this condition. Instead, hypotension is the hallmark due to peripheral vasodilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurogenic shock is a type of distributive shock associated with hypotension and bradycardia due to the loss of sympathetic tone following spinal cord injuries, leading to vasodilation, decreased cardiac output, and unopposed vagal activity.

choices.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g
Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.text: The following are correct regarding normal placenta, except _______. (INICET NOV 2022) (OBG)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

 

Among the options, Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present (option C) is the incorrect statement.

 

In a normal placenta:

 

  • The placenta at term weighs about 470 g (option A).
  • It is round to oval in shape with a diameter of approximately 22 cm (option B).
  • The central thickness of the placenta is generally greater than 2.5 cm (option D).
  • The umbilical cord in a normal placenta has three vessels—two arteries and one vein. A two-vessel cord is abnormal and can be associated with congenital anomalies.

 

Thus, option C is incorrect because the normal umbilical cord has three vessels, not two.

 

Other Information:

 

The placenta is a discoid, deciduate, and hemochorial structure:

 

  • Deciduate means that the placenta is shed at the time of parturition.
  • Hemochorial indicates that maternal blood comes into direct contact with the fetal trophoblasts.

 

The placenta consists of two plates:

 

  • Chorionic plate: The fetal surface of the placenta, lined by the amniotic membrane, to which the umbilical cord is attached.
  • Basal plate: The maternal side, which is attached to the uterine wall, divided into clefts known as cotyledons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal placenta at term weighs around 470 g, is round-oval with a diameter of 22 cm, and has a three-vessel umbilical cord. A two-vessel cord is an abnormal finding.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Electron microscopy

 

Among the given options, electron microscopy will be the least useful in assessing nasal mucociliary clearance. Other tests, such as the saccharine test, charcoal powder method, and scintigraphy, are commonly used to measure mucociliary transit time and total nasal clearance in humans.

 

Electron microscopy is used to study the structure and function of cilia. It can help detect structural abnormalities in the cilia, which could impair mucociliary clearance. However, it cannot measure the actual clearance function or detect functional obstructions in the nasal passage.
