Tests typically used for assessing mucociliary clearance include:

 

  • Saccharine test: A simple test that measures the time it takes for a patient to taste a small amount of saccharine placed in the nasal cavity.
  • Scintigraphy: Uses radioactive tracers to assess mucociliary transport by measuring how long it takes for radioactive particles to be cleared from the nasal cavity.
  • Charcoal powder method: A small amount of charcoal is placed on the nasal lining, and clearance is assessed by detecting the presence of charcoal in the pharynx.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saccharine test: This is a commonly used, simple, and non-invasive method to assess mucociliary clearance. It measures how long it takes for the patient to taste the sweet saccharine placed in their nasal cavity.

 

Option C. Charcoal powder method: This method involves placing a small amount of charcoal in the nasal cavity and observing its clearance by detecting the charcoal in the pharynx. It is another method for measuring mucociliary clearance.

 

Option D. Scintigraphy: Scintigraphy uses radioisotopes to track the clearance of particles from the nasal cavity. It is an effective tool for measuring mucociliary function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electron microscopy is used to study the structure of cilia but cannot measure mucociliary clearance. Other tests, such as the saccharine test, scintigraphy, and the charcoal powder method, are used to directly assess nasal mucociliary clearance in clinical practice.

questions.text:
Match the following: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

 

Tooth

A. Canine

B. Lateral incisor

C. First molar

D. Third molar

 

Age of eruption

1. 6-7 years

2. 8-9 years

3. 11-12 years

4. 17-25 yearss
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

The correct option is Option C. A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4.

 

The time of emergence of secondary dentition or permanent teeth is crucial in pediatric and forensic medicine. For the given teeth:

 

  • First molar: The first molar typically erupts around 6-7 years of age.
  • Lateral incisor: Lateral incisors emerge around 7-9 years of age.
  • Canine: Canines usually emerge between 11-12 years of age.
  • Third molar: The third molars (also known as wisdom teeth) usually appear between 17-25 years of age.

 

This matches the arrangement in Option C, which makes it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-1, B-3, C-2, D-4: Incorrect. The lateral incisor is assigned to an incorrect age range, as lateral incisors erupt between 7-9 years, not 11-12 years as implied here.

 

Option B. A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2: Incorrect. The third molar has an incorrect assigned range of 8-9 years, which is too early for its eruption, typically occurring much later (17-25 years).

 

Option D. A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1: Incorrect. The sequence places the first molar too late at 17-25 years, which is actually the time for the third molar's eruption, making this option invalid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct timeline of tooth eruption for different types of permanent teeth is essential for understanding developmental milestones, particularly in pediatrics and forensic medicine. Key timings include:

 

  • First molar: 6-7 years
  • Lateral incisor: 7-9 years
  • Canine: 11-12 years
  • Third molar: 17-25 years

questions.text: Handedness is seen at the age of ______. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 years

 

Handedness is typically established at the age of 3 years. This refers to a child's preference for using one hand over the other, which usually becomes noticeable around this age. It is a part of the developmental milestones that children go through, and at this age, a child is expected to have a clear preference for either the right or left hand. Trying to change a child’s hand preference after this age may result in frustration or confusion for the child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 year: At 1 year, children are developing motor skills, such as walking with support or independently. However, their hand preference is not firmly established at this stage, and both hands are typically used interchangeably.

 

Option B. 2 years: By 2 years, children have better motor control and can perform simple tasks, such as making a tower of blocks, but hand preference (handedness) is still not clearly defined or permanent at this stage.

 

Option D. 4 years: Although children can perform more complex tasks by 4 years of age, such as drawing shapes or hopping, their handedness is already established by this time, which typically happens around 3 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Handedness is typically seen and established by the age of 3 years. This is a crucial developmental milestone and should be recognized as part of normal child development.

questions.text: Identify the conduction abnormality from the ECG given below. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Second degree heart block

 

The ECG shown above is the second-degree atrioventricular block type 1 - Wenckebach phenomenon.

 

Second Degree Heart Block occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS complex. There are two types:

 

  • Mobitz type 1/Wenckebach: This occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. The hallmark of this block is the progressive elongation of the PR interval, leading to an eventual drop of the QRS complex. It is commonly seen in young athletes.
  • Mobitz type 2: It occurs in the distal or infra-His conduction system. Unlike Mobitz type 1, the PR interval remains constant, but some P waves fail to conduct, leading to missed QRS complexes. Mobitz type 2 is more serious and may require a pacemaker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: This block is characterized by a prolonged but consistent PR interval (greater than 200 milliseconds), with every P wave followed by a QRS complex. There is no dropped QRS in first-degree heart block, unlike the second-degree heart block, which shows intermittent dropped QRS complexes.

 

Option B. Ventricular tachycardia: Ventricular tachycardia appears on the ECG as a wide QRS complex tachycardia with a rate of over 100 beats per minute. This is distinct from the block patterns, which primarily affect the PR interval and conduction between the atria and ventricles.

 

Option C. Third degree heart block: In third-degree (complete) heart block, there is no conduction between the atria and ventricles, leading to independent beating of the atria (P waves) and ventricles (QRS complexes). The PR intervals are variable and unrelated to the QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Second-degree heart block type 1 (Wenckebach) is characterized by progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a QRS complex is dropped.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of dilation and curettage in sequence. (INICET NOV 2022) 

 

  1. Serial dilation
  2. Curettage
  3. Uterine sound
  4. Assessment of uterine size and direction
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4-3-1-2

 

The correct sequence of dilation and curettage (D&C) is 4-3-1-2:

 

  1. Assessment of uterine size and direction: This ensures that the uterine position is understood before further intervention.
  2. Uterine sound: This is used to determine the length and angle of the uterine cavity.
  3. Serial dilation: Gradual dilation of the cervical canal is done using graduated dilators to prepare for the curettage procedure.
  4. Curettage: A curette is used to scrape the endometrial lining or remove tissue from the uterine cavity.

 

The steps of the procedure ensure the safe and proper removal of uterine contents, while minimizing trauma to the cervix and uterine wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for performing a dilation and curettage is 4-3-1-2, starting with assessing the uterine size and direction, followed by uterine sounding, dilation, and finally curettage. This order is crucial to ensure safe and effective treatment.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient clinic with intentional tremors, and poor scholastic performance. His sister has similar complaints. On examination, hepatomegaly is seen. The eye finding is shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wilson's disease

 

The probable diagnosis in the given case, based on the clinical scenario and the image, which shows icterus in the eyes, is Wilson’s disease.

 

Wilson’s disease is an autosomal-recessive condition caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes for the ATPase that removes copper, preventing its accumulation in the liver and brain.

 

Clinical features include jaundice, ascites, hepatomegaly, dysarthria, dystonia, wing-beating tremor, a decline in school performance, and personality change. Deposition of copper in the eyes results in Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings seen in the cornea, along with symptoms such as sunflower cataracts.

 

Diagnosis is confirmed by:

 

  • KF rings and decreased levels of serum copper and ceruloplasmin.
  • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion is another diagnostic marker.
  • Liver biopsy with measurement of hepatic copper levels is considered the gold standard.

 

Treatment:

 

  • British anti-lewisite (intramuscular) or D-penicillamine (oral), which enhance copper excretion.
  • Zinc acetate helps reduce copper absorption.
  • Trientine hydrochloride is used as an alternative in patients intolerant to penicillamine.

 

Liver transplantation is reserved for advanced stages of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Huntington's chorea: This is a CAG repeat disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. It is characterized by involuntary movements known as chorea. The clinical presentation of Huntington’s disease typically involves progressive motor dysfunction, psychiatric disturbances, and cognitive decline, which does not fit the symptoms of this patient.

 

Option C. Glutaric aciduria: Glutaric aciduria is an autosomal recessive disorder typically presenting in the first 6 months of life. Symptoms include hypotonia, jitteriness, and hyperkinetic movements like dystonia or choreoathetosis. This condition usually presents earlier in infancy and lacks the copper metabolism issues found in Wilson’s disease.

 

Option D. Hepatitis A: Hepatitis A is caused by the fecal-oral transmission of the Hepatitis A virus. It typically presents with nausea, vomiting, mild fever, and jaundice. However, it is acute and resolves without causing the neurological symptoms or chronic liver disease seen in Wilson’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson’s disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to abnormal copper accumulation in organs, most notably the liver and brain. Symptoms include neurological decline and hepatic dysfunction, along with characteristic Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of damage control surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vascular anastomosis

 

Vascular anastomosis is undertaken as a part of definitive surgery, not damage control surgery (DCS).

 

Damage Control Surgery (DCS) is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient initially and is followed by definitive surgery later. It coordinates staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients who have sustained major injuries.

 

  • The initial focus is hemorrhage control, resuscitation, and contamination control. It includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen to manage the physiologic response to shock and hemorrhage.

 

After the initial steps of DCS, vascular anastomosis may be done in a later stage, tailored to the patient's condition, and is preferred to be completed within 24–72 hours.

 

Note: Vascular anastomosis is less likely to be part of the initial stages of DCS, making it the best option as the correct answer for this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Control of hemorrhage: Is one of the primary steps of DCS to prevent ongoing blood loss.

 

Option B. Resuscitation: Is critical and is performed aggressively throughout DCS to stabilize the patient’s hemodynamic condition.

 

Option C. Decontamination: Is necessary in DCS to reduce infection risk, particularly in the case of bowel perforation or other contaminating injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vascular anastomosis is not a part of damage control surgery but is performed in later stages as part of definitive surgery. Damage control surgery is aimed at stabilizing patients with life-threatening conditions through steps like hemorrhage control, resuscitation, and contamination limitation.

choices.text: Large bowel obstruction due to sigmoid volvulus
Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith
Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation

questions.text: An elderly lady presents with abdominal pain and distension. She has a history of scoliosis. Given below is the erect X-ray abdomen radiograph of the lady. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Large bowel obstruction due to sigmoid volvulus

 

The given clinical scenario with an elderly woman and the radiograph showing characteristic coffee bean appearance are highly suggestive of sigmoid volvulus causing a large bowel obstruction.

 

Sigmoid volvulus is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. Symptoms include constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. The onset may be acute or chronic. It occurs more commonly in patients with a history of mental illness and chronic constipation.

 

X-ray abdomen shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign, Frimann-Dahl sign (three dense lines converge towards the site of obstruction), and the absence of rectal gas. CT may reveal a large gas-filled loop without haustral markings, forming a closed-loop obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith: Fecolith (a hardened mass of stool) is more likely to cause appendicitis or obstruction at the ileocecal valve rather than in the sigmoid colon. Fecolith obstruction does not commonly result in the characteristic "coffee bean" appearance on imaging.

 

Option C. Cecal volvulus: While this is another form of volvulus, it is less common than sigmoid volvulus. Cecal volvulus typically occurs in younger patients and presents with a different radiological appearance, including haustral markings and a different orientation of the twisted bowel.

 

Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation: Small bowel obstruction does not typically show the "coffee bean" sign seen in sigmoid volvulus. Additionally, perforation would likely show free air under the diaphragm, which is not indicated in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "coffee bean sign" seen on X-ray is a characteristic feature of sigmoid volvulus, a condition where the sigmoid colon twists on itself, causing large bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing a "coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart are highly suggestive of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease with the following four components:

 

  1. Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
  2. Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  3. Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta)
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

 

In TOF, the hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uplifted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal. On X-ray, this appears as a boot-shaped heart or coeur en sabot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ebstein's anomaly: Is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by diminished pulmonary blood flow due to abnormality of the tricuspid valve. In this condition, severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium leads to an elevated apex, giving a box-shaped heart.

 

Option C. Transposition of great arteries (TGA): Is a congenital heart condition where the great arteries are transposed. The chest radiograph in TGA often shows an egg-on-a-string appearance due to the narrow superior mediastinum and enlarged cardiac silhouette. It is the most specific congenital heart defect in infants of diabetic mothers.

 

Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC): Occurs when pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium instead of the left atrium. The chest X-ray shows a snowman-shaped heart due to the supracardiac type of TAPVC, where the heart and superior mediastinal structures resemble a snowman.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart disease that shows a boot-shaped heart (coeur en sabot) on chest radiograph due to right ventricular hypertrophy. The condition is characterized by pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: Vesicular rash is seen in __________. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hand, foot, and mouth disease

 

Vesicular rash is seen in hand, foot, and mouth disease.

 

It is a mild exanthematous fever usually occurring in children but may also occur in adults. It is characterized by papulovesicular rashes that involve the oral mucosa, palms, and soles.

 

The virus is shed in the stool and is transmitted by the fecal-oral route. It is a self-limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks. Treatment is symptomatic as the rash heals spontaneously.

 

Coxsackieviruses are enteroviruses and belong to the Picornaviridae family. They are classified into groups A and B. Group A viruses are classified into 24 types, and group B viruses are classified into 6 types.

 

Diseases caused by Coxsackie A viruses include:

 

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD)
  • Herpangina – Characterized by ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces, or palate or uvula, and the posterior pharyngeal wall.
  • Aseptic meningitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dengue: Cutaneous and mucosal findings in dengue are erythema, morbilliform eruptions, and hemorrhagic lesions. The rash in dengue is not typically vesicular.

 

Option C. Zika fever: Zika fever is characterized by fever, maculopapular rash, arthralgia, and conjunctivitis, but not by vesicular rashes.

 

Option D. Roseola infantum: Presents as a nonpruritic, pink papular rash that begins on the trunk, not as a vesicular rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key point to remember from this question is that vesicular rashes, especially involving the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, are characteristic of hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by Coxsackie A virus.

questions.text:
Match the following plant poisons with their active principles. (INICET NOV 2022) 

 

Column:1

1. Datura

2. Opium

3. Abrus precatorius

4. Nux vomica

 

Column:2

a. Atropine
b. Abrin
c. Thebaine
d. Strychnine
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d.

 

The correct match is 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d.

 

The active ingredients of Datura include the anticholinergic alkaloids atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. The seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked.

 

Manifestations of Datura toxicity:

 

  • Dry hot skin (Temperature rises up to 42°C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated).
  • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation.
  • Diplopia.
  • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst.
  • Dysphagia.
  • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels.
  • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking).
  • Drunken gait.
  • Delirium.
  • Drowsiness.
  • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure.

 

Opium is derived from the poppy plant and includes natural opioids like morphine, codeine, and thebaine.

 

Abrin is a toxalbumin of the plant Abrus precatorius, and it acts by inhibiting protein synthesis.

 

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius:

 

  • Abrin (a toxalbumen).
  • Abrine (an amino acid).
  • Abralin (a glucoside).

 

Abrin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis, leading to cell death. Clinical features after oral ingestion of these seeds include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, and miosis. Faintness, dyspnea, and convulsions may also occur.

 

The poison obtained from Strychnos nux-vomica seeds is strychnine. Strychnine acts at the ventral horn by blocking the postganglionic glycine receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem. Glycine is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that acts at the postsynaptic membranes of ventral horn motor neurons. Hence, the blockade of these receptors results in unopposed muscle contraction, resulting in the classical clinical features:

 

  • Tonic-clonic seizures.
  • Opisthotonus (body arched in hypertension).
  • Risus sardonicus.

questions.text: The following image shows a health belief model. What does box C stand for? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Health motivation

 

Box C stands for health motivation.

 

The health belief model was proposed based on the idea that a person's health behavior changes in accordance with certain beliefs. It explains the relationship between a person's perceptions about a disease and their actions to prevent or manage it.

 

The Health Belief Model consists of:

 

  1. Perceived susceptibility: A person's belief in their risk of developing a disease.
  2. Perceived severity: How serious a person considers the disease and its consequences.
  3. Perceived benefits: The belief in the positive outcomes of taking preventive actions.
  4. Perceived barriers: The potential obstacles in the way of taking actions to reduce risk.
  5. Cues to action: Factors that trigger the decision to make a health-related change.
  6. Self-efficacy: Confidence in one's ability to take action.

 

The "C" box refers to health motivation, which integrates all these elements. If a person is highly motivated, perceives a high risk of disease (high susceptibility and severity), and believes in the benefits of preventive action, they are more likely to take positive health-related actions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perceived control: Perceived control is a person's belief in their ability to influence events or outcomes in their life. In the health belief model, perceived control can affect how likely a person is to take health actions but it’s distinct from health motivation.

 

Option B. Behavioral modification: This refers to the actions a person takes to change their behavior after assessing the situation. It is not the central driver (C) in this model but rather the outcome of health motivation.

 

Option D. Self-efficacy: This is related to a person’s confidence in their ability to successfully perform health behaviors. While important, it does not represent box C in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The health belief model is a framework for understanding how a person's beliefs about health and illness can influence their behavior. The key takeaway is that health motivation plays a central role in whether someone decides to take action to protect their health.

choices.text: Osteoporotic compression fracture

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal female patient comes with persistent backache not responding to conservative treatment. She has a history of lifting heavy weights 4 months back and progressively increasing pain that worsens on walking. The pain starts radiating down her legs after walking for a distance of around 100 m. However, she feels no pain on walking uphill. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lumbar stenosis

 

The given clinical scenario of an elderly woman with back pain that worsens on walking and is relieved when walking uphill points to the diagnosis of lumbar stenosis.

 

  • Walking uphill may be preferred as it flexes the spine and maximizes the spinal canal capacity, relieving the pain.

 

Spinal stenosis is the narrowing of the spinal canal, leading to nerve compression. It can be congenital or acquired, with degeneration being the most common cause. Other contributing factors include spondylolysis, trauma, infection, and metabolic disorders.

 

Degenerative spinal stenosis involves disc degeneration, facet joint hypertrophy, and ligamentum flavum calcification, all leading to reduced spinal canal dimensions and nerve compression, resulting in neurogenic claudication.

 

  • Symptoms include back pain (most common), sciatica, sensory disturbances in the legs, motor weakness, and sometimes urinary disturbances.
  • Pain typically occurs after standing or walking for a few minutes and is relieved by sitting, squatting, or flexing the spine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporotic compression fracture: Though this can cause back pain, the classic presentation is sudden back pain after minimal trauma in elderly individuals with osteoporosis. The pain is typically not worsened by walking and doesn’t radiate down the legs like in lumbar stenosis.

 

Option C. Thromboangiitis obliterans: This condition involves inflammatory occlusion of small and medium-sized blood vessels and is often seen in young smokers. It typically presents with claudication of the lower extremities and ischemic pain, which is not relieved by walking uphill.

 

Option D. Atherosclerosis: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) due to atherosclerosis presents with intermittent claudication that is worsened by walking. However, the pain is due to poor blood flow and is typically not relieved by walking uphill or sitting, unlike the neurogenic claudication in lumbar stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lumbar stenosis presents with back pain that worsens with standing and walking (neurogenic claudication) and is relieved by sitting, squatting, or walking uphill due to the flexion of the spine, which increases the spinal canal capacity and reduces nerve compression.

questions.text:
A child presents with acute exacerbation of asthma. Which of the following would you do? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Chest X-ray
  2. Oxygen administration
  3. Salbutamol nebulization three times in 60 minutes
  4. Administration of oral corticosteroids
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3 ,4

 

A child coming with acute exacerbation of asthma will be administered oxygen, salbutamol nebulization three times in 60 minutes, and oral corticosteroids.

 

Exacerbation of asthma involves an increase in symptoms such as cough, wheezing, and/or breathlessness. If the child has cyanosis, silent chest, poor respiratory effort, altered sensorium, and oxygen saturation of <90%, the exacerbation is considered life-threatening.

 

Based on severity, acute asthma is classified as mild, moderate, and severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3, 4: While salbutamol nebulization and oral corticosteroids are important in managing an asthma exacerbation, omitting oxygen therapy (especially in cases of hypoxia) is incorrect.

 

Option B. 1, 4:  A chest X-ray is not routinely indicated in acute asthma exacerbations unless there is suspicion of another underlying condition (e.g., pneumonia, pneumothorax). Oxygen therapy and salbutamol nebulization are key for immediate management.

 

Option C. 1, 3, 4:  Similar to option B, a chest X-ray is not immediately necessary unless there is concern for an alternative diagnosis or complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute exacerbation of asthma, management includes oxygen therapy, salbutamol nebulization, and oral corticosteroids. A chest X-ray is only indicated if complications or other diagnoses are suspected.

choices.text: Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genitofemoral nerve

 

The genitofemoral nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization.

 

  • The genitofemoral nerve originates from the L1 and L2 ventral rami. It divides into the genital and femoral branches after crossing behind the ureter.
  • The genital branch enters the inguinal canal through the deep ring and accompanies the spermatic cord or round ligament. It exits the superficial inguinal ring and supplies the cremaster muscle and the skin of the external genitalia.
  • The femoral branch descends lateral to the external iliac artery to pass behind the inguinal ligament and enters the femoral sheath lateral to the femoral artery. It pierces the anterior wall of the femoral sheath and fascia lata, supplying them.

 

The genitofemoral nerve gives sensory supply to the anteromedial thigh via the femoral branch. The genital branch supplies the skin of the scrotum in males and mons pubis and labium majus in females. It also innervates the cremaster muscle via the genital branch and is responsible for the cremasteric reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve arises from the posterior division of the L2-L4 spinal segments. It lies outside the femoral sheath and enters the femoral triangle lateral to the femoral artery. Since it lies outside the femoral sheath, it is not involved in femoral vein catheterization.

 

Option C. Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh: This nerve provides sensory innervation to the anterolateral thigh. Injury to this nerve leads to meralgia paresthetica, causing pain and paresthesia in this region, but it does not relate to the femoral vein catheterization procedure.

 

Option D. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve is most commonly injured during open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury. It supplies the root of the penis and the scrotum, but is not relevant for femoral vein catheterization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genitofemoral nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is administered below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization. This nerve provides sensory innervation to the anteromedial thigh, scrotum in males, and mons pubis in females, and is responsible for the cremasteric reflex. Understanding the anatomy of the inguinal region and its relation to the femoral triangle is crucial in procedures involving catheterization or surgery in this area.

choices.text: The patient would need another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition.
Prevalence of the disease is 2%.
Patient is less likely to have the disease.
Patient has been wrongly ruled out due to false negativity.

questions.text: A point-of-care diagnostic test with a sensitivity of 98% shows a negative test result in a patient. What does this imply? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patient is less likely to have the disease.

 

A negative result in a diagnostic test with a sensitivity of 98% implies that the patient is less likely to have the disease.

 

Sensitivity is the proportion of all people with the disease who test positive. It is the probability that the test will be positive when the disease is present. The sensitivity of a test is determined by how many patients with the disease actually test positive (true positives) out of the total number of diseased individuals. In this case, a sensitivity of 98% means that 98% of people with the disease would test positive, so a negative result would likely indicate that the patient does not have the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The patient would not need another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition because the sensitivity of the diagnostic test is 98%.

 

Option B. Prevalence refers to the number of old and new cases at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It cannot be derived from the given data.

 

Option D. The higher the sensitivity of a diagnostic test, the lower will be the number of false negatives. Since the test has a 98% sensitivity, the patient most likely does not have the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The higher the sensitivity of a diagnostic test, the fewer false negatives occur, meaning a negative result implies the patient is less likely to have the disease.

choices.text: Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.
There is no pain on ocular movement.
Multiple myeloma is a common cause.
Oral corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about optic neuritis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.

 

In optic neuritis, relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil is seen. It is elicited by the swinging flashlight test. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of RAPD, both pupils dilate when moving the flashlight from the normal eye to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is known as Marcus Gunn pupil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pain is actually aggravated by ocular movement:  particularly in upward or downward directions due to the attachment of the superior rectus muscle to the dura mater.

 

Option C. Multiple sclerosis: not multiple myeloma, is a well-known demyelinating cause of optic neuritis. Multiple sclerosis often presents with optic neuritis as an early sign.

 

Option D. Oral corticosteroid therapy alone is contraindicated:  because it does not improve the outcome and is associated with an increased risk of new attacks of optic neuritis. Instead, intravenous methylprednisolone can be used, especially in patients showing radiological evidence of multiple sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), also called Marcus Gunn pupil, is a key diagnostic finding in optic neuritis, and multiple sclerosis is the common cause of this condition.

choices.text: A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4
A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3
A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4
A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1

questions.text:
Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Marjolin ulcer over the dorsum of the foot measuring 3 x 2 cm
  2. 1.5 cm cervical lymph node in the neck
  3. Soft tissue sarcoma over mid-thigh
  4. Solitary thyroid nodule

 

  1. Excision biopsy
  2. Core needle biopsy
  3. USG guided FNAC
  4. Wedge biopsy
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3


The correct answer is Option B. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3. Here's why:

 

A. Marjolin ulcer over the dorsum of the foot measuring 3 cm x 2 cm – Wedge biopsy: Marjolin's ulcer is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma, which usually arises from a long-standing wound, ulcer, or scar. In this case, a wedge biopsy is the best diagnostic method because it takes a sample of tissue from the edge of the ulcer for histopathological evaluation.

 

B. 1.5 cm cervical lymph node in the neck – Excision biopsy: For lymph node pathology, an excision biopsy is preferred. This method removes the entire lymph node for complete histopathological examination, which is crucial for the diagnosis of malignancies or other pathological conditions.

 

C. Soft tissue sarcoma over mid-thigh – Core needle biopsy: Soft tissue sarcomas are aggressive tumors that require precise diagnosis. A core needle biopsy allows the collection of tissue from the tumor without needing a large excision, thus minimizing risk and providing adequate material for histological analysis.

 

D. Solitary thyroid nodule – USG guided FNAC: Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) under ultrasound guidance is the investigation of choice for a solitary thyroid nodule. It is a minimally invasive method used to assess whether the nodule is benign or malignant, helping guide further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4 : This option incorrectly matches the biopsy types. Marjolin's ulcer should be biopsied using a wedge biopsy (not excision), and soft tissue sarcoma requires a core needle biopsy (not FNAC).

 

Option C. A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4: This also mismatches the biopsy types. Marjolin's ulcer should not be evaluated with FNAC, and soft tissue sarcomas are better diagnosed with core needle biopsies rather than excision biopsies.

 

Option D. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1: The correct combination for a solitary thyroid nodule is USG-guided FNAC, not an excision biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:


Marjolin's ulcer requires a wedge biopsy for diagnosis, soft tissue sarcomas are best diagnosed using core needle biopsy, and USG-guided FNAC is used for thyroid nodules.

choices.text: GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor)
SCC (Squamous Cell Carcinoma)

questions.text:
A female patient was diagnosed with gastric cancer. On immunohistopathology, the biopsy sample was found to be positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

 

LCA - Leukocyte common antigen
GIST - Gastrointestinal stromal tumors
SCC - Squamous cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor)

 

The clinical scenario, along with immunohistopathological findings showing positivity for CD117 and negativity for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100, is strongly suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST).

 

CD117 (also known as c-KIT) is a marker that is characteristically expressed in GIST. These tumors arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal in the gastrointestinal tract, with the stomach being the most common site. GISTs often present with gastrointestinal symptoms such as bleeding, and they express specific markers like CD117, PDGF receptor A, and sometimes CD34.

 

Other immunohistochemical (IHC) markers mentioned, like S100, cytokeratin, and LCA, are seen in different types of cancers:

 

  • S100 is associated with melanoma.
  • Cytokeratin is often found in squamous cell carcinoma.
  • LCA is found in lymphomas.

 

These negative results, combined with the positive CD117, make GIST the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinomas typically express markers such as cytokeratins (which are negative in this case), making this diagnosis less likely. Adenocarcinomas are not characterized by CD117 positivity.

 

Option C. Hodgkin's lymphoma: Hodgkin's lymphoma would typically express LCA (leukocyte common antigen), which is negative in this case. Additionally, CD117 is not a marker for Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option D. SCC (Squamous Cell Carcinoma): Squamous cell carcinoma typically shows cytokeratin positivity, which is absent here. Also, SCC does not usually express CD117.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are identified by the expression of CD117 (c-KIT) on immunohistochemistry, with the most common site being the stomach. Markers such as S100, cytokeratin, and LCA are negative in GIST but positive in other tumor types (melanoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and lymphoma, respectively).

questions.text: Disruption of the axon with an intact endoneurium is seen in which of the following? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axonotmesis

 

Disruption of the axon with an intact endoneurium is seen in axonotmesis. In this condition, there is axonal disruption (the inner axon is damaged), which leads to loss of conductivity, but the outer sheath of the nerve, including the endoneurium and perineurium, remains intact.

 

In axonotmesis:

 

  • There is a loss of conduction, but the nerve’s continuity is maintained because the neural tubes are intact. The axon is disrupted, meaning that its continuity is broken, but the endoneurium and perineurium remain intact.
  • It occurs following trauma, such as closed fractures and dislocations.
  • Wallerian degeneration occurs distal to the lesion, where the axon disintegrates and is resorbed by phagocytes. Axonal regeneration then begins, with fine unmyelinated fibers growing from the proximal stumps into the endoneurial tubes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurapraxia: Neurapraxia is a reversible physiological nerve conduction block that causes temporary loss of sensation and motor function. This condition is associated with segmental demyelination without axonal damage. It often follows prolonged compression, such as in Saturday night palsy or crutch palsy.

 

Option B. Axonapraxia: Axonapraxia refers to disruption at the level of the axoplasm and is a temporary failure of nerve conduction. It is not associated with structural damage to the axon itself.

 

Option D. Neurotmesis: Neurotmesis is the complete transection of the nerve trunk, typically associated with more severe injuries like open wounds. In this case, both the axon and the endoneurium are destroyed, leading to significant loss of function. The regenerating axons cannot re-enter the distal segment, resulting in poor recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Axonotmesis involves the disruption of the axon while the endoneurium and perineurium remain intact. This allows for axonal regeneration, unlike in more severe injuries like neurotmesis, where complete nerve continuity is lost.

questions.text:
A patient was brought following an RTA. He was found to have an incomplete lesion of the spinal cord. What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs.
  2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs.
  3. Bladder and bowel involvement.
  4. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

In this patient with central cord syndrome, LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk, UMN of lower limbs, and bladder and bowel involvement will be seen.

 

Central cord syndrome results from damage to the central region of the spinal cord, specifically affecting the gray matter nerve cells and the decussating spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal, which carry crude touch, pain, and temperature sensations.

 

This syndrome commonly occurs due to hyperextension of the cervical spine, causing compression of the spinal cord. Other causes include spinal trauma, syringomyelia, or intrinsic cord tumors.

 

Key clinical features include:

 

  • Arm weakness > leg weakness (upper limb motor loss is more severe than lower limb motor loss).
  • Dissociated sensory loss, with loss of crude touch, pain, and temperature sense, while proprioception and vibration senses are spared.
  • Bilateral lower motor neuron paralysis in the upper limbs and trunk (due to central damage), with upper motor neuron symptoms in the lower limbs.
  • Bladder and bowel dysfunction are frequently involved, and Horner’s syndrome can also occur.

 

This condition typically spares the posterior column, which is responsible for proprioception and fine touch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 and 4: While the LMN lesion of the upper limbs is correct, posterior tract involvement is incorrect, as the posterior columns (proprioception and vibration) are usually spared in central cord syndrome.

 

Option B. 2 and 3: UMN lesions of the upper limbs and trunk do not occur in central cord syndrome. Central cord syndrome primarily results in LMN lesions in the upper limbs, with UMN signs in the lower limbs.

 

Option C. 2 and 4: This combination incorrectly suggests UMN lesions in the upper limbs and posterior tract involvement, which are not features of central cord syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central cord syndrome is characterized by upper limb motor weakness (LMN), lower limb UMN signs, and bladder and bowel dysfunction. It often occurs following hyperextension injuries of the cervical spine and is marked by sensory dissociation (loss of pain and temperature, with sparing of proprioception and fine touch).

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery

questions.text: Bleeding as shown in the image is due to which of the following vessels? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bridging veins

 

The image shows a bleed under the dura, which is suggestive of a subdural hemorrhage (SDH). This type of hemorrhage typically results from the shearing of cortical bridging veins that traverse the space between the arachnoid and dura mater.

 

Subdural hemorrhage refers to a collection of blood in the space between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Common causes include:

 

  • Trauma
  • Use of anticoagulants or antiplatelets
  • Alcohol abuse
  • Battered baby syndrome

 

The preferred diagnostic test for subdural hemorrhage is non-contrast CT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle meningeal artery: A rupture of the middle meningeal artery results in an extradural (epidural) hemorrhage, which is not what is shown in the image.

 

Option C. Lenticulostriate artery: The lenticulostriate artery supplies the deep structures of the brain, and rupture leads to an intraparenchymal hemorrhage, not a subdural hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Vertebral artery: Vertebral artery dissection can lead to a subarachnoid hemorrhage or, in some cases, intraparenchymal hemorrhage, but not a subdural hemorrhage as seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A subdural hemorrhage is caused by the tearing of bridging veins between the dura and arachnoid. It is most commonly associated with head trauma, anticoagulant use, and alcohol abuse. The hallmark imaging finding is blood accumulation under the dura, and non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of management in a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA (Road Traffic Accident)? (INICET NOV 2022) 

 

  1. Cervical spine stabilization
  2. Intubation
  3. IV cannulation
  4. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The correct sequence of management in a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA is Option B. Cervical spine stabilization, Intubation, IV cannulation, and CECT, as per the ABCDE protocol in trauma management.

 

According to the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) protocol, the management follows the primary survey with the following steps:

 

  1. Cervical spine stabilization: Always prioritize stabilizing the cervical spine in trauma patients, especially in cases where spinal injury is suspected.
  2. Intubation: After airway management, securing the airway via intubation is crucial to ensure oxygenation and prevent aspiration.
  3. IV cannulation: Establish intravenous access for fluid resuscitation and medication administration.
  4. CECT: Imaging, such as contrast-enhanced CT (CECT), is performed once the patient is stabilized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 3, 2, 4: While cervical spine stabilization is correctly prioritized, IV cannulation should not occur before securing the airway with intubation. Airway management is always the top priority after stabilizing the cervical spine.

 

Option C. 2, 1, 3, 4: Intubation before cervical spine stabilization is incorrect because spinal injury protection takes precedence in trauma patients. Airway management should follow after ensuring the spine is stabilized.

 

Option D. 2, 1, 4, 3: Intubation before cervical spine stabilization is incorrect, and performing CECT before IV cannulation would delay critical fluid resuscitation and medication access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence in the primary survey of trauma management includes cervical spine stabilization, airway protection (intubation), intravenous access, and imaging (CECT) to assess injuries. Following the ATLS protocol ensures patient stabilization and appropriate treatment priorities.

questions.text: Delayed hypersensitivity is due to ______. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

Delayed hypersensitivity is due to interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma).

 

Delayed hypersensitivity, also known as type 4 hypersensitivity, is a cell-mediated immune response primarily mediated by T cells. It occurs by two mechanisms:

 

  1. CD4+ T helper cells (Th1) mediated.
  2. CD8+ T cells mediated.

 

CD4+ T helper cells mediated pathway:

 

Antigen peptides recognized by CD4+ T cells cause these cells to secrete interleukin-2 (IL-2), which promotes the proliferation of T cells responding to the antigen. These T cells differentiate into Th1 or Th17 cells due to cytokines released from antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

 

APCs also release interleukin-12, which further promotes differentiation to the Th1 subset. Inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and IL-23 drive differentiation into the Th17 subset. These Th1 cells release interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma), which alters macrophage activity to help clear the antigen.

 

Interferon-gamma causes several changes in macrophages:

 

  1. Enhances their ability to phagocytose and kill microorganisms.
  2. Promotes class 2 MHC molecule expression, improving antigen presentation.
  3. Increases secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and interleukin-1.
  4. Amplifies the Th1 response by promoting further release of interleukin-12.

 

CD8+ T cells mediated pathway:

 

CD8+ T cells attack antigen-presenting target cells through the release of perforins and granzymes, which induce apoptosis. In the process, interferon-gamma is also released, which drives the hypersensitivity reaction by stimulating inflammatory mediators.

 

Examples of delayed hypersensitivity reactions include the tuberculin reaction and contact dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interleukin-2: Although interleukin-2 is involved in the proliferation of T cells and differentiation into Th1 cells, it does not directly cause delayed hypersensitivity. Its primary role is to enhance the response of T cells during the immune response.

 

Option C. Interleukin-12: Interleukin-12 helps to differentiate T cells into the Th1 subset and promotes the release of interferon-gamma, but it is not the primary mediator of delayed hypersensitivity itself. Interferon-gamma is the direct effector responsible for activating macrophages and driving the type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.

 

Option D. Interleukin-4: Interleukin-4 is primarily involved in the differentiation of T cells into the Th2 subset, which is related to humoral immunity and not to delayed hypersensitivity. Th2 responses are associated with allergies and antibody production rather than the cell-mediated immune response seen in delayed hypersensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) plays a central role in delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity, as it activates macrophages and amplifies the immune response. This process is critical in conditions such as tuberculin reactions and contact dermatitis.

choices.text: Arnold stick test

questions.text: What test is not used for testing olfaction? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arnold stick test

 

The Arnold stick test is not a test used for olfaction.

 

Tests used for olfaction include the following:

 

  1. Smell diskettes are used as a screening test for olfaction. These reusable diskettes are applied with 8 different odorants, and a questionnaire with illustrations is used to score the patient’s responses.
  2. The University of Pennsylvania smell identification test (UPSIT) is a commercially available, self-administered test. It assesses the function of an individual's olfactory system by using microencapsulated odorants in scratch-and-sniff booklets.
  3. The 12-item version of UPSIT, known as the cross-cultural smell identification test (CC-SIT), is useful for quantifying smell loss in a shorter time frame, taking less than 5 minutes. It is an effective means of assessing olfactory function.
  4. The Sniffin' sticks test is another method used to evaluate olfactory performance. This test is based on pen-like odor-dispensing devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Arnold stick test is not used to test olfaction. Common tests for evaluating the olfactory system include smell diskettes, UPSIT, and CC-SIT.
